G5202.W3 1855 ,C6 THE REPUBLIC OE CHILL
Astronomical Position.—Between latitudes 24° 30' and 55° 597 south, and longitudes G8° 5CV and 74° 357 west from Greenwich, or 2° 28' and 06/ east from Washington.
Boundaries.—Northern: the Desert of Atacama;—eastern: the great chain of the Andes, which separates Chili from the Argentine Confederation;—southern: Cape Horn, the southern extremity of South America; and—western: the Pacific Ocean.
Dimensions.—The greatest length of Chili, north and south, is 2,140 miles; and the width varies from 80 or 90 miles in the north to 220 in the middle portion, thence narrowing gradually southward. Including Chilian Patagonia, and the islands near the mainland and those of Juan Fernandez (in lat. 33° 40' south, and long. 69° 00/ west), the superficial area of the Republic is estimated at 249,952 square miles.
General Aspect.—The mainland of Chili is an inclined plane, rapidly sinking from the base of the Andes to the shores of the Pacific. The country is generally hilly, being crowded with ramifications from the Andes, which gradually diminish in height as they recede from the main ridge and approach the sea, forming elevated plateaux, often covered with timber and a rich vegetation, and between them deep valleys, some of them of considerable breadth, and many of them highly fertile, though numerous others are mere ravines. The richest and most luxuriant of these districts are in the south, where the scenery is pleasing and picturesque. Proceeding north, toward Valparaiso, the hills begin to look bleak and naked, being thinly clad with a stunted brushwood ; and at Coquimbo even this disappears, giving place to a scanty sprinkling of wiry grass. Still farther north a scene of utter desolation presents itself, the hills and plains being covered with bare sand, and no trace of vegetation visible. This latter portion of the country is the great mineral region.
Mountains, etc.—The mean elevation of the great chain of the Andes that runs along the eastern limits of the country is from 13,000 to 14,000 feet above the sea-level, but many of the peaks rise much higher. The loftiest summits are those of Tupungato, to the east of Santiago, 22,450 feet high; Joncal, 20,348 feet above the level of the sea; and sixteen volcanoes, placed at proportional distances each from the other. Among the latter are Aconcagua (22,301 feet high), San Jose (18,150 feet), Petorca (memorable for its eruption in 1764), the Chilian, An-tuco, Yillarica, Hanahue, Calbuco, and Oorcobado. Few of these are active volcanoes, and hence the frequency of those terrible convulsions for which Chili has been notorious. In 1822 Valparaiso and a number of other towns were destroyed by one of these perturbations, and again in 1851 Valparaiso and Santiago, the capital, were partially laid in ruins. Thunder and lightning in the valleys of Chili are seldom experienced, being drawn off by the mountains, and to the same cause is attributable the long dry season, from October to May, of the middle and northern sections. The northern provinces have only one or two 8 lowers during the winter, while in the south the rainy season often lasts six or seven months. The night dews of summer, however, are copious, and, in connection with the system of irrigation pursued, cover the fields with luxuriant verdure. Hence these vast mountain ranges act no unimportant part in the physical economy of the country, and on them depend the climatic peculiarities that have made Chili the granary of the Pacific. The great chain has also several passes, important alike in a military as in a commercial point of view.
Rivers, Lakes, etc.—There are one hundred and twenty rivers worthy of notice, forty of which, embodying the waters of the others, are lost in the ocean; and though the narrowness of the country limits very much the length of their courses, some of them are navigable half their way, as the Sinfondo, Bueno, Chaivin, Valdivia, Cauten, Tolten, and Maule. The- Biobio, the largest of all, is much interrupted in consequence of the many reefs and dangers that its bed conceals. There are aLso several thermal waters, particularly in the Cordilleras. The most celebrated in the central part of Chili, on account of their medicinal qualities, are those of Cauquenes, Colin a, and Serquilanquen—the second named a very fashionable resort during the summer season. The lakes are few and small: the principal ones of salt water are Bucalemu. Caliuil, Buchuquen, and Bolleruca; and of fresh water— Villarica, Banco, and Aculeo, near Santiago. The whole of Chili belongs to the basin of the Pacific, excepting the Valley of Uspallata, in the latitude of Valparaiso, and formed by a bifurcation of the Andes, which sends waters to the Atlantic.
Doasts, Harbors, etc.—The coast is bold and rocky, and in general has deep water close in shore. The harbors are numerous, but many of them require the hand of industry to make them available. Beginning at the north—Betas, at the mouth of the Salado, Joncal, and ChaHaral do las Animas are unsheltered; Caldera has the best anchorage in the Copiapo harbor: Iluasco and Coquimbo, safe and beautiful; Valparaiso, the principal port, open to the north winds and unsafe; San Antonio, Topocalma, and Buchuquen insignificant; Constitu5ion, in the mouth of the Maule, dangerous on account of its movable banks; Curanipe, Tome, Cerrilloverde, and Talcahuano, in the large and fine Bay of Concepcion; San Vicente, and after some others on the coast of Arauco, Valdivia, the best port of Chili. The Archipelago of Chiloe has two fine ports, Ancud and Castro. Following 'the coast of the continent, there are San Jose, the Bay of Purgatorio, St. Quintin’s, San Estevan, San Andres, and on the Straits of Magellan San Felipe or Famine. In this latter is the fortress Bulnes, that contains a Chilian colony.
Islands, etc.—The islands of Chili are—the Coquimbanos, called Mu-jillon, Totorol, and Pajaros; Juan Fernandez, called La de Tierra, and Mas a Fuera, the former of which is fourteen leagues in circumference, mountainous and damp, but fertile ; Guiriquina, at the entrance of the Bay of Concepyion; Talca or Santa Maria, with two excellent ports; Mocha, near the coast of Arauco, twenty leagues in circumference, and with two good harbors; and the archipelagoes of Chiloe and of Chinos, and the islands to the south of them as far as Cape Horn, which form a province of the Republic.
Minerals.—Nature has been prodigal in the mineral kingdom of Chili. Gold is found in its mountains, in the earth of many places, and mingled with the sands of many rivers and torrents. The silver ores of Chafiarcello and Tres-Puntas have effaced the reputation of those of Potosi; but in copper Chili has no competitor in the world, its abundant ore being not seldom enriched by having in its composition large quantities of gold. To these three staples, and the lead and tin sufficient for home consumption, the mining industry of Chili is at present directed; but the investigation of naturalists have sufficiently demonstrated that quicksilver and iron, rich marbles, jasper, alabaster, agate, jet, sapphire, load-stone, rock-crystal, sulphur, coal, and slate exist in immense quantities, and at no distant future will become exhaustless sources of wealth to the country.
Climate.—The climate is one of the healthiest in the world, but the atmosphere near the sea-coast is still finer than that of the interior, being less subject to variations. January and February are the hottest months of the year, the thermometer frequently indicating 90° and 95° Fahr. in the shade, but after sunset the air is cooled by a refreshing breeze. Rains fall only in the winter months, and after these the whole valley country is clothed in a vast and gorgeous variety of flowers. The rains are frequently so heavy as to interrupt all out-door business, in the interior parts of the Cordilleras, snow falls at intervals during the winter, and in some of the mountain gorges never disappears altogether. Generally by December the greater part has been melted,
supplying the rivers with an abundance of water. In the central parts storms of hail are frequent in the winter, and thunder and lightning in the more elevated regions. The lightning is very vivid and the thunder appalling, from its reverberation among the hills and ravines. The climate, however, varies considerably with the latitude, and also with the physical formation of localities.
Vegetation.—Though possessing many fertile tracts, a great portion of Chili is unsusceptible of cultivation, being naked and mountainous, especially toward the north. The south provinces present a different appearance ; and here a profuse vegetation prevails—-dense forests are spread over the land, and the sides of the Andes are covered with herbaceous plants and flowers of the richest and most beautiful hues. Laurels, myrtles, cypresses, and other evergreens, attain here a gigantic size, their timber being available for various purposes. Hard woods of different descriptions also abound, and throughout the country valuable medicinal herbs are indigenous.
Animals.—Chili is remarkably free from the larger and fiercer animals, and also from noxious insects and reptiles. The animals common to the continent, however, are found here, including the guanaco, a species of llama, the cougar or puma, the jaguar, monkeys, etc., and the skunk, remarkable for the offensive odor it emits. Among the feathered race are the great condor, vultures, pelicans, parrots, parro-quets, etc. On the coast, whales, dolphins, cods, pilchards, etc., are caught. Fish and shell-fish of all kinds, indeed, are very plentiful, and on the shores and in the waters of Chiloe they supply the subsistence of thousands of swine, the meat of which is of a delicate and exquisite flavor. All the domestic animals of the old continent have been prodigiously propagated and improved. The horse is more fiery, and much handsomer than its Andalusian progenitor; the cow larger and more robust than that of Europe ; the sheep furnish long and fine wool. Black cattle are raised in great numbers. The mules and asses are also excellent, being of good size and of extraordinary endurance.
Divisions, Population, etc.—Chili is divided into 13 provinces and 2 colonies, 57 departments, 453 sub-delegations, and 2,131 districts. The area and population of the provinces in 1855 were as follows:

—of the total, 712,932 were males and 726,188 females. Population in 1833, 1,010,336; in 1843, 1,119,802, and in 1855,1,439,120. It 1857 it was estimated at 1,558,319, and in 1860 at 1,679, 641.
Productive Industry.—The most important branches of industry pursued in Chili are mining, agriculture, and commerce. In these the country ranks high among the Indo-Spanish nations of South America. Manufactures, properly so called, have made but little progress, but still many of the wants of the people are supplied by Chilian artisans.
1.	Mining.—The principal mining operations are carried on in the provinces north of the Rio Maule. Many of the mines are worked by foreign companies. The production and exports for the year 1859 were as follows—copper in bars, 177,765 quintals ; native copper, 257,852 quintals; ores of copper, 559,560 quintals; silver and copper-ores, 9,873 quintals; ores of silver, 255,799 quintals; ores of cobalt, 4,348 quintals; and silver in bars, etc., 270,984 marcs. The copper ores are sent chiefly to Wales for smelting, but of'late years large quantities have been reduced at the mines.
2.	Agriculture.—The Chilians are industrious agriculturists, and though unacquainted witli modern implements or the scientific modes of cultivation, produce abundant crops, and have a large amount of live-stock. Some of the grazing farms own from 20,000 to 30,000 heads of cattle. The southern provinces contain the most fertile lands, and are those best watered. In the north, maize is the principal object of culture, and in the south, wheat and barley. Wheat, however, may be considered as the staple of the valleys. Leguminous vegetables are grown in abundance, and furnish the laboring classes with a wholesome, cheap food. Chili is also the country of the potato. The hemp of Chili is not inferior to the European, and linseed grows wild in Valdivia. The vine, as varied as abundant, is grown from Co piapo as far as Concep9ion, and will produce all the varieties of the foreign wines. The fruits and plants of all regions flourish in the open air, but the culture of some, as the cotton-plant and sugar-cane have been abandoned, as not being remunerative. Fruits are abundant in their seasons, and apples, pears, apricots, nectarines, plums, peaches, cherries, figs, grapes, oranges, limes, water-melons, gourds, etc., find in one part or another of the country a suitable climate and soil.
3.	Manufactures.—Cliili does not claim to be a manufacturing country. It lias, however, a considerable number of minor establishments, making hempen cloth, earthen-ware, cordage, soap, copper-ware, leather, brandy, tallow, etc., and besides these it possesses a large number of flour mills, which produce an excellent article. In the cities are found artists working in gold and silver. A large portion of the population also wear home-made stuff's, especially wmolens, and yet the importation of textile fabrics is constantly increasing.
4.	Commerce.—Chili has a valuable commerce with all the leading nations of the Old and New Worlds, and this of late years, under the influence of favoring circumstances, has wonderfully prospered. The number of ships entered in 1859 was 1,137, with 339,031 tons; and cleared, 1,143, with 341,914 tons. Among these were 76 war vessels, 884 guns, entered and cleared. The imports and exports for the ten years ending with 1859, have been as follows :

The principal exports are flour, grain, and minerals; and the principal imports, European and American manufactured goods, iron and iron-ware, sugar, tea, coffee, etc. The mercantile marine consisted in 1859 of 267 vessels, with an aggregate burden of 62,209 tons, manned by 2,281 seamen.
5. Internal ancl Transit Trade.—The internal trade of the Republic is limited for want of good roads. Until lately, the almost sole means of transport was by mule-carriage. There are now, however, several railroads extending from the ports to the interior, viz.; one from Caldera to Copiapo, 50 miles long; one from Valparaiso to Limache, 36 miles, and which will be extended to Santiago, 110 miles; one from Santiago to San Bernardino, 12 miles, to be extended to Talca and Santa Fe; and a short line between Talcahuana and Concept-ion. There are
* Indefinite, and included in Chilian Patagonia.
t To this should bo added 115,590 square miles, which is the area of Chilian Patagonia.
also several others in various stages of progress. These will open up a considerable part of the country, and already their effect has been to develop the vast wealth of regions hitherto inaccessible to the markets. Besides its own commerce, the country also enjoys a large transit trade, chiefly with the Argentine Republic, which imports and exports largely tnrough the ports of Chili.
Government.—The sovereignty rests with the nation, and the right of voting is secured to all who can read and write or who have any profession or trade. Foreigners may become citizens after a residence of ten years, or if married and supporting a family, of six years, and if married to a Chilian woman, only three years. The legislative power is exercised by a Congress composed of a Chamber of Deputies (one member for every 20,000 inhabitants), elected for three years, and a Senate, of 20 members, elected by provincial colleges, one third trien-nially. The President is also elected indirectly, and holds his office for five years. In case of absence or disability, his place is occupied by the Minister of the Interior. The President is aided in his functions by a Council of State, which is composed of the four ministers and representatives of the judiciary, the Church, the army, etc. The judiciary is exercised by a superior court in the capital, courts of appeal at Con-cep9ion, Santiago, and La Serena, a tribunal of accounts, and in the provincial capitals, primary courts of civil and criminal jurisdiction, etc. The provinces are governed by intendentes, appointed by the President, and the departments, sub-delegations, and districts, by governors, sub-delegates, and inspectors respectively.
Army and Navy.—The military force of the Republic consists of—artillery 303, infantry 1,593, cavalry 665, military school 38, and invalids 409—2,993 men of all arms. The national guard or militia numbers 54,682 men, viz., 1,080 artillery, 29,757 infantry, and 23,845 cavalry. The national navy consists of two screw and two side-wheel steamers, average 200 horse-power, and carrying in all 28 guns ; and three sail-vessels, carrying in all 42 guns. There is also a frigate used as a naval school. There were under construction, in 1859, three steamers.
Revenue, Debt, etc.—The public debt of Chili consists of two series—a foreign and a domestic debt. The former originated in a loan of £1,000,000 sterling, made in 1822, which was to have been redeemed by installments in thirty years. On account of the disturbed state of the country, however, neither principal nor interest were disbursed for many years, and the debt had almost doubled, when in 1842 the whole was consolidated on the terms that the original debt should pay 6 per cent, and the interest 3 per cent, per annum. Since this arrangement, no default has been made, and in 1859 the debt had been reduced t<* £1,152,800. The domestic debt in the same year amounted to $2,225,575, which bears 3 per cent, interest. The revenue, in 1860, amounted to $8,795,243, of which about one half accrued from cus* toms, and was expended—for general state purposes, $1,295,304; fov the judiciary, worship, and schools, $1,093,829; for the army and navy, $1,913,289 ; and for debt, etc., $2,402,821.
Religion.—The Roman Catholic is the state religion, and the public exercise of any other is forbidden. The Church is under the direction of the Archbishop of Santiago and the bishops of Concep9ion, Coquimbo, and San Carlos de Chiloe.
Education.—Of the total population in 1855, only 193,853 (123,437* males and 70,416 females) or 13.5 per cent, could read, and only 153,294 (100,011 males and 53,283 females) or 10.7 per cent, could write. This, however, is a great improvement since 1832, when the first national schools were established, before which education had very limited facilities, and those only open to the wealthy. or a total in all the institutions, in 1855, of 35,308, or 2.4 per cent, of the total population. During 1854 the state distributed to the school libraries about 98,000 volumes. In 1832 there were in the Bepublio only two national schools: in 1842, 28; in 1852, 157. The increase, since this last-named year, has been remarkably rapid.
Principal Cities, Towns, etc.—Santiago, the capital, founded 12 Feb., 1541, is located in a delightful valley, 2,000 feet above the sea (lat. 33° 35" S., and long. 70° 44' W.). It has many handsome buildings, most of them only one story high, as a precaution against earthquakes. Among these are a university, a national institute, a school of arts and trades, a school of agriculture, a museum, a normal school for teachers, many academies, a large public library, two theatres, two hospitals, a penitentiary, several charitable establishments, and a great many churches and convents. Congress meets here on the 1st June annually. Population 80,000. Valparaiso is the chief port, and has an active commerce. The theatre is perhaps the largest and finest in America, and this is the only place in Chili at which Protestants have a chapel. Population 20,000. North from Santiago are San Felipe de Aconcagua, with a lyceum, etc.; La Serena, a considerable town; Coquimbo, a noted port; Copiapo, the centre of a vast mining industry, and connected with the port of the same name by railroad, etc. To the south of Santiago are San Fernando, the capital of Colchagua; Talca, near which is the Descabezado, one of the highest mountains of Chili; Cauquenes, and its port Constitution ; Concepcion, and its port Talcahuano ; Valdivia, around which many Germans have settlements; Sanr Carlos, the capital of Chiloe, and a tine port, etc. There are also several flourishing cities in the interior.
History.—Of the original inhabitants of Chili, history has left no records. In 1532, Pizarro, the conqueror of Peru, sent his colleague, Almagro, into the country, but lie was driven back by the Indians. A second invasion was undertaken in 1540, which proved more successful, although it cost more sacrifice of life and treasure than the conquest of all the rest of America; nor have the Araucanians, the bravest of the aboriginal tribes, succumbed to this day. The Spanish colony was governed by a captain-general, president of the kingdom of Chili, a royal court of justice as his advisers, several tribunals, intendentes, and chiefs, until Napoleon’s army entered Spain. The Chilians embraced this opportunity to throw off their allegiance to the Spanish crown, and on the 18th September, 1810, established a junta guber-nativa, and the first national Congress was inaugurated in Santiago on the 14th July, 1811. Soon the Spaniards commenced a sanguinary war against the patriots, and after many vicissitudes the Chilian army obtained a complete triumph in Chacabuco, on the 12th Feb., 1817. On the same day of the following year the independence of the Republic of Cliili was sworn to and promulgated to the world. The glorious victory of Maipu, on the 5th April of that year, sealed that declaration, and the Spaniards lost the last bulwark they had by the surrender of Chiloe in January, 1826. Civil war, the most fearful of calamities, succeeded to the sacred war for liberty; one constitution was tried after another, and the infancy of the Republic was thus prolonged. But at last the people became tired of so many misfortunes, and a constitution was promulgated on the 25th May, 1833, which has been for Chili a sheet-anchor of salvation.

G5202.W3 1855 ,C6 THE REPUBLIC OE CHILL
Astronomical Position.—Between latitudes 24° 30' and 55° 597 south, and longitudes G8° 5CV and 74° 357 west from Greenwich, or 2° 28' and 06/ east from Washington.
Boundaries.—Northern: the Desert of Atacama;—eastern: the great chain of the Andes, which separates Chili from the Argentine Confederation;—southern: Cape Horn, the southern extremity of South America; and—western: the Pacific Ocean.
Dimensions.—The greatest length of Chili, north and south, is 2,140 miles; and the width varies from 80 or 90 miles in the north to 220 in the middle portion, thence narrowing gradually southward. Including Chilian Patagonia, and the islands near the mainland and those of Juan Fernandez (in lat. 33° 40' south, and long. 69° 00/ west), the superficial area of the Republic is estimated at 249,952 square miles.
General Aspect.—The mainland of Chili is an inclined plane, rapidly sinking from the base of the Andes to the shores of the Pacific. The country is generally hilly, being crowded with ramifications from the Andes, which gradually diminish in height as they recede from the main ridge and approach the sea, forming elevated plateaux, often covered with timber and a rich vegetation, and between them deep valleys, some of them of considerable breadth, and many of them highly fertile, though numerous others are mere ravines. The richest and most luxuriant of these districts are in the south, where the scenery is pleasing and picturesque. Proceeding north, toward Valparaiso, the hills begin to look bleak and naked, being thinly clad with a stunted brushwood ; and at Coquimbo even this disappears, giving place to a scanty sprinkling of wiry grass. Still farther north a scene of utter desolation presents itself, the hills and plains being covered with bare sand, and no trace of vegetation visible. This latter portion of the country is the great mineral region.
Mountains, etc.—The mean elevation of the great chain of the Andes that runs along the eastern limits of the country is from 13,000 to 14,000 feet above the sea-level, but many of the peaks rise much higher. The loftiest summits are those of Tupungato, to the east of Santiago, 22,450 feet high; Joncal, 20,348 feet above the level of the sea; and sixteen volcanoes, placed at proportional distances each from the other. Among the latter are Aconcagua (22,301 feet high), San Jose (18,150 feet), Petorca (memorable for its eruption in 1764), the Chilian, An-tuco, Yillarica, Hanahue, Calbuco, and Oorcobado. Few of these are active volcanoes, and hence the frequency of those terrible convulsions for which Chili has been notorious. In 1822 Valparaiso and a number of other towns were destroyed by one of these perturbations, and again in 1851 Valparaiso and Santiago, the capital, were partially laid in ruins. Thunder and lightning in the valleys of Chili are seldom experienced, being drawn off by the mountains, and to the same cause is attributable the long dry season, from October to May, of the middle and northern sections. The northern provinces have only one or two 8 lowers during the winter, while in the south the rainy season often lasts six or seven months. The night dews of summer, however, are copious, and, in connection with the system of irrigation pursued, cover the fields with luxuriant verdure. Hence these vast mountain ranges act no unimportant part in the physical economy of the country, and on them depend the climatic peculiarities that have made Chili the granary of the Pacific. The great chain has also several passes, important alike in a military as in a commercial point of view.
Rivers, Lakes, etc.—There are one hundred and twenty rivers worthy of notice, forty of which, embodying the waters of the others, are lost in the ocean; and though the narrowness of the country limits very much the length of their courses, some of them are navigable half their way, as the Sinfondo, Bueno, Chaivin, Valdivia, Cauten, Tolten, and Maule. The- Biobio, the largest of all, is much interrupted in consequence of the many reefs and dangers that its bed conceals. There are aLso several thermal waters, particularly in the Cordilleras. The most celebrated in the central part of Chili, on account of their medicinal qualities, are those of Cauquenes, Colin a, and Serquilanquen—the second named a very fashionable resort during the summer season. The lakes are few and small: the principal ones of salt water are Bucalemu. Caliuil, Buchuquen, and Bolleruca; and of fresh water— Villarica, Banco, and Aculeo, near Santiago. The whole of Chili belongs to the basin of the Pacific, excepting the Valley of Uspallata, in the latitude of Valparaiso, and formed by a bifurcation of the Andes, which sends waters to the Atlantic.
Doasts, Harbors, etc.—The coast is bold and rocky, and in general has deep water close in shore. The harbors are numerous, but many of them require the hand of industry to make them available. Beginning at the north—Betas, at the mouth of the Salado, Joncal, and ChaHaral do las Animas are unsheltered; Caldera has the best anchorage in the Copiapo harbor: Iluasco and Coquimbo, safe and beautiful; Valparaiso, the principal port, open to the north winds and unsafe; San Antonio, Topocalma, and Buchuquen insignificant; Constitu5ion, in the mouth of the Maule, dangerous on account of its movable banks; Curanipe, Tome, Cerrilloverde, and Talcahuano, in the large and fine Bay of Concepcion; San Vicente, and after some others on the coast of Arauco, Valdivia, the best port of Chili. The Archipelago of Chiloe has two fine ports, Ancud and Castro. Following 'the coast of the continent, there are San Jose, the Bay of Purgatorio, St. Quintin’s, San Estevan, San Andres, and on the Straits of Magellan San Felipe or Famine. In this latter is the fortress Bulnes, that contains a Chilian colony.
Islands, etc.—The islands of Chili are—the Coquimbanos, called Mu-jillon, Totorol, and Pajaros; Juan Fernandez, called La de Tierra, and Mas a Fuera, the former of which is fourteen leagues in circumference, mountainous and damp, but fertile ; Guiriquina, at the entrance of the Bay of Concepyion; Talca or Santa Maria, with two excellent ports; Mocha, near the coast of Arauco, twenty leagues in circumference, and with two good harbors; and the archipelagoes of Chiloe and of Chinos, and the islands to the south of them as far as Cape Horn, which form a province of the Republic.
Minerals.—Nature has been prodigal in the mineral kingdom of Chili. Gold is found in its mountains, in the earth of many places, and mingled with the sands of many rivers and torrents. The silver ores of Chafiarcello and Tres-Puntas have effaced the reputation of those of Potosi; but in copper Chili has no competitor in the world, its abundant ore being not seldom enriched by having in its composition large quantities of gold. To these three staples, and the lead and tin sufficient for home consumption, the mining industry of Chili is at present directed; but the investigation of naturalists have sufficiently demonstrated that quicksilver and iron, rich marbles, jasper, alabaster, agate, jet, sapphire, load-stone, rock-crystal, sulphur, coal, and slate exist in immense quantities, and at no distant future will become exhaustless sources of wealth to the country.
Climate.—The climate is one of the healthiest in the world, but the atmosphere near the sea-coast is still finer than that of the interior, being less subject to variations. January and February are the hottest months of the year, the thermometer frequently indicating 90° and 95° Fahr. in the shade, but after sunset the air is cooled by a refreshing breeze. Rains fall only in the winter months, and after these the whole valley country is clothed in a vast and gorgeous variety of flowers. The rains are frequently so heavy as to interrupt all out-door business, in the interior parts of the Cordilleras, snow falls at intervals during the winter, and in some of the mountain gorges never disappears altogether. Generally by December the greater part has been melted,
supplying the rivers with an abundance of water. In the central parts storms of hail are frequent in the winter, and thunder and lightning in the more elevated regions. The lightning is very vivid and the thunder appalling, from its reverberation among the hills and ravines. The climate, however, varies considerably with the latitude, and also with the physical formation of localities.
Vegetation.—Though possessing many fertile tracts, a great portion of Chili is unsusceptible of cultivation, being naked and mountainous, especially toward the north. The south provinces present a different appearance ; and here a profuse vegetation prevails—-dense forests are spread over the land, and the sides of the Andes are covered with herbaceous plants and flowers of the richest and most beautiful hues. Laurels, myrtles, cypresses, and other evergreens, attain here a gigantic size, their timber being available for various purposes. Hard woods of different descriptions also abound, and throughout the country valuable medicinal herbs are indigenous.
Animals.—Chili is remarkably free from the larger and fiercer animals, and also from noxious insects and reptiles. The animals common to the continent, however, are found here, including the guanaco, a species of llama, the cougar or puma, the jaguar, monkeys, etc., and the skunk, remarkable for the offensive odor it emits. Among the feathered race are the great condor, vultures, pelicans, parrots, parro-quets, etc. On the coast, whales, dolphins, cods, pilchards, etc., are caught. Fish and shell-fish of all kinds, indeed, are very plentiful, and on the shores and in the waters of Chiloe they supply the subsistence of thousands of swine, the meat of which is of a delicate and exquisite flavor. All the domestic animals of the old continent have been prodigiously propagated and improved. The horse is more fiery, and much handsomer than its Andalusian progenitor; the cow larger and more robust than that of Europe ; the sheep furnish long and fine wool. Black cattle are raised in great numbers. The mules and asses are also excellent, being of good size and of extraordinary endurance.
Divisions, Population, etc.—Chili is divided into 13 provinces and 2 colonies, 57 departments, 453 sub-delegations, and 2,131 districts. The area and population of the provinces in 1855 were as follows:

—of the total, 712,932 were males and 726,188 females. Population in 1833, 1,010,336; in 1843, 1,119,802, and in 1855,1,439,120. It 1857 it was estimated at 1,558,319, and in 1860 at 1,679, 641.
Productive Industry.—The most important branches of industry pursued in Chili are mining, agriculture, and commerce. In these the country ranks high among the Indo-Spanish nations of South America. Manufactures, properly so called, have made but little progress, but still many of the wants of the people are supplied by Chilian artisans.
1.	Mining.—The principal mining operations are carried on in the provinces north of the Rio Maule. Many of the mines are worked by foreign companies. The production and exports for the year 1859 were as follows—copper in bars, 177,765 quintals ; native copper, 257,852 quintals; ores of copper, 559,560 quintals; silver and copper-ores, 9,873 quintals; ores of silver, 255,799 quintals; ores of cobalt, 4,348 quintals; and silver in bars, etc., 270,984 marcs. The copper ores are sent chiefly to Wales for smelting, but of'late years large quantities have been reduced at the mines.
2.	Agriculture.—The Chilians are industrious agriculturists, and though unacquainted witli modern implements or the scientific modes of cultivation, produce abundant crops, and have a large amount of live-stock. Some of the grazing farms own from 20,000 to 30,000 heads of cattle. The southern provinces contain the most fertile lands, and are those best watered. In the north, maize is the principal object of culture, and in the south, wheat and barley. Wheat, however, may be considered as the staple of the valleys. Leguminous vegetables are grown in abundance, and furnish the laboring classes with a wholesome, cheap food. Chili is also the country of the potato. The hemp of Chili is not inferior to the European, and linseed grows wild in Valdivia. The vine, as varied as abundant, is grown from Co piapo as far as Concep9ion, and will produce all the varieties of the foreign wines. The fruits and plants of all regions flourish in the open air, but the culture of some, as the cotton-plant and sugar-cane have been abandoned, as not being remunerative. Fruits are abundant in their seasons, and apples, pears, apricots, nectarines, plums, peaches, cherries, figs, grapes, oranges, limes, water-melons, gourds, etc., find in one part or another of the country a suitable climate and soil.
3.	Manufactures.—Cliili does not claim to be a manufacturing country. It lias, however, a considerable number of minor establishments, making hempen cloth, earthen-ware, cordage, soap, copper-ware, leather, brandy, tallow, etc., and besides these it possesses a large number of flour mills, which produce an excellent article. In the cities are found artists working in gold and silver. A large portion of the population also wear home-made stuff's, especially wmolens, and yet the importation of textile fabrics is constantly increasing.
4.	Commerce.—Chili has a valuable commerce with all the leading nations of the Old and New Worlds, and this of late years, under the influence of favoring circumstances, has wonderfully prospered. The number of ships entered in 1859 was 1,137, with 339,031 tons; and cleared, 1,143, with 341,914 tons. Among these were 76 war vessels, 884 guns, entered and cleared. The imports and exports for the ten years ending with 1859, have been as follows :
Years.	Imports.	Exports.	Years.	Imports.	Exports.
1850 .		$11,78S,193 ....	....$12,426,269	1855 		.$1S,443,287 ....		$17,676,911
1851 .		 15,884,972 ....	.... 12,146,391	1856 		. 17,676,911 ....		 18,159,522
1852 .		 15,347,232 ....	... 12,116,468	1857 		. 22,75S,861 ....		 18,378,967
1853 .		 16,687,178 ....	.... 13,011,627	1858 ........	. 23,649-690 ....		 18,335,442
1854 .		 17,42S,299 ....	.... 14,627,156	1S59		. 24,761,S66 ....		 19,558,254
The principal exports are flour, grain, and minerals; and the principal imports, European and American manufactured goods, iron and iron-ware, sugar, tea, coffee, etc. The mercantile marine consisted in 1859 of 267 vessels, with an aggregate burden of 62,209 tons, manned by 2,281 seamen.
5. Internal ancl Transit Trade.—The internal trade of the Republic is limited for want of good roads. Until lately, the almost sole means of transport was by mule-carriage. There are now, however, several railroads extending from the ports to the interior, viz.; one from Caldera to Copiapo, 50 miles long; one from Valparaiso to Limache, 36 miles, and which will be extended to Santiago, 110 miles; one from Santiago to San Bernardino, 12 miles, to be extended to Talca and Santa Fe; and a short line between Talcahuana and Concept-ion. There are
* Indefinite, and included in Chilian Patagonia.
t To this should bo added 115,590 square miles, which is the area of Chilian Patagonia.
also several others in various stages of progress. These will open up a considerable part of the country, and already their effect has been to develop the vast wealth of regions hitherto inaccessible to the markets. Besides its own commerce, the country also enjoys a large transit trade, chiefly with the Argentine Republic, which imports and exports largely tnrough the ports of Chili.
Government.—The sovereignty rests with the nation, and the right of voting is secured to all who can read and write or who have any profession or trade. Foreigners may become citizens after a residence of ten years, or if married and supporting a family, of six years, and if married to a Chilian woman, only three years. The legislative power is exercised by a Congress composed of a Chamber of Deputies (one member for every 20,000 inhabitants), elected for three years, and a Senate, of 20 members, elected by provincial colleges, one third trien-nially. The President is also elected indirectly, and holds his office for five years. In case of absence or disability, his place is occupied by the Minister of the Interior. The President is aided in his functions by a Council of State, which is composed of the four ministers and representatives of the judiciary, the Church, the army, etc. The judiciary is exercised by a superior court in the capital, courts of appeal at Con-cep9ion, Santiago, and La Serena, a tribunal of accounts, and in the provincial capitals, primary courts of civil and criminal jurisdiction, etc. The provinces are governed by intendentes, appointed by the President, and the departments, sub-delegations, and districts, by governors, sub-delegates, and inspectors respectively.
Army and Navy.—The military force of the Republic consists of—artillery 303, infantry 1,593, cavalry 665, military school 38, and invalids 409—2,993 men of all arms. The national guard or militia numbers 54,682 men, viz., 1,080 artillery, 29,757 infantry, and 23,845 cavalry. The national navy consists of two screw and two side-wheel steamers, average 200 horse-power, and carrying in all 28 guns ; and three sail-vessels, carrying in all 42 guns. There is also a frigate used as a naval school. There were under construction, in 1859, three steamers.
Revenue, Debt, etc.—The public debt of Chili consists of two series—a foreign and a domestic debt. The former originated in a loan of £1,000,000 sterling, made in 1822, which was to have been redeemed by installments in thirty years. On account of the disturbed state of the country, however, neither principal nor interest were disbursed for many years, and the debt had almost doubled, when in 1842 the whole was consolidated on the terms that the original debt should pay 6 per cent, and the interest 3 per cent, per annum. Since this arrangement, no default has been made, and in 1859 the debt had been reduced t<* £1,152,800. The domestic debt in the same year amounted to $2,225,575, which bears 3 per cent, interest. The revenue, in 1860, amounted to $8,795,243, of which about one half accrued from cus* toms, and was expended—for general state purposes, $1,295,304; fov the judiciary, worship, and schools, $1,093,829; for the army and navy, $1,913,289 ; and for debt, etc., $2,402,821.
Religion.—The Roman Catholic is the state religion, and the public exercise of any other is forbidden. The Church is under the direction of the Archbishop of Santiago and the bishops of Concep9ion, Coquimbo, and San Carlos de Chiloe.
Education.—Of the total population in 1855, only 193,853 (123,437* males and 70,416 females) or 13.5 per cent, could read, and only 153,294 (100,011 males and 53,283 females) or 10.7 per cent, could write. This, however, is a great improvement since 1832, when the first national schools were established, before which education had very limited facilities, and those only open to the wealthy. The condition of the schools, in the census year, is shown in the following table;

or a total in all the institutions, in 1855, of 35,308, or 2.4 per cent, of the total population. During 1854 the state distributed to the school libraries about 98,000 volumes. In 1832 there were in the Bepublio only two national schools: in 1842, 28; in 1852, 157. The increase, since this last-named year, has been remarkably rapid.
Principal Cities, Towns, etc.—Santiago, the capital, founded 12 Feb., 1541, is located in a delightful valley, 2,000 feet above the sea (lat. 33° 35" S., and long. 70° 44' W.). It has many handsome buildings, most of them only one story high, as a precaution against earthquakes. Among these are a university, a national institute, a school of arts and trades, a school of agriculture, a museum, a normal school for teachers, many academies, a large public library, two theatres, two hospitals, a penitentiary, several charitable establishments, and a great many churches and convents. Congress meets here on the 1st June annually. Population 80,000. Valparaiso is the chief port, and has an active commerce. The theatre is perhaps the largest and finest in America, and this is the only place in Chili at which Protestants have a chapel. Population 20,000. North from Santiago are San Felipe de Aconcagua, with a lyceum, etc.; La Serena, a considerable town; Coquimbo, a noted port; Copiapo, the centre of a vast mining industry, and connected with the port of the same name by railroad, etc. To the south of Santiago are San Fernando, the capital of Colchagua; Talca, near which is the Descabezado, one of the highest mountains of Chili; Cauquenes, and its port Constitution ; Concepcion, and its port Talcahuano ; Valdivia, around which many Germans have settlements; Sanr Carlos, the capital of Chiloe, and a tine port, etc. There are also several flourishing cities in the interior.
History.—Of the original inhabitants of Chili, history has left no records. In 1532, Pizarro, the conqueror of Peru, sent his colleague, Almagro, into the country, but lie was driven back by the Indians. A second invasion was undertaken in 1540, which proved more successful, although it cost more sacrifice of life and treasure than the conquest of all the rest of America; nor have the Araucanians, the bravest of the aboriginal tribes, succumbed to this day. The Spanish colony was governed by a captain-general, president of the kingdom of Chili, a royal court of justice as his advisers, several tribunals, intendentes, and chiefs, until Napoleon’s army entered Spain. The Chilians embraced this opportunity to throw off their allegiance to the Spanish crown, and on the 18th September, 1810, established a junta guber-nativa, and the first national Congress was inaugurated in Santiago on the 14th July, 1811. Soon the Spaniards commenced a sanguinary war against the patriots, and after many vicissitudes the Chilian army obtained a complete triumph in Chacabuco, on the 12th Feb., 1817. On the same day of the following year the independence of the Republic of Cliili was sworn to and promulgated to the world. The glorious victory of Maipu, on the 5th April of that year, sealed that declaration, and the Spaniards lost the last bulwark they had by the surrender of Chiloe in January, 1826. Civil war, the most fearful of calamities, succeeded to the sacred war for liberty; one constitution was tried after another, and the infancy of the Republic was thus prolonged. But at last the people became tired of so many misfortunes, and a constitution was promulgated on the 25th May, 1833, which has been for Chili a sheet-anchor of salvation.

V ARAD EROS DEL RIO PUTUMAYO
De la boca del rio Cotrihe en el Putumayo, a la boca del rio Yaguas, hay dos dias canoa, surcando mas 6 menos diez millas diarias. El rio Yaguas es navegable 25 dias noa. En lancha a vapor se sui’ca 6 dias en creciente y 3 en vaciante.
i	------
El rio Cotuhe es navegable en lancha, tres dias en creciente y dos en vaciante; contan-dose 12 horas de navegacion. •
De la boca del rio Cotuhe a Buenos Aires, hay cuatro dias en canoa, surcando de Buenos Aires hasta el Hamacayacu para tomar canoa, se emplea 25 horas a pie en el varadero. Del rio Hamacayacu, terminando el varadero, al rio Amazonas, se emplea un dia en
De la boca del rio Cotuhe a la Quebrada de Bella Flor, que esta en la orilla izquierda del Putumayo, se emplea 15 horas de navegacion en lancha surcando; esta quebrada en tres dias en canoa para liegar a un varadero en el que se emplea 30 horas pie y bajando un dia en canoa, un afluente, se llega al rio Caqueta.
en
en ca-
E1 rio Putumayo tiene una extensibn navegable de 1,235 kilbmetros; de estos, 460 son navegables, desde el rio Cotuhb hasta la desembocadura del rio Igaraparana, afluente izquier-do, por embarcaciones de lra25 a 2m44 de calado; los 775 kilbmetros restantes son navegables por embarcaciones de 0m60 a lm22 de calado, desde la desembocadura del Igaraparana hasta la desembocadura del rio Guames, afluente derecho del Putumayo.
canoa.
El rio Igaraparana afluente izquierdo del Putumayo, es navegable 330 kilometres, por embarcaciones de 0m60 a lm22 de calado (2 4 4 pies)

The United States Army and Navy
Regular army: officers, 4,470; enlisted men, 81,331.
Philippine scouts: officers, 180; enlisted men, 5,480.
Militia: officers, 9,142; enlisted men, 112,710.
Regular navy: officers, 3,114; enlisted men, 46,651.
Marine corps: officers, 319; enlisted men, 9,567.
Naval militia: officers, 615; enlisted men, 7,185.
In the regular army the infantry consists of thirty regiments of three battalions each, and each battalion falls into four companies. The cavalry has fifteen regiments of three squadrons. The field artillery comprises six regiments, each of six batteries; of these two regiments are light artillery, two mountain artillery, one field artillery, and one horse artillery. To each battery are allotted four guns firing a 15-pound shell, and eight wagons.
' The militia is a body of voluntary troops which the President can call out for service within the country or outside of it.

The Pacific Fleet
#
varies considerably in size, as vessels are frequently interchanged between it and the Asiatic Fleet. Recently the Pacific Fleet has included the battleship “Oregon,” two divisions of armored cruisers, nine other cruisers, twelve destro}rers and torpedo boats, and two submarines.
The Mexican Army and Navy
has at present largely a paper strength, as a considerable part of the regular army in the north has gone over to the Constitutional camp. The official figures on the organization of the army are:
Peace strength: 107 generals, 6,236 officers, 49,332 men.
War strength: estimated at from 50,000-84,000 of all ranks.
The army consists of 30 battalions of infantry, 18 regiments of cavalry,
1 regiment of horse artillery, 2 regiments of field artillery, and 1 of mountain guns, etc.
Each artillery regiment consists in time of peace of four batteries, in time of war raised to six.
Mauser rifles (1901 model) are used by the regular infantry and cavalry, h\ t the reserves use the old Remington 1893 model. The artillery is fairly well supplied wi h Schnek er-Canet quick-firing guns. Recently, the Mexican government has made heavy purchases of guns, chiefly rifles, in Japan. Most of the ammunition used is made in Mexican arsenals.
The navy is almost a negligible feature. There were until July five gunboats, but one of these was destroyed recently by the Constitutionalists in the harbor of Guaymas.

The Mexican Situation
Since 1910 Mexico has been in a state of continuous turmoil. Previously, President Diaz had ruled the country with an iron hand for a generation, and although despotic and arbitrary had preserved a fair degree of order and done much to develop the country's resources. Gradually the people tired of the dictatorial rule of Diaz, and when in 1910 a leader of the opposition arose in the person of Francisco Madero, the whole country soon became aflame with revolution. In May, 1911, President Diaz was forced to abdicate and in October Madero was chosen his successor. As Diaz was too despotic, so Madero was too indulgent. Soon malcontents were inciting revolutions in various parts of the country. The fall of the Madero regime was however achieved finally by the men who had been his own supporters, and a few days later the ex-president was assassinated under exceedingly sinister circumstances. The Huerta regime has been able to establish efficient control only in the central part of Mexico, all remote corners of the country being in open rebellion. In the north the provisional government has failed utterly to maintain any control, and the Constitutionalists have set up an independent administration and are maintaining it with a considerable degree of success. American and European lives have been lost in considerable number, foreign property has been destroyed, and life and capital in general are so jeopardized that both in Europe and America the conviction has grown that the present lawless condition must end. Under the Monroe Doctrine it becomes our duty to establish peace and safety in Mexico. The question of the day is: Can this be done by diplomatic mediation, or will military intervention be necessary?

Mexican Events in 1913-14
A pitched battle takes place in the streets of Mexico City between Federal troops and the followers of Felix Diaz. General Bernardo Reyes is slain.
President Taft in note to President Madero reaffirms the policy of non-intervention.
President Madero is taken prisoner by Federal General Huerta; the latter is proclaimed Provisional President.
Gustavo Madero, brother of the president and former Minister of Finance, is executed by troops of the new government.
Ambassador Plenry Lane Wilson sends his “sincere congratulations" to Huerta. Huerta assures United States Government that Madero will not be executed summarily.
United States War Department orders 4,000 soldiers to Mexican border.
President Madero and Vice-President Suarez are assassinated while being transferred to the penitentiary. Revolt is started in eleven states against the Huerta regime.
United States announces its policy not changed by murder.
Huerta asks for the passage of a bill to pardon all political offenders.
Mexican troops kill 60 prisoners under fugitive law.
Huerta denies murder of Madero and Suarez.
Ex-President Porflrio Diaz indorses Huerta regime.
The Mexican government protests to United States against the shipment of arms across the border.
Federal garrison at Naeo under General Ojeda flees into Arizona and surrenders to American soldiers.
Huerta declares Ambassador Wilson without diplomatic standing because United States fails bo recognize Mexican government.
Federal officers executed by order of the Constitutionalist commanders.
Huerta is charged in Mexican Parliament with conspiracy, usurpation, and assassination.	\
Federal troops are defeated in Coahuila. Everything between Saltillo and Mon-clava falls into hands of Constitutionalists.
Federal troop train is dynamited and 200 killed.
Federal troops defeat Constitutionalists in two-day battle at Ortiz.
Ambassador Wilson leaves for Washington to explain Mexican situation.
Durango falls into hands of Constitutionalists.
Ambassador Wilson resigns Mexican post.
John Lind is dispatched to Mexico on battleship “New Hampshire" to present President Wilson's plans for mediation and the holding of a popular election for president.
Huerta announces that Lind will be persona non grata unless he comes prepared to recognize existing government.
General Felix Diaz on way to Japan with special mission from Mexican government.
Japan refuses to recognizfvljiaz. Constitutionalists raise siege of Torreon after loss of 3,200 men.
Huerta rejects President Wilson’s “peace plan," and Special Envoy Lind returns to Vera Cruz from Mexico City.
In a message to the Mexican Congress, Huerta promises an unrestricted popular election for the presidency.
Diaz is recalled to Mexico for active army service, after his candidacy for the presidency is announced.
The Constitutionalists capture the city of Piedras Negras.
Huerta seizes and imprisons 110 deputies of the Mexican Parliament who had signed a resolution of warning against him because of the disappearance of a senator.
Huerta suspends Constitutional guarantees and proclaims himself dictator. Sir Lionel Carden, British Minister to Mexico, presents his credentials to Huerta.
Elections take place in Mexico which are evidently farcical.
President Wilson sends ultimatum to Huerta, demanding that he retire. Huerta ignores it.
Premier Asquith announces policy of non-intervention by Great Britain. Constitutionalists capture Culiacan, capital of the state of Sinaloa.
Victoria, capital of Tamaulipas, captured and occupied by the Constitutionalists. ** Pancho Villa wins the battle of Juarez.
Chihuahua is evacuated by the Federals and Villa begins his victorious advance toward Mexico City.
The election results of October 27 are annulled and new elections set for July. Meanwhile Huerta is to retain provisional presidency.
Ojinaga occupied by Villa after a six-day battle. The Constitutionalists are now in control of the northern tier of Mexican states.
President Wilson lifts the embargo on arms, applied to Mexico by President Taft.
William S. Benton, British subject, is killed in Juarez by Fierro, one of Villa's lieutenants. Villa is cleared of blame.
Clemente Vergera, a Texas Ranger, is lured across the border by the Federals and killed. Texans recover his body.
Torreon is evacuated by the Federals after repeated defeat in several hard fought battles.
The Constitutionalists move against Tampico and begin the attack.
A party of American marines from the United States Gunboat “Dolphin" lands on neutral ground in Tampico, and is arrested by a Mexican Federal officer.
Admiral Mayo demands an apology.
Huerta refuses to give the salute demanded by the United States Government. ^
A war fleet of twenty-one battleships receives orders to sail for Mexico and to block the Mexican ports if Huerta does not comply with the demand for a salute.
Huerta again definitely refuses to yield to the demand for an unconditional salute, claiming there had been no insult to the United States flag.
Vera Cruz is blockaded by the American war fleet. Congress holds a special session, authorizing the president to declare war.

The Mexican Army and Navy
has at present largely a paper strength, as a considerable part of the regular army in the north has gone over to the Constitutional camp. The official figures on the organization of the army are:
Peace strength: 107 generals, 6,236 officers, 49,332 men.
War strength: estimated at from 50,000-84,000 of all ranks.
The army consists of 30 battalions of infantry, 18 regiments of cavalry, 1 regiment of horse artillery, 2 regiments of field artillery, and 1 of mountain guns, etc. Each artillery regiment consists in time of peace of four batteries, in time of war raised to six.
The national guard is practically without training or organization and would be very difficult to mobolize.
Mauser rifles (1901 model) are used by the regular infantry and cavalry, but the reserves use the old Remington 1893 model. The artillery is fairly well supplied with Schneider-Canet quick-firing guns. Recently, the Mexican government has made heavy purchases of guns, chiefly rifles, in Japan. Most of the ammunition used is made in Mexican arsenals.
The navy is almost a negligible feature. There were until July, 1912, five gunboats, but one of these was destroyed recently by the Constitutionalists in the harbor of Guaymas.
Personnel of the United States Army and Navy
Regular army: officers, 4,470; enlisted men, 81,331.
Philippine scouts: officers, 180; enlisted men, 5,480.
Militia: officers, 9,142; enlisted men, 112,710.
Regular navy: officers, 3,114; enlisted men, 46,651.
Marine corps: officers, 319; enlisted men, 9,567.
Naval militia: officers, 615; enlisted men, 7,185.
In the regular army the infantry consists of thirty regiments of three battalions each, and each battalion falls into four companies. The cavalry has fifteen regiments of three squadrons. The field artillery comprises six regiments, each of six batteries; of these two regiments are light artillery, two mountain artillery, one field artillery, and one horse artillery. To each battery are allotted four guns firing a 15-pound shell, and eight wagons.
The militia is a body of voluntary troops which the President can call out for service within the country or outside of it.

The Mexican Army and Navy
has at present largely a paper strength, as a considerable part of the regular army in the north has gone over to the Constitutional camp. The official figures on the organization of the army are:
Peace strength: 107 generals, 6,236 officers, 49,332 men.
War strength: estimated at from 50,000-84,000 of all ranks.
The army consists of 30 battalions of infantry, 18 regiments of cavalry,
1 regiment of horse artillery, 2 regiments of field artillery, and 1 of mountain guns, etc.
Each artillery regiment consists in time of peace of four batteries, in time of war raised to six.
Mauser rifles (1901 model) are used by the regular infantry and cavalry, h\ t the reserves use the old Remington 1893 model. The artillery is fairly well supplied wi h Schnek er-Canet quick-firing guns. Recently, the Mexican government has made heavy purchases of guns, chiefly rifles, in Japan. Most of the ammunition used is made in Mexican arsenals.
The navy is almost a negligible feature. There were until July five gunboats, but one of these was destroyed recently by the Constitutionalists in the harbor of Guaymas.

The Mexican Situation
Since 1910 Mexico has been in a state of continuous turmoil. Previously, President Diaz had ruled the country with an iron hand for a generation, and although despotic and arbitrary had preserved a fair degree of order and done much to develop the country's resources. Gradually the people tired of the dictatorial rule of Diaz, and when in 1910 a leader of the opposition arose in the person of Francisco Madero, the whole country soon became aflame with revolution. In May, 1911, President Diaz was forced to abdicate and in October Madero was chosen his successor. As Diaz was too despotic, so Madero was too indulgent. Soon malcontents were inciting revolutions in various parts of the country. The fall of the Madero regime was however achieved finally by the men who had been his own supporters, and a few days later the ex-president was assassinated under exceedingly sinister circumstances. The Huerta regime has been able to establish efficient control only in the central part of Mexico, all remote corners of the country being in open rebellion. In the north the provisional government has failed utterly to maintain any control, and the Constitutionalists have set up an independent administration and are maintaining it with a considerable degree of success. American and European lives have been lost in considerable number, foreign property has been destroyed, and life and capital in general are so jeopardized that both in Europe and America the conviction has grown that the present lawless condition must end. Under the Monroe Doctrine it becomes our duty to establish peace and safety in Mexico. The question of the day is: Can this be done by diplomatic mediation, or will military intervention be necessary?

Mexican Events in 1913-14
A pitched battle takes place in the streets of Mexico City between Federal troops and the followers of Felix Diaz. General Bernardo Reyes is slain.
President Taft in note to President Madero reaffirms the policy of non-intervention.
President Madero is taken prisoner by Federal General Huerta; the latter is proclaimed Provisional President.
Gustavo Madero, brother of the president and former Minister of Finance, is executed by troops of the new government.
Ambassador Plenry Lane Wilson sends his “sincere congratulations" to Huerta. Huerta assures United States Government that Madero will not be executed summarily.
United States War Department orders 4,000 soldiers to Mexican border.
President Madero and Vice-President Suarez are assassinated while being transferred to the penitentiary. Revolt is started in eleven states against the Huerta regime.
United States announces its policy not changed by murder.
Huerta asks for the passage of a bill to pardon all political offenders.
Mexican troops kill 60 prisoners under fugitive law.
Huerta denies murder of Madero and Suarez.
Ex-President Porflrio Diaz indorses Huerta regime.
The Mexican government protests to United States against the shipment of arms across the border.
Federal garrison at Naeo under General Ojeda flees into Arizona and surrenders to American soldiers.
Huerta declares Ambassador Wilson without diplomatic standing because United States fails bo recognize Mexican government.
Federal officers executed by order of the Constitutionalist commanders.
Huerta is charged in Mexican Parliament with conspiracy, usurpation, and assassination.	\
Federal troops are defeated in Coahuila. Everything between Saltillo and Mon-clava falls into hands of Constitutionalists.
Federal troop train is dynamited and 200 killed.
Federal troops defeat Constitutionalists in two-day battle at Ortiz.
Ambassador Wilson leaves for Washington to explain Mexican situation.
Durango falls into hands of Constitutionalists.
Ambassador Wilson resigns Mexican post.
John Lind is dispatched to Mexico on battleship “New Hampshire" to present President Wilson's plans for mediation and the holding of a popular election for president.
Huerta announces that Lind will be persona non grata unless he comes prepared to recognize existing government.
General Felix Diaz on way to Japan with special mission from Mexican government.
Japan refuses to recognizfvljiaz. Constitutionalists raise siege of Torreon after loss of 3,200 men.
Huerta rejects President Wilson’s “peace plan," and Special Envoy Lind returns to Vera Cruz from Mexico City.
In a message to the Mexican Congress, Huerta promises an unrestricted popular election for the presidency.
Diaz is recalled to Mexico for active army service, after his candidacy for the presidency is announced.
The Constitutionalists capture the city of Piedras Negras.
Huerta seizes and imprisons 110 deputies of the Mexican Parliament who had signed a resolution of warning against him because of the disappearance of a senator.
Huerta suspends Constitutional guarantees and proclaims himself dictator. Sir Lionel Carden, British Minister to Mexico, presents his credentials to Huerta.
Elections take place in Mexico which are evidently farcical.
President Wilson sends ultimatum to Huerta, demanding that he retire. Huerta ignores it.
Premier Asquith announces policy of non-intervention by Great Britain. Constitutionalists capture Culiacan, capital of the state of Sinaloa.
Victoria, capital of Tamaulipas, captured and occupied by the Constitutionalists. ** Pancho Villa wins the battle of Juarez.
Chihuahua is evacuated by the Federals and Villa begins his victorious advance toward Mexico City.
The election results of October 27 are annulled and new elections set for July. Meanwhile Huerta is to retain provisional presidency.
Ojinaga occupied by Villa after a six-day battle. The Constitutionalists are now in control of the northern tier of Mexican states.
President Wilson lifts the embargo on arms, applied to Mexico by President Taft.
William S. Benton, British subject, is killed in Juarez by Fierro, one of Villa's lieutenants. Villa is cleared of blame.
Clemente Vergera, a Texas Ranger, is lured across the border by the Federals and killed. Texans recover his body.
Torreon is evacuated by the Federals after repeated defeat in several hard fought battles.
The Constitutionalists move against Tampico and begin the attack.
A party of American marines from the United States Gunboat “Dolphin" lands on neutral ground in Tampico, and is arrested by a Mexican Federal officer.
Admiral Mayo demands an apology.
Huerta refuses to give the salute demanded by the United States Government. ^
A war fleet of twenty-one battleships receives orders to sail for Mexico and to block the Mexican ports if Huerta does not comply with the demand for a salute.
Huerta again definitely refuses to yield to the demand for an unconditional salute, claiming there had been no insult to the United States flag.
Vera Cruz is blockaded by the American war fleet. Congress holds a special session, authorizing the president to declare war.

The Mexican Army and Navy
has at present largely a paper strength, as a considerable part of the regular army in the north has gone over to the Constitutional camp. The official figures on the organization of the army are:
Peace strength: 107 generals, 6,236 officers, 49,332 men.
War strength: estimated at from 50,000-84,000 of all ranks.
The army consists of 30 battalions of infantry, 18 regiments of cavalry, 1 regiment of horse artillery, 2 regiments of field artillery, and 1 of mountain guns, etc. Each artillery regiment consists in time of peace of four batteries, in time of war raised to six.
The national guard is practically without training or organization and would be very difficult to mobolize.
Mauser rifles (1901 model) are used by the regular infantry and cavalry, but the reserves use the old Remington 1893 model. The artillery is fairly well supplied with Schneider-Canet quick-firing guns. Recently, the Mexican government has made heavy purchases of guns, chiefly rifles, in Japan. Most of the ammunition used is made in Mexican arsenals.
The navy is almost a negligible feature. There were until July, 1912, five gunboats, but one of these was destroyed recently by the Constitutionalists in the harbor of Guaymas.

-r ** *v*‘V «/ .
THE TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS OF THE UNITED STATES
The United States Geological Survey is making a standard topographic atlas of the United States. This work has been in progress since 1882, and its results consist of published maps of more than 42 per cent of the country, exclusive of outlying possessions.
This topographic atlas is published in the form of maps on sheets measuring about 16f by 20 inches. Under the general plan adopted the country is divided into quadrangles bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude. These quadrangles are mapped on different scales, the scale selected for each map being that which is best adapted to general use in the development of the country, and consequently, though the standard maps are of nearly uniform size, they represent areas of different sizes. On the lower margin of each map are printed graphic scales showing distances in feet, meters, and miles. In addition, the scale of the map is shown by a fraction expressing a fixed ratio between linear measurements on the map and corresponding distances on the ground. For example, the scale means that 1 unit on the map (such as 1 inch, 1 foot, or 1 meter) represents 62,500 similar units on the earth’s surface.
Although some areas are surveyed and some maps are compiled and published on special scales for special purposes, the standard topographic surveys for the United States proper and the resulting maps have for many years been divided into three types, differentiated as follows:	-
1.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of great public importance—relating, for example, to'mineral development, irrigation, or reclamation of swamp areas—are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of (1 inch — one-half mile), with a contour interval of 1, 5, or 10 feet.
2.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of average public importance, such as most of the basin of the Mississippi and its tributaries, are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of ^ (1 inch —nearly 1 mile), with a contour interval of 10 to 25 feet.
3.	Surveys of areas in which the problems are of minor public importance, such as much of the mountain or desert region of Arizona or New Mexico, are made with sufficient accuracy to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of
(1 inch = nearly 2 miles), with a contour interval of 25 tb 100 feet.	.
A topographic survey of Alaska has been in progress since 1898, and nearly 43 per cent of its area has now been mapped. About 10 per cent of the Territory has been covered by reconnaissance maps on a scale of	or about 10 miles to an
inch. Most of the remaining area surveyed in Alaska has been mapped on a scale of but about 4,000 square miles has been mapped on a scale of or larger.
The Hawaiian Islands, with the exception of the small islands at the western end of the group, have been surveyed, and the resulting maps are published on a scale of
(works of man), such as towns, cities, roads, railroads, and boundaries. The symbols used to represent these features are shown and explained below. Variations appear on some earlier maps, and additional features are represented on some special
maps.
All the water features are represented in blue, the smaller streams and canals by single blue lines and the larger streams, the lakes, and the sea by blue water lining or blue tint. Intermittent streams—those whose beds are dry for a large part of the year—are shown by lines of blue dots and dashes.
Relief is shown by contour lines in brown, which on some maps are supplemented by shading showing the effect of light thrown from the northwest across the area represented, for the purpose of giving the appearance of relief and thus aiding in the interpretation of the contour lines. A contour line represents an imaginary line on the ground (a contour) every part of which is at the same altitude above sea level. Such a line could be drawn at any altitude, but in practice only the contours at certain regular intervals of altitude are shown. The line of the seacoast itself is a contour, the datum or zero of altitude being mean sea level. The 20-foot contour would be the shore line if the sea should rise 20 feet. Contour lines show the shape of the bills, mountains, and valleys, as well as their altitude. Successive contour lines, that, are far apart on the map indicate a gentle slope; lines that are close together indicate a steep slope; and lines that run together indicate a cliff.
The manner in which contour lines express altitude, form, and grade is shown in the figure below.
82.500 '
The features shown on these maps may be arranged in three groups—(1) water, including seas, lakes, rivers, canals, swamps, and other bodies of water; (2) relief, including mountains, hills, valleys, and other features of the land surface; (3) culture
The sketch represents a river valley that lies between two hills. In the foreground is the sea, with a bay that is partly inclosed by a hooked sand bar. On each side of the valley is a terrace into which small streams have cut narrow gullies. The hill on the right has a rounded summit and gently slop-
ing spurs separated by ravines. The spurs are truncated at their lower ends by a, sea cliff. The hill at the left terminates abruptly at the valley in a steep scarp, from which it slopes gradually away and forms an inclined table-land that is traversed by a few shallow gullies. On the map each of these features is represented, directly beneath its position in the sketch, by contour lines.
The contour interval, or the vertical distance in feet between one contour and the next, is stated at the bottom of each map. This interval differs according to the topography of the area mapped: in a flat country it may be as small as 1 foot; in a mountainous region it may be as great as 250 feet. Certain contour lines, every fourth or fifth one, are made heavier than the others and are accompanied by figures showing altitude. The heights of many points—such as road corners, summits, surfaces of lakes, and bench marks—are also given on the map in figures, which show altitudes to the nearest foot only. More exact altitudes—those of bench marks—as well as the geodetic coordinates of triangulation stations, are published in bulletins issued by the Geological Survey.
Lettering and the works of man are shown in black. Boundaries, such as those of a State, county, city, land grant, township/or reservation, are shown by continuous or broken lines of different kinds and weights. Good motor or public roads are shown by fine double hues, poor motor or private roads by dashed double lines, trails by dashed single lines.
Each quadrangle is designated by the name of a city, town, or prominent natural feature within it, and on the margins of the map are printed the names of adjoining quadrangles of which maps have been published. Over 3,300 quadrangles in the United States have been surveyed, and maps of them similar to the one on the other side of this sheet have been
published.	•
The topographic map is the base on which the geology and mineral resources of a quadrangle are represented, and the maps showing these features are bound together with a descriptive text to form a folio of the Geologic Atlas of the United States. More than 220 folios have been published.
Index maps of each State and of Alaska and Hawaii showing the areas covered by topographic maps and geologic folios published by the United States Geological Survey may be obtained free. Copies of the standard topographic maps may be obtained for 10 cents each; some special maps are sold at different prices. A discount of 40 per cent is allowed on an order for maps amounting to $5 or more at the retail price. The geologic folios are sold for 25 cents or more each, the price depending on the size of the folio. A circular describing the folios will be sent on request.
Applications for maps or folios should be accompanied by cash, draft, or money order (not postage stamps) and should be addressed to
TPIE DIRECTOR,
United States Geological Survey,
Washington, D. C.
September, 1928.
