U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY CHART E S D. WALC OTT . DIRECTOR
3I"43
ARIZONA
(COCHISE COUNTY)
TOMBSTONE SPECIAL MAP
’02'
31°43' 30" DESCRIPTION OF THE TOPOGRAPHIC MAP OF THE UNITED STATES
o=
The United States Geological Survey is making a topographic map of the United States. This work has been in progress since 1882, and about three-tenths of the area of the country, excluding outlying possessions, has been mapped. The mapped areas are widely scattered, nearly every State being represented, as shown on the progress map accompanying each annual report of the Director. ' ‘^This great map is being published in atlas sheets of convenient size, which are bounded by parallels and meridians. The four-cornered division of land corresponding to an atlas sheet is called a quadrangle. The sheets are of approximately the same size: the paper dimensions are 20 by 16& inches; the map occupies about 17i inches of height and Hi to 16 inches of width, the latter varying with latitude. Three scales, however, are employed. The largest scale is 1:62500, or very nearly one mile to one inch; i. e., one linear mile on the ground is represented by one linear inch on the map. This scale is used for the thickly settled or industrially important parts of the country. For the greater part of the country an intermediate scale of 1:125000, or about two miles to one inch, is employed. A third and still smaller scale of 1:150000, or about four miles to one inch, has been used in the desert regions of the far West. Alfew special maps on larger scales are made of limited areas in mining districts. The sheets on the largest scale cover 15' of latitude by 15' of longitude; those on the intermediate scale, 30' of latitude by 30' of longitude;, and those on the smallest scale, 1° of latitude by 1° of longitude.
• 'The features shown on this map may, for convenience, be classed in three groups: (1) water, including seas, lakes, ponds, rivers and other fleams, canals, swamps, etc.; (2) relief, including mountains, hills, valleys, cliffs, etc.; (3) culture, i. e., wmrks of man, such as towns, cities, roads, railroads, boundaries, etc. The conventional signs used for these features are grouped below. Variations appear in some maps of earlier dates.
All water features are shown in blue, the smaller streams and canals in full blue lines, and the larger streams, lakes, and the sea by blue water-lining. Certain streams, however, which flow during only a part of the year, their beds being dry at other
times, are shown, not Dy lull lines, hut by lines o dots and dashes. Ponds which are dry during a part of the year are shown by oblique parallel lines. Salt-water marshes are shown by horizontal ruling interspersed with tufts of blue, and freshwater marshes and swamps by blue tufts with broken horizontal lines.
Relief is shown by contour lines in brown. Each contour passes through points which have the same altitude. One who follows a contour on the ground will go neither uphill nor downhill, but on a level. By the use of contours not only are the shapes of the plains, hills, and mountains shown, but also the elevations. The line of the seacoast itself is a contour line, the datum or zero of elevation being mean sea level. The contour line at, say, 20 feet above sea level is the line that would be the seacoast if the sea were to rise or the land to sink 20 feet. Such a line runs back up the valleys and forward around the points of hills and spurs. On a gentle slope this contour line is far from the present coast line, while on a steep slope it is near it. Thus a succession of these contour lines far apart on the map indicates a gentle slope; if close together, a steep slope; and if the contours run together in one line, as if each were vertically under the one above it, they indicate a cliff. In many parts of the country are depressions or hollows with no outlets. The contours of course surround these, just as they surround hills. Those small hollows known as sinks are usually indicated by hachures, or short dashes, on the inside of the curve. The contour interval, or the vertical distance in feet between one contour and the next, is stated at the bottom of each map. This interval varies according to the character of the area mapped; in a flat country it may be as small as 10 feet; in a mountainous region it may be 200- feet. Certain contours, usually every fifth one, are accompanied by figures stating elevation above sea level. The heights of many definite points, such as road corners, railroad crossings, railroad stations, summits, water surfaces, triangulation stations, and bench marks, are also given. The figures in each case are placed close to the point to which they apply, and express the elevation to the nearest foot only. The exact elevations of bench marks and
well as the descriptionsland
geodetic coordinates of triangulation stations, are published in the annual reports and bulletins of the Survey. The publications pertaining to specified localities may be had on application.
The works of man are shown in black, in which color all lettering also is printed. Boundaries, such as State, county, city, land-grant, reservation, etc., are shown by broken lines of different kinds and weights. Cities are indicated by black blcfcks, representing the built-up portions, and country houses by small black squares. Roads are shown by fine double lines (full for the better-roads, dotted for the inferior ones), trails by single dotted lines, and railroads by full black lines with cross lines. Other cultural features are represented by conventions which are easily understood.
The sheets composing the topographic atlas are designated by the name of a principal town or of some prominent natural feature within the district, and the names of adjoining published sheets are printed on the margins. The sheets are sold at five cents each when fewer than 100 copies are purchased, but when they are ordered in lots of] 100 or more copies, whether of the same sheet or of different sheets, the price is three cents each.
The topographic map is the base on which the facts of geology and the mineral resources of a quadrangle are represented. The topographic: and geologic maps of a quadrangle are finally bound together, accompanied by a description of the district, to form a folio of the Geologic Atlas of the United States. The folios are sold at twenty-five cents each, except such as are unusually comprehensive, which are priced accordingly.
Applications for the separate topographic maps or for folios of the Geologic Atlas should be accompanied by the cash or by post-office money order (not postage stamps), and should be addressed to—
THE DIRECTOR,
, United States Geological SurveyM
Washington, D. C.
July, 1905.

INTRODUCTION
Consult legend at bottom of large map for location and types of roads. Some routes are shown which are passable only at certain seasons; others are traversed only with great difficulty at any time. Information on the condition of roads may be secured from the Utah State Automobile Association, the Utah State Highway Commission, Chambers of Commerce or local residents. During 1929 and 1930, many additions were made to Utah highways and roads and several of them put in better condition. The 1931 program comprehends more improvements than ever undertaken in any previous year.
On the left margin of the large map is a list of subjects which cover a number of historical points of interest. Seventy-four points of historical interest in Salt Lake City are indicated.
The modern traveler usually follows the main highways and in many cases these modern highways do not follow the old historic routes. An attempt has been made here to correlate modern highways with old routes so far as possible. Through the courtesy of the local A.A.A., the Utah Historical Landmarks Association has been permitted to reproduce their 1928 highway map. As stated above, later changes have been made in these highways hut this map will suffice for all ordinary purposes.
The average resident or traveler is interested in history but in many cases cannot give the necessary time to collect such information. In Utah the traveler will find many old pioneers and descendants of pioneers who are interested in the early history of the State, and who will be glad to cite the traveler to local points of interest and to relate early experiences.
Suggestions and corrections will be most heartily welcomed by the Utah Historical Landmarks Association. No claim is made to exactness nor exhaustive detail. This folder is merely an attempt to give the residents in Utah and travelers a brief synopsis of the high lights in the early history of Utah and to encourage others to pursue such studies.
TRAILS
Like other states, Utah had many early trails used by prehistoric dwellers, Indians and trappers. Animals also made trails which were frequently followed by men in pursuit of game or on account of easy locomotion. Trails, as the term is used here, means travel on foot or horseback with or without pack animals. Trails were characterized by “single file travel.” Trails usually followed water courses for several reasons. Grades were better, game was more plentiful, feed for animals was more abundant, water was procurable, wood could be obtained for fuel and forage for animals.
ROADS
Many of these trails became early routes, and these routes later became auto roads. Automobile roads of today, as well as air lines, follow water courses where arable soils, timber, water for power, culinary use, manufacturing, mining, smelting and railroading may be found.
CLIFF DWELLINGS AND PETROGLYPHS
Cliff Dwellers inhabited many parts of Utah. There are well preserved ruins near Blanding which are \ accessible to travelers. Cliff dwellings, petroglyphs and mounds have been located in various sections from Brigham City on the north to the southern part of the State. Discoveries are being made each
year and Utah affords a splendid opportunity for students of archaeology to carry on research work. In some sections archaeologists have removed pottery and other articles intimately associated with the lives of these early people, placing the exhibits in museums far removed from the place of origin. As a matter of research, such work can be highly commended but it would be more fortunate if these relics were preserved and displayed at the site of excavation where the association could be understood. Tourists should visit the L. D. S. museum and the museum at the State Capitol, where there are exhibits of prehistoric pottery and many interesting pioneer relics. The Daughters of the Utah Pioneers have collected thousands of pioneer articles which are attractively displayed at the State Capitol, and attendants in charge there will extend every courtesy to visitors. The Utah State Historical Society, Room No. 131, State Capitol, publishes the “Utah Historical Quarterly,” devoted to early historical events of Utah. Residents and non-residents should encourage these two organizations in every way.
PRE-MORMON WHITE PERIOD
Silvestre Velez de Escalante, a Franciscan Friar, left Spain in 1768 and reached America the same year. He did some preliminary work, which prepared him for exploration later. Escalante and another Franciscan Friar, Francisco Atanasio Dominquez, set out from Santa Fe, New Mexico, on July 29, 1776. to discover a commercial route from the settlements along the lower part of the Mississippi to California, the objective point on the Pacific coast being Monterey. The general course was northwest; they crossed the Grand and the Green Rivers, the latter being named “Rio San Buenaventura.” Farther on they noted the Uintah River and the Duchesne and were the first white men of record to look on Utah Lake, which was reached through Spanish Fork Canyon. The Jordan River was called the Rio de Santa Ana; accounts were written of Salt Lake Valley. The Indians near Provo were promised that missionaries would be sent to them the following year to carry on religious work among them. Due to difficulties encountered after reaching Santa Fe, this promise could not be fulfilled. After many hardships, they abandoned the trip to California and returned to Santa Fe, reached after many difficulties. The outbound course south through Utah passed near the present town of Milford. The Colorado River was crossed at a point now called “The Crossing of the Fathers” above Lee’s Ferry. Escalante and Dominquez reached Santa Fe January 2, 1777.
Etienne Provot was a French-Canadian, one of many early adventurers of French origin. Early in his trapping career, Provot carried on work for the Rocky Mountain Fur Company along the Yellowstone. In 1825 he visited the valley of Great Salt Lake. He explored the region from Salt Lake County to Sevier County; the city of Provo is named for this early adventurer. St. Louis, on account of its advantages as a river port and because lead mines were nearby, was the outfitting point for Provot and many of the early fur traders. Provot, like many other trappers, spent his last days in St. Louis where he died in 1850.
Jedediah S. Smith is well known to historians and to Californians generally but until recently has not occupied a prominent place in the early history of Utah. Smith was the first man to traverse the Great Salt Desert. He was a picturesque character, a courageous man and a conscientious worker of religious turn who carried a bible with him on his trips and sometimes preached to the Indians. Smith sold out his inter-est to James Bridger and others SMI1H	;n 1830. The next year he start-
ed on a trading expedition to the West and was presumably killed by Indians or Mexicans while obtaining water from a spring in what is now Western Kansas. Smith deserves a place in history with Lewis and Clark, Fremont. Carson and other explorers.
From the national viewpoint. John Charles Fremont is the most noted of early Utah explorers. He was born at Savannah, Georgia, January 21, 1813. Dellenbaugh, in his “Fremont and ’49,” states that a few months after Fremont was born Andrew Jackson and Thomas H. Benton, (Fremont’s future father-in-law), fought a duel near an inn occupied by the infant Fremont and a ball from one of the pistols passed thru the room where the parents were sitting. This was a most fitting introduction to a vivid career which extended to June 13, 1890. On that day he died in New York City from an attack of ptomaine poisoning while trying to wind up involved affairs that he might “live in peace in California.” His mother was a beautiful and brilliant daughter of Virginia; his father a courageous and adventurous Frenchman. Fremont was something of a classical student, excelled in mathematics, abandoned law and chose exploration as a calling. Charlestown College expelled him for inattention and insubordination and later rendered homage by giving him both a bachelor’s and master’s degree. He married Jessie Benton on October 19, 1841. Fremont left written records of five trails which reached from the Mississippi River across the country to Portland on the north and San Diego on the south. He was well equipped mentally and physically for his work. As an officer during the Civil War, he advocated arming negroes which brought trouble with the administration. Later he suffered financial reverses. There was lack of recognition and the Government forgot what he had done. Literary ghouls have attempted, as in the case of Custer, to besmirch his reputation, but his record rests on his writings and the statements of his associates. He always led—never followed.
Baptiste Tabeau was a member of Fremont’s party who left the little town of Kansas, about June 1, 1843, to explore the West. The expedition reached southwestern Utah on May 8, 1844. While camped near the Beaver Dam Mountains, then called the Santa Clara Mountains, a-mule was lost and Tabeau left camp without obtaining Fremont’s permission to secure the animal. cue him from the Indians. On the morning of May 10, 1844, Fremont and Thomas Fitzpatrick located the place where Tabeau had been killed. His horse, gun and clothes had been taken away and his body apparently thrown into the river. This is the first record of the death of a white man in what is now the State of Utah.
Pierre Jean DeSmet, of the Society of Jesus, was a native of Belgium who removed to America at an early age and spent more than thirty years in exploration work in the West. DeSmet’s principal labors were in what is now Montana, Idaho, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming where he established missions. While he was a devout Jesuit and defended his faith at all times, he wrote intelligently and entertainingly on secular affairs and fortunately left many descriptions of places, people and events. His general attitude was conciliatory and the friendly attitude he evidenced towards the Indians, together with what he said in peace councils, made travel much safer for whites. Brigham Young consulted him in 1846 on conditions in the West and the possibilities of settling there. DeSmet and Brigham Young were born the same year—1801. DeSmet died in St. Louis in 1873.
William Ashley was a leading spirit in the early fur trade. He traversed what is now Utah in 1825. In 1826 he sold out his interest to Smith, Jackson and Sublette of St. Louis. He was twice elected to Congress from Missouri and died in 1838.
Miles Goodyear secured a grant of land from the Mexican Government in 1841. This grant of land comprised a few square miles now occupied by Ogden. Goodyear built a fort and started settlement which consisted of a few mountaineers, Indians and half-breeds. James Brown, prominent Mormon pioneer, visited Goodyear early in January, 1848, and purchased his claim for some $3,000. Goodyear moved on and the Mormons began the systematic cultivation of crops around Ogden the same year.
According to the late Henry Byram Beckstead of South Jordan, a Mexican, who had secured a land grant from his Government, lived near the present town of Riverton when the Mormons entered the valley in 1847. According to Mr. Beckstead, his interests were bought out by church officials and the Mexican left the region. The south line of this grant ran through Riverton, the east line was the Jordan River, the north line was the southern shore of Great Salt Lake and the west line was the Oquirrh range.
John Bidwell was a native of Ohio. After teaching school and roughing it for a time, Bidwell helped organize the Bartleson-Bidwell Party which took the first wagons across what is now northern Utah in 1841. Bidwell and his companions pushed on to California. He became associated with Sutter and on many occasions acted as his right-hand man. Bidwell possessed a spirit of investigation, enterprise and integrity, combined with rare judgment. He was one of the early gold miners; from what is now called “Bidwell’s Bar” it is reported he took out $100,000 in gold. He became a large landholder and founded the town of Chico. He became prominent in politics and was the first candidate for the presidency from California. He was a staunch prohibitionist and opposed to the use of liquor in any way, and even to the
BIDWELL
DONNER
cultivation of grapes from which wine could be made. The Bidwell Route is now being marked by the Utah Historical Landmarks Association.
The Donner Party passed through Utah in 1846. Members of this party read glowing accounts of the West written by Lansford W. Hastings, and decided to emigrate. Two of the leaders in the party were George Donner, an elder brother Jacob, and James F. Reed. These men. and others in the party, were highly respected residents of Sangamon County, Ill. Reed was a member of the Black Hawk Military Company with Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas. The party left Springfield, Ill., in April, and Independence, Missouri, in May, 1846. They lost one member of their party in Kansas but reached Fort Bridger without great difficulty. Here the party divided and part of them went by way of Fort Hall, making their way safely to California. The Donner division was induced to follow a route outlined by Hastings, who preceded them with another party a few days ahead. Hastings and his party entered the Echo Canyon near Castle Rock, passed down Echo Canyon, through Weber Canyon and south to Salt Lake City, then across the desert to Pilot Peak. When the Donners reached what is now Echo, they found a note from Hastings advising them not to go down Weber Canyon on account of its inaccessibility. Men were sent on ahead to confer with Hastings who was located west of Grantsville. Hastings returned to the Oquirrh mountains and indicated a route through which the Donner party could reach Salt Lake Valley. The Donner party then proceeded down the canyon to Henefer, passed up Main Canyon along what is now East Canyon Creek reservoir, turned to the right at Dutchman’s Creek at the Clayton Ranch, passed over Big Mountain through Mountain
H
<s
HASTINGS
Dell and over Little Mountain into Emigration Canyon. According to tradition, this point of emergence in Emigration Canyon is also the same place where Brigham Young’s wagon rested the last night before he entered Salt Lake Valley. The Donner party came into Salt Lake Valley, spent some time around City Creek and crossed the Jordan. They buried a member of their party, Luke Halloran, near what is now Garfield, the first Mason buried in Utah. They then proceeded west to Twenty Wells, now Grantsville, around the point of the mountain at Timpie, south to Big Springs, near losepa, across Skull Valley and over Hastings Pass and onto the desert. They were led to believe that the Great Salt Desert extended west about forty-five miles; the distance is nearly ninety. After terrible privations, loss of livestock and equipment, they finally reached Pilot Peak and proceeded on their way to the Humboldt. At Gravelly Ford, near what is now Beowawe, members of the party quarreled and one of them was killed. The party finally reached Donner Lake in the Sierras. An early winter set in and nearly half of them were frozen or starved to death. The Donner Route is followed

BRIDGER
quite closely by the Lincoln Highway from Fort Bridger to Salt Lake City and by the Lincoln-Vic-tory Highway to Wendover. The Donner Route and the Hastings Route through Weber Canyon, have been marked by the Utah Historical Landmarks Association from Fort Bridger to Wendover. The Donner Route was the first historic emigrant road to be marked through Utah. A splendid monument marks the spot where this party camped at Donner Lake.
James Bridger, of Scotch descent, was born in Richmond, Virginia, in 1804, and died near Kansas City in 1881. As a youth, Bridger learned the blacksmith trade which was of great use to him in later years in repairing guns and equipment. When he was eighteen years of age he enlisted with the Ashley party and made a trip to the mouth of the Yellowstone, traveling by way of the Missouri river. Early in life he became acquainted with the tactics, traditions, practices and leaders of different fur companies, rival trappers and hostile Indians. He was one of the party which discovered Bridger’s Pass through which the Union Pacific runs.
To Bridger belongs the credit of being the first white man to look on the waters of Great Salt Lake. This was in 1824. He established Ft. Bridger in 1843, rendered valuable aid to the U. S. Government and was known and highly respected by the great western military leaders of his day. He made many strong friends and bitter enemies and a few writers have attempted to belittle his reputation. J. Cecil Alter in his “James Bridger” has performed a service for this great frontiersman similar to that performed by Dellenbaugh for Fremont in his “Fremont and ’49.”
COLONIZATION
Brigham Young was born June 1, 1801, at Whit-ingham, Windham County, Vermont, and died in Salt Lake City, Utah, on August 29, 1877. His father served in the Revolutionary War and his grandfather served in the French and Indian wars. The Youngs were Methodists. When Brigham Young was three years old the family moved to Sherburne, Chenango County, New York. Brigham Young’s father was a farmer and he assisted his father on the farm; he also learned something of carpenter work and painting and was proficient as a glazier. He first saw the Book of Mormon in 1830, and in 1832 became converted to Mormonism and was baptized April 14, 1832. Heber C. Kimball joined the church about the same time; his early associations with Kimball lasted through life. Brigham Young visited Kirtland early in 1831 and met the Prophet Joseph Smith in Kirtland in May, 1832. _ He was a leader during the troublesome times of ’33 and ’34, and in 1835 was selected as one of the twelve apostles. In 1840 Brigham Young, with others, sailed on a mission to England. He was instrumental in making many converts and under his direction the first saints sailed for America. He was in New Hampshire when the Prophet Joseph Smith was assassinated at Nauvoo. He succeeded Joseph Smith as head of the Mormon Church, a position he oc^ cupied until his death. INTRODUCTION
Consult legend at bottom of large map for location and types of roads. Some routes are shown which are passable only at certain seasons; others are traversed only with great difficulty at any time. Information on the condition of roads may be secured from the Utah State Automobile Association, the Utah State Highway Commission, Chambers of Commerce or local residents. During 1929 and 1930, many additions were made to Utah highways and roads and several of them put in better condition. The 1931 program comprehends more improvements than ever undertaken in any previous year.
On the left margin of the large map is a list of subjects which cover a number of historical points of interest. Seventy-four points of historical interest in Salt Lake City are indicated.
The modern traveler usually follows the main highways and in many cases these modern highways do not follow the old historic routes. An attempt has been made here to correlate modern highways with old routes so far as possible. Through the courtesy of the local A.A.A., the Utah Historical Landmarks Association has been permitted to reproduce their 1928 highway map. As stated above, later changes have been made in these highways hut this map will suffice for all ordinary purposes.
The average resident or traveler is interested in history but in many cases cannot give the necessary time to collect such information. In Utah the traveler will find many old pioneers and descendants of pioneers who are interested in the early history of the State, and who will be glad to cite the traveler to local points of interest and to relate early experiences.
Suggestions and corrections will be most heartily welcomed by the Utah Historical Landmarks Association. No claim is made to exactness nor exhaustive detail. This folder is merely an attempt to give the residents in Utah and travelers a brief synopsis of the high lights in the early history of Utah and to encourage others to pursue such studies.
TRAILS
Like other states, Utah had many early trails used by prehistoric dwellers, Indians and trappers. Animals also made trails which were frequently followed by men in pursuit of game or on account of easy locomotion. Trails, as the term is used here, means travel on foot or horseback with or without pack animals. Trails were characterized by “single file travel.” Trails usually followed water courses for several reasons. Grades were better, game was more plentiful, feed for animals was more abundant, water was procurable, wood could be obtained for fuel and forage for animals.
ROADS
Many of these trails became early routes, and these routes later became auto roads. Automobile roads of today, as well as air lines, follow water courses where arable soils, timber, water for power, culinary use, manufacturing, mining, smelting and railroading may be found.
CLIFF DWELLINGS AND PETROGLYPHS
Cliff Dwellers inhabited many parts of Utah. There are well preserved ruins near Blanding which are \ accessible to travelers. Cliff dwellings, petroglyphs and mounds have been located in various sections from Brigham City on the north to the southern part of the State. Discoveries are being made each
year and Utah affords a splendid opportunity for students of archaeology to carry on research work. In some sections archaeologists have removed pottery and other articles intimately associated with the lives of these early people, placing the exhibits in museums far removed from the place of origin. As a matter of research, such work can be highly commended but it would be more fortunate if these relics were preserved and displayed at the site of excavation where the association could be understood. Tourists should visit the L. D. S. museum and the museum at the State Capitol, where there are exhibits of prehistoric pottery and many interesting pioneer relics. The Daughters of the Utah Pioneers have collected thousands of pioneer articles which are attractively displayed at the State Capitol, and attendants in charge there will extend every courtesy to visitors. The Utah State Historical Society, Room No. 131, State Capitol, publishes the “Utah Historical Quarterly,” devoted to early historical events of Utah. Residents and non-residents should encourage these two organizations in every way.
PRE-MORMON WHITE PERIOD
Silvestre Velez de Escalante, a Franciscan Friar, left Spain in 1768 and reached America the same year. He did some preliminary work, which prepared him for exploration later. Escalante and another Franciscan Friar, Francisco Atanasio Dominquez, set out from Santa Fe, New Mexico, on July 29, 1776. to discover a commercial route from the settlements along the lower part of the Mississippi to California, the objective point on the Pacific coast being Monterey. The general course was northwest; they crossed the Grand and the Green Rivers, the latter being named “Rio San Buenaventura.” Farther on they noted the Uintah River and the Duchesne and were the first white men of record to look on Utah Lake, which was reached through Spanish Fork Canyon. The Jordan River was called the Rio de Santa Ana; accounts were written of Salt Lake Valley. The Indians near Provo were promised that missionaries would be sent to them the following year to carry on religious work among them. Due to difficulties encountered after reaching Santa Fe, this promise could not be fulfilled. After many hardships, they abandoned the trip to California and returned to Santa Fe, reached after many difficulties. The outbound course south through Utah passed near the present town of Milford. The Colorado River was crossed at a point now called “The Crossing of the Fathers” above Lee’s Ferry. Escalante and Dominquez reached Santa Fe January 2, 1777.
Etienne Provot was a French-Canadian, one of many early adventurers of French origin. Early in his trapping career, Provot carried on work for the Rocky Mountain Fur Company along the Yellowstone. In 1825 he visited the valley of Great Salt Lake. He explored the region from Salt Lake County to Sevier County; the city of Provo is named for this early adventurer. St. Louis, on account of its advantages as a river port and because lead mines were nearby, was the outfitting point for Provot and many of the early fur traders. Provot, like many other trappers, spent his last days in St. Louis where he died in 1850.
Jedediah S. Smith is well known to historians and to Californians generally but until recently has not occupied a prominent place in the early history of Utah. Smith was the first man to traverse the Great Salt Desert. He was a picturesque character, a courageous man and a conscientious worker of religious turn who carried a bible with him on his trips and sometimes preached to the Indians. Smith sold out his inter-est to James Bridger and others SMI1H	;n 1830. The next year he start-
ed on a trading expedition to the West and was presumably killed by Indians or Mexicans while obtaining water from a spring in what is now Western Kansas. Smith deserves a place in history with Lewis and Clark, Fremont. Carson and other explorers.
From the national viewpoint. John Charles Fremont is the most noted of early Utah explorers. He was born at Savannah, Georgia, January 21, 1813. Dellenbaugh, in his “Fremont and ’49,” states that a few months after Fremont was born Andrew Jackson and Thomas H. Benton, (Fremont’s future father-in-law), fought a duel near an inn occupied by the infant Fremont and a ball from one of the pistols passed thru the room where the parents were sitting. This was a most fitting introduction to a vivid career which extended to June 13, 1890. On that day he died in New York City from an attack of ptomaine poisoning while trying to wind up involved affairs that he might “live in peace in California.” His mother was a beautiful and brilliant daughter of Virginia; his father a courageous and adventurous Frenchman. Fremont was something of a classical student, excelled in mathematics, abandoned law and chose exploration as a calling. Charlestown College expelled him for inattention and insubordination and later rendered homage by giving him both a bachelor’s and master’s degree. He married Jessie Benton on October 19, 1841. Fremont left written records of five trails which reached from the Mississippi River across the country to Portland on the north and San Diego on the south. He was well equipped mentally and physically for his work. As an officer during the Civil War, he advocated arming negroes which brought trouble with the administration. Later he suffered financial reverses. There was lack of recognition and the Government forgot what he had done. Literary ghouls have attempted, as in the case of Custer, to besmirch his reputation, but his record rests on his writings and the statements of his associates. He always led—never followed.
Baptiste Tabeau was a member of Fremont’s party who left the little town of Kansas, about June 1, 1843, to explore the West. The expedition reached southwestern Utah on May 8, 1844. While camped near the Beaver Dam Mountains, then called the Santa Clara Mountains, a-mule was lost and Tabeau left camp without obtaining Fremont’s permission to secure the animal. cue him from the Indians. On the morning of May 10, 1844, Fremont and Thomas Fitzpatrick located the place where Tabeau had been killed. His horse, gun and clothes had been taken away and his body apparently thrown into the river. This is the first record of the death of a white man in what is now the State of Utah.
Pierre Jean DeSmet, of the Society of Jesus, was a native of Belgium who removed to America at an early age and spent more than thirty years in exploration work in the West. DeSmet’s principal labors were in what is now Montana, Idaho, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming where he established missions. While he was a devout Jesuit and defended his faith at all times, he wrote intelligently and entertainingly on secular affairs and fortunately left many descriptions of places, people and events. His general attitude was conciliatory and the friendly attitude he evidenced towards the Indians, together with what he said in peace councils, made travel much safer for whites. Brigham Young consulted him in 1846 on conditions in the West and the possibilities of settling there. DeSmet and Brigham Young were born the same year—1801. DeSmet died in St. Louis in 1873.
William Ashley was a leading spirit in the early fur trade. He traversed what is now Utah in 1825. In 1826 he sold out his interest to Smith, Jackson and Sublette of St. Louis. He was twice elected to Congress from Missouri and died in 1838.
Miles Goodyear secured a grant of land from the Mexican Government in 1841. This grant of land comprised a few square miles now occupied by Ogden. Goodyear built a fort and started settlement which consisted of a few mountaineers, Indians and half-breeds. James Brown, prominent Mormon pioneer, visited Goodyear early in January, 1848, and purchased his claim for some $3,000. Goodyear moved on and the Mormons began the systematic cultivation of crops around Ogden the same year.
According to the late Henry Byram Beckstead of South Jordan, a Mexican, who had secured a land grant from his Government, lived near the present town of Riverton when the Mormons entered the valley in 1847. According to Mr. Beckstead, his interests were bought out by church officials and the Mexican left the region. The south line of this grant ran through Riverton, the east line was the Jordan River, the north line was the southern shore of Great Salt Lake and the west line was the Oquirrh range.
John Bidwell was a native of Ohio. After teaching school and roughing it for a time, Bidwell helped organize the Bartleson-Bidwell Party which took the first wagons across what is now northern Utah in 1841. Bidwell and his companions pushed on to California. He became associated with Sutter and on many occasions acted as his right-hand man. Bidwell possessed a spirit of investigation, enterprise and integrity, combined with rare judgment. He was one of the early gold miners; from what is now called “Bidwell’s Bar” it is reported he took out $100,000 in gold. He became a large landholder and founded the town of Chico. He became prominent in politics and was the first candidate for the presidency from California. He was a staunch prohibitionist and opposed to the use of liquor in any way, and even to the
BIDWELL
DONNER
cultivation of grapes from which wine could be made. The Bidwell Route is now being marked by the Utah Historical Landmarks Association.
The Donner Party passed through Utah in 1846. Members of this party read glowing accounts of the West written by Lansford W. Hastings, and decided to emigrate. Two of the leaders in the party were George Donner, an elder brother Jacob, and James F. Reed. These men. and others in the party, were highly respected residents of Sangamon County, Ill. Reed was a member of the Black Hawk Military Company with Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas. The party left Springfield, Ill., in April, and Independence, Missouri, in May, 1846. They lost one member of their party in Kansas but reached Fort Bridger without great difficulty. Here the party divided and part of them went by way of Fort Hall, making their way safely to California. The Donner division was induced to follow a route outlined by Hastings, who preceded them with another party a few days ahead. Hastings and his party entered the Echo Canyon near Castle Rock, passed down Echo Canyon, through Weber Canyon and south to Salt Lake City, then across the desert to Pilot Peak. When the Donners reached what is now Echo, they found a note from Hastings advising them not to go down Weber Canyon on account of its inaccessibility. Men were sent on ahead to confer with Hastings who was located west of Grantsville. Hastings returned to the Oquirrh mountains and indicated a route through which the Donner party could reach Salt Lake Valley. The Donner party then proceeded down the canyon to Henefer, passed up Main Canyon along what is now East Canyon Creek reservoir, turned to the right at Dutchman’s Creek at the Clayton Ranch, passed over Big Mountain through Mountain
H
<s
HASTINGS
Dell and over Little Mountain into Emigration Canyon. According to tradition, this point of emergence in Emigration Canyon is also the same place where Brigham Young’s wagon rested the last night before he entered Salt Lake Valley. The Donner party came into Salt Lake Valley, spent some time around City Creek and crossed the Jordan. They buried a member of their party, Luke Halloran, near what is now Garfield, the first Mason buried in Utah. They then proceeded west to Twenty Wells, now Grantsville, around the point of the mountain at Timpie, south to Big Springs, near losepa, across Skull Valley and over Hastings Pass and onto the desert. They were led to believe that the Great Salt Desert extended west about forty-five miles; the distance is nearly ninety. After terrible privations, loss of livestock and equipment, they finally reached Pilot Peak and proceeded on their way to the Humboldt. At Gravelly Ford, near what is now Beowawe, members of the party quarreled and one of them was killed. The party finally reached Donner Lake in the Sierras. An early winter set in and nearly half of them were frozen or starved to death. The Donner Route is followed

BRIDGER
quite closely by the Lincoln Highway from Fort Bridger to Salt Lake City and by the Lincoln-Vic-tory Highway to Wendover. The Donner Route and the Hastings Route through Weber Canyon, have been marked by the Utah Historical Landmarks Association from Fort Bridger to Wendover. The Donner Route was the first historic emigrant road to be marked through Utah. A splendid monument marks the spot where this party camped at Donner Lake.
James Bridger, of Scotch descent, was born in Richmond, Virginia, in 1804, and died near Kansas City in 1881. As a youth, Bridger learned the blacksmith trade which was of great use to him in later years in repairing guns and equipment. When he was eighteen years of age he enlisted with the Ashley party and made a trip to the mouth of the Yellowstone, traveling by way of the Missouri river. Early in life he became acquainted with the tactics, traditions, practices and leaders of different fur companies, rival trappers and hostile Indians. He was one of the party which discovered Bridger’s Pass through which the Union Pacific runs.
To Bridger belongs the credit of being the first white man to look on the waters of Great Salt Lake. This was in 1824. He established Ft. Bridger in 1843, rendered valuable aid to the U. S. Government and was known and highly respected by the great western military leaders of his day. He made many strong friends and bitter enemies and a few writers have attempted to belittle his reputation. J. Cecil Alter in his “James Bridger” has performed a service for this great frontiersman similar to that performed by Dellenbaugh for Fremont in his “Fremont and ’49.”
COLONIZATION
Brigham Young was born June 1, 1801, at Whit-ingham, Windham County, Vermont, and died in Salt Lake City, Utah, on August 29, 1877. His father served in the Revolutionary War and his grandfather served in the French and Indian wars. The Youngs were Methodists. When Brigham Young was three years old the family moved to Sherburne, Chenango County, New York. Brigham Young’s father was a farmer and he assisted his father on the farm; he also learned something of carpenter work and painting and was proficient as a glazier. He first saw the Book of Mormon in 1830, and in 1832 became converted to Mormonism and was baptized April 14, 1832. Heber C. Kimball joined the church about the same time; his early associations with Kimball lasted through life. Brigham Young visited Kirtland early in 1831 and met the Prophet Joseph Smith in Kirtland in May, 1832. _ He was a leader during the troublesome times of ’33 and ’34, and in 1835 was selected as one of the twelve apostles. In 1840 Brigham Young, with others, sailed on a mission to England. He was instrumental in making many converts and under his direction the first saints sailed for America. He was in New Hampshire when the Prophet Joseph Smith was assassinated at Nauvoo. He succeeded Joseph Smith as head of the Mormon Church, a position he oc^ cupied until his death. DIGEST OF MOTOR VEHICLE LAWS
Licenses. Must be obtained by resident owners prior to the third Monday in January, or within five days after buying new car. Fees must be sent to the Assessor of the county in which the applicant resides. Misdemeanor to operate car without plates for current year.
Visitors' Permits. Visitors from other States who have complied with the laws of home State are permitted to remain in Nevada for 90 days before procuring Nevada license. However, within 10 days after arrival, they must register with the Secretary of State, the Assessor of any county, or the Nevada Highway Association at Reno, and obtain visitor’s permit. Home registration certificate must be presented for stamping when permit is requested. No charge for permit.
Speed. Reasonable and proper speed, having regard to traffic, nature of road, etc., must be maintained; 50 miles, maximum.
Plates. Two plates, one at each end. must be carried in plain view. Do not conceal plates behind baggage or bumpers. Fictitious plates are unlawful. If one plate be lost or destroyed, it becomes the duty of the owner to return the remaining plate to the issuing officer, with an affidavit setting forth the fact that the other plate was lost or destroyed, with a fee of $1, whereupon a new set of plates will be issued.
Lights. Must be dimmed in face of approaching traffic, or cars must be equipped with lenses that keep the light below a line 42 inches above the road.
Drivers—Intoxicated, incompetent or incapable persons, or persons under the age of 15 years are prohibited from driving automobiles on any road.
Enforcement. All peace officers of the State are required to enforce the Motor Vehicle Act, particularly in respect to registfa-tion. The State Police also constitute a special enforcement detail.
Transfer of Ownership. When a vehicle is transferred, it becomes the duty of the former owner to return at once the registration certificate to the Assessor with a fee of 50 cents, whereupon the registration will be transferred to the new owner.
Rendering Aid. When a driver of any ve'hicle strikes another vehicle or person, he shall stop immediately and give his name and address and the number of his vehicle. If required or requested, he shall give any aid that may be necessary, including the carrying of the injured person or persons to medical or surgical treatment.
Maximum Weight. No vehicle permitted to be operated when total weight of vehicle and load exceeds 25,000 pounds when equipped with four wheels running on the highway, or 30,000 pounds when equipped with six wheels and three axles, no two of which are less than 96 inches apart. Maximum weight per inch of tire cannot exceed 600 pounds.
Brakes. Efficient brakes must be maintained at all times. When driving in mountains always keep car in gear when descending grades.

HIGHWAY MAP
OF THE
STATE OF NEVADA
Issued by
THE DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS
Carson City, Nevada
S. C. DURKEE State Highway Engineer
This map is issued in accordance with the statutes of Nevada establishing the Department of Highways, and is intended primarily for the use of the Department of Highways. The map is intended also to give the traveling public a fair representation of the highways as they exist in this State. Improved highways differentiating between types of surfacing are shown under legend on face of map. County roads are in general narrow dirt roads receiving some county maintenance.
No particular attempt is made on this map to show natural features or topography. Counties are outlined but not named. For further information concerning the State of Nevada the reader is referred to the Department of Highways.

DIGEST OF MOTOR VEHICLE LAWS
Licenses. Must be obtained by resident owners prior to the third Monday in January, or within five days after buying new car. Fees must be sent to the Assessor of the county in which the applicant resides. Misdemeanor to operate car without plates for current year.
Visitors' Permits. Visitors from other States who have complied with the laws of home State are permitted to remain in Nevada for 90 days before procuring Nevada license. However, within 10 days after arrival, they must register with the Secretary of State, the Assessor of any county, or the Nevada Highway Association at Reno, and obtain visitor’s permit. Home registration certificate must be presented for stamping when permit is requested. No charge for permit.
Speed. Reasonable and proper speed, having regard to traffic, nature of road, etc., must be maintained; 50 miles, maximum.
Plates. Two plates, one at each end. must be carried in plain view. Do not conceal plates behind baggage or bumpers. Fictitious plates are unlawful. If one plate be lost or destroyed, it becomes the duty of the owner to return the remaining plate to the issuing officer, with an affidavit setting forth the fact that the other plate was lost or destroyed, with a fee of $1, whereupon a new set of plates will be issued.
Lights. Must be dimmed in face of approaching traffic, or cars must be equipped with lenses that keep the light below a line 42 inches above the road.
Drivers—Intoxicated, incompetent or incapable persons, or persons under the age of 15 years are prohibited from driving automobiles on any road.
Enforcement. All peace officers of the State are required to enforce the Motor Vehicle Act, particularly in respect to registfa-tion. The State Police also constitute a special enforcement detail.
Transfer of Ownership. When a vehicle is transferred, it becomes the duty of the former owner to return at once the registration certificate to the Assessor with a fee of 50 cents, whereupon the registration will be transferred to the new owner.
Rendering Aid. When a driver of any ve'hicle strikes another vehicle or person, he shall stop immediately and give his name and address and the number of his vehicle. If required or requested, he shall give any aid that may be necessary, including the carrying of the injured person or persons to medical or surgical treatment.
Maximum Weight. No vehicle permitted to be operated when total weight of vehicle and load exceeds 25,000 pounds when equipped with four wheels running on the highway, or 30,000 pounds when equipped with six wheels and three axles, no two of which are less than 96 inches apart. Maximum weight per inch of tire cannot exceed 600 pounds.
Brakes. Efficient brakes must be maintained at all times. When driving in mountains always keep car in gear when descending grades.

HIGHWAY MAP
OF THE
STATE OF NEVADA
Issued by
THE DEPARTMENT OF HIGHWAYS
Carson City, Nevada
S. C. DURKEE State Highway Engineer
This map is issued in accordance with the statutes of Nevada establishing the Department of Highways, and is intended primarily for the use of the Department of Highways. The map is intended also to give the traveling public a fair representation of the highways as they exist in this State. Improved highways differentiating between types of surfacing are shown under legend on face of map. County roads are in general narrow dirt roads receiving some county maintenance.
No particular attempt is made on this map to show natural features or topography. Counties are outlined but not named. For further information concerning the State of Nevada the reader is referred to the Department of Highways.
THIS MAP MUST NOT BE SOLD

KAIBAB NATIONAL FOREST.
This folder describes briefly the Grand Canyon of the Colorado Eiver, the Kaibab National Forest, and contiguous country.
The Grand Canyon proper is within the boundaries of two of the National Forests, the Tusayan ou the south, and the Kaibab 011 the north. Also included within these Forests is the Grand Canyon National Game Preserve with an area of 1,492,928 acres, and the Grand Canyon National Monument with an area of 806,400 acres.
The Kaibab Forest has an approximate area of 1,072,900 acres. This area does not by any means include all of the interesting features of the Grand Canyon country. Immediately to the north, south, east, and west, and extending for hundreds of miles along the Colorado Eiver are mountains, plateaus, deep canyons, and wide valleys of surpassing interest, many of which have never been explored by white men. Little is known of the deep side gorges and canyons of the Grand Canyon proper, save that they afford safe retreat for mountain sheep (bighorn) and other wild game.
Visitors are always welcome in the Kaibab Forest and the Grand Canyon. The local Forest force is ready to furnish the traveler with information and to assist in making his trip a pleasant one. In return, visitors are earnestly requested to cooperate with the Forest officers in protecting the timber and other Forest resources from injury.
Carelessness with fire is an unforgivable sin. A forest fire once beyond control may not only destroy the traveler’s own opportunities for pleasure, but endanger his life as well, besides doing incalculable damage to timber and private property. A forest fire destroys in an hour that which has taken centuries to develop. To guard against this, visitors are requested to observe closely the regulations and laws regarding forest fires, as well as the Federal laws regarding the Game Presen e, the National Monument, and public health and camp sanitation.
SCENIC ATTRACTIONS.
The ‘ ‘ Grand Canyon ’ ’ of the Colorado lies entirely within the boundaries of Arizona. The Canyon, combined with the Kaibab National Forest and Game Preserve, presents recreational and sight-seeing features not found anywhere else in the West. Topograpically, the entire length of the Grand Canyon, beginning at Lee’s Ferry on the Colorado Eiver and extending westerly to the Grand Wash and nearly to the mouth of the Virgin Eiver, is 238 miles. That part of the Canyon forming the south boundary of the Kaibab Forest, about 150 miles along the river, presents scenic features of exceptional grandeur and is the Mecca of tourists from all all parts of the world.
The Grand Canyon was first explored in 1869-70, and the Colorado Eiver, which finds its way through the Canyon to the Gulf of Lower California, was navigated at the same time by Major Powell and party in the employ of the United States Government. A most interesting account of this trip through the Canyon in boats has been given by Fredrick S. Dcllenbaugh, who accompanied the party, in his book, u The Romance of the Colorado River.” Dellenbaugh’s description of their experiences while passing through Marble Canyon is well worth quoting:
“The 22d was a day particularly remembered, for the walls, though more broken at the water’s edge, were now some 3,500 feet high and seemed to be increasing by leaps and bounds, for at one place through the side gorge on the right, we could see cliffs so far above our heads that tall pine trees on them looked no larger than lead pencils. It was the end of the Kaibab Plateau whose summit was more than 5,000 feet higher than the river at that point. (This was the east rim of Greenland, the southern extremity of the Kaibab Plateau.) Cataract after cataract followed rapidly and rapids followed cataracts as we were hurled on down through the midst of the sublimity, which parting at our advance, closed again behind like some wonderful phantasmagoria.”
The following day Dellenbaugh describes their passage from Marble Canyon into the Grand Canyon proper:
£ 1 Late in the day there came a long straight stretch; at the bottom the river appeared to vanish. Had anyone now said that the course was underground from that point onward it would have seemed entirely appropriate. In the outer world the sun was low, though it had long gone to us, and the blue haze of approaching night was drawing a veil of strange uncertainty among the cliffs, while far above, the upper portions of the mighty eastern walls, at all times of gorgeous hue, were now beautifully enriched by the last hot radiance of the western sky. Such views as this were well worth the labor we had accomplished. When the end of the marvellous piece of canyon was reached, a small river was seen to enter on the left through a narrow gorge like the main canyon. This was the Little Colorado Eiver, and beside it on the sand bank we stopped for the night, having ended one of the finest runs of our experience. This day’s run was about 18 miles with but a single let-down, yet in this distance there were 18 rapids, one of which was about 2-1 miles long. It was a glorious record, and I do not recall another day which was so exhilarating. We arrived at the end of Marble Canyon and the beginning of the Grand Canyon, there being nothing to mark the division but the narrow gorge of the Little Colorado River. In Marble Canyon we had found 69 rapids in 65 miles with a total descent of 480 feet.”
The Buckskin Mountains and the Kaibab Plateau are practically one and the same, and like the Grand Canyon and the National Game Preserve, are within the boundaries of the Kaibab Forest. The word “plateau” aptly describes the physical features of the Forest. The word “Kaibab” is a Piute Indian name and means “mountain lying down,” a term thoroughly descriptive of the Buckskin Mountains. Save for the numerous small draws and ridges marking the surface, and a gradual variation of elevation between 8,000 and 9,000 feet,
the mountains form a plateau. The total length of this plateau north and south is more than 75 miles ; its width at the widest place on top is 25 miles. The area rises gradually from all sides to a point in the center. It is easily accessible from the east, west, and north sides, as well as from the northeast over the Grand Canyon Highway, which has been completed entirely across the plateau to Bright Angel Station on the rim of the Canyon. For about 30 miles out of Kauab the road passes over a desert country covered with sage brush, having an average elevation of perhaps 5,000 feet; then begins the climb up the side of the plateau 6 miles to the top. A rise of some 2,500 feet is made in this distance, which takes one into the edge of the pine timber for which the Forest has become famous, and which is perhaps the largest single body of such timber in the world. From this elevation the road continues almost due south across the plateau, via Jacobs Lake Eanger Station, through the timber, interspersed with beautiful parks where deer gather in large numbers, to the rim of the Grand Canyon. From Bright Angel Eanger Station it is only 2.2 miles to Bright Angel Point, where one comes suddenly to the rim of the Grand Canyon of the Colorado Eiver and the first splendid view.
The geological formation of this region, surface, transfiguration, location, climatical conditions, and variations, places the Grand Canyon entirely within a class by itself. The whole gamut of climatical variations are experienced in a trip from the rim of the Canyon at an elevation of over 8,000 feet, to the Colorado Eiver at the bottom of the Canyon some 5,000 feet below. The difference in elevation between the bottom of the Grand Canyon and Bright Angel Point is over 5,000 feet, or practically 1 mile.
The north rim of the Grand Canyon is fully 1,200 feet higher than the rim on the south side. At Bright Angel Point the benchmark
established by Major Powell in 1882 records an elevation of 8,153 feet. This monument is located on the furthermost extremity of a narrow tableland overlooking much of the deeper part of the Canyon. Splendid views from this point may be had of many of the side canyons, which are almost as deep as the Grand Canyon. From this point to El Tavor Hotel and the Santa Fe Eailway Station on the opposite rim of the Canyon, the distance is approximately 12 miles in a straight line. This is the average width of the Canyon from rim to rim for a distance of perhaps 75 miles. To the west of Bright Angel Point along the rim are Tiyo, Grama, Sublime, Lancelot, Emerald, and Yio-let Points. From Point Sublime a panoramic view can be had of at least 100 miles of the Grand Canyon and side canyons, with 2 or 3 miles of the Colorado Eiver deep down in the gorge.
West of Point Sublime lies Powell Plateau, a tableland set entirely off from the main land but accessible by trail. This plateau is completely surrounded by deep canyons and perpendicular limestone and marble cliffs, presenting a most stupendous assemblage of deep caverns, canyons and cliffs, temples and gorges. It is some 10 miles long and 2 miles wide, with an average elevation of 8,000 feet, and contains several thousand acres of splendid grazing land. Deer and other wild game abound. Splendid views are to be had from here of the Canyon, Eiver, Buckskin Mountains, the Forest, and desert to the west and south.
To the west of Powell Plateau are Kanab Creek and Kanab Canyon, marking the west boundary of the Kaibab Forest and Game Preserve. Kanab Canyon is in itself a Grand Canyon of no small porportions, and is so rugged and so infrequented by human beings that mountain sheep abound in great numbers. To the west of Kanab Creek outside the boundaries of the Forest, are Tucket Canyon, Toroweap Yalley. and Trumbull Mountain, also the home of mountain sheep and deer.
To the east of Bright Angel Point lies Greenland, which is, as may be seen from the accompanying map, a splendid timbered peninsula or tableland of some 20 miles in length, so named on account of its resemblance to the island of Greenland. Some of the finest views are to be had from Greenland, especially from Cape Eoyal at the extreme south end of the peninsula. The Colorado Eiver, deep down in the Canyon, is visible in several places from this point. Fully half of the Navajo Indian Eeser-vation, “The Painted Desert,” the Little Colorado Eiver and Canyon, which is nearly as deep as the Grand Canyon, the San Francisco Mountains, and the Tusayan National Forest, are plainly seen. At Cape Eoyal, Cape Final, Naji, Horan, Obi, and Komo Points, magnificent views are to be had of different sections of the Grand Canyon and Eiver. To the north of Greenland along the rim, and especially at a point locally known as “Skadoo Point,” other splendid views may be obtained. From this latter point Nancoweap, Kwagunt, House Bock Yalley, and the Pahreah Plateau are to be seen. House Bock Valley, with its 200,000 acres of fine grazing land, is in itself well worth the trip. It is a low, flat fan-shaped tract of land sloping toward the Colorado Eiver, ensconced between the high Buckskin Mountains to the north and west and the pink vermilion cliffs of Pahreah to the east. It is the winter range for a great number of cattle and horses. Some 40 buffalo and cattelo also range in this valley. The cattelo is a hybrid obtained by cross-breeding cattle with buffalo. The result is, however, to all appearances a buffalo, except that the characteristic hump is not as prominent.
From Skadoo Point the course of the Colorado Eiver is plainly visible for 50 miles to Lee’s Ferry by the snake-like course of the deep gorge across the floor of the valley. The course of the Colorado Eiver in this valley is through Marble Canyon, and is said to be the most beautiful and most dangerous to uavigate of any section of the Grand Canyon. Some 300
falls and cataracts were encountered by Major Powell in his memorable trip. Marble Canyon begins at Lee’s Ferry and is 50 miles in length. Lee’s Ferry is the only place iu a distance of 500 miles along the Colorado Eiver where one may cross to the south side of the Eiver with a team or other’conveyance on a ferry boat.
ANCIENT RUINS AND RELICS.
In the dark, inaccessible recesses of the Grand Canyon, thousands of feet below the rim, are numerous cliff dwellings, ruins of an ancient and vanished race. Many of these dwellings are high up under the overhanging cliffs and bluffs and cannot be reached. From evidences left by the cliff dwellers, the canyons, plateaus, and deserts of the surrounding country undoubtedly supported a large population. How they managed to exist in this deep canyon where there is so little soil suited to cultivation is a mystery. This one feature of the Grand Canyon is well worth the time and expense required to see it. Years could be spent in the depths of the canyons in the exploration of these hidden and long-abandoned homes of a race of people of whom we know so little. Within 10 miles of Kanab, in Cottonwood Canyon and other canyons nearby, are well preserved ancient dwellings. The timbers used in this construction are still preserved. In Kanak, Johnson, Shinumo, and other canyons and gulches are many Indian paintings and hieroglyphics on the surfaces of boulders and rock ledges. Trips from Kanab or Fredonia to all these interesting-ruins and paintings may be made with comparative ease, either with team or on horseback, at almost any time of the year.
WILD GAME.
It is estimated that the Grand Canyon National Game Preserve contains between 10,000 and 15,000 deer. A great many of them can be seen in a trip across the Forest, and sometimes they may be approached close enough to be photographed. In the Grand Canyon below the
rim, and in the breaks, are both deer and mountain sheep. The sheep are never seen on the plateau and very rarely in the Canyon. There are also numerous mountain lions in all parts of the Forest. They are frequently seen prowling around through the timber, and thousands of deer are destroyed each year by these predatory animals. The Government now employs hunters to destroy them. There are a few timber wolves, while coyotes and bobcats are numerous. To the east of the Game Preserve, and immediately off the Forest in House Rock Yalley, are some 45 head of buffalo. They were shipped into the country in 1907 from the Goodnight Ranch in the Panhandle of Texas. They are increasing and bid fair to develop into a large herd. The home of these animals is easy of access over trails from all parts of the Forest.
One other interesting feature of protected, wild life on this Preserve is the white-tailed squirrel. It is said that the Kaibab Forest is the only place in the world where this peculiar animal is found. In size and color it is similar to the common grey squirrel of the eastern and southern states, the only dissimilarity being that this animal has a white bushy tail. The animals are numerous, and are always seen during the course of a trip across the Preserve or Forest. Like the deer, mountain sheep, quail, and grouse, they are protected by Federal laws and there is no open season for hunting them.
The destruction of predatory animals, such as timber wolves, mountain lions, coyotes, and bobcats, however, is not prohibited but encouraged. No better mountain lion hunting can be found anywhere in the west than on this Forest, and more satisfactory results may be had than is ^usually the case elsewhere with this kind of sport. The timber in this section is open, making it possible to ride rapidly through it in following the chase.
FOREST RESOURCES.
Practically 40 per cent of the area of the Kaibab Forest is heavily timbered with a dense stand of western yellow pine (Rinus ponderosa.) This timber occupies the plateau section of the Buckskin Mountains above an elevation of 7,000 feet, and the extent of the belt is practically 50 miles north and south by 20 miles east and west. The main body of timber is frequently intercepted by long narrow areas of open grass parks. It is estimated there are over 2 billion feet of merchantable timber 011 the Forest, of which 80 per cent or more is yellow pine. Considerable Douglas fii' of large size and excellent (quality is scattered over the south half of the area. From a logging and lumbering standpoint, this timbered belt contains fewer engineering difficulties than any similar belt of timber west of the Eocky Mountains.
FOREST FIRES.
If we wish to preserve these National re-sou toes, extreme care must be exercised by campers and tourists with camp fires, matches, piqies, cigar and cigarette stubs from which fire may originate. More than three-fourths of all forest fires are due to carelessness on the part of campers and other travelers. Many disastrous fires have been caused by a non-extinguished match, a cigarette or cigar stub, carelessly flipped into inflammable material. Camp fires should not be built against trees or rotten logs, or near large accumulations of debris. Rotten logs often smoulder though apparently the fire has been extinguished, when after a few hours it will break out again in flames.
The six rules, given on page 14, if observed closely by campers, will keep down the number of fires to a minimum.
A close observation of these rules will not only add to the pleasure and security of the tourists and campers while on the Forest, but will be of inestimable assistance to the local Forest officers.
There are very stringent laws covering forest fires caused by carelessness. Forest officers are empowered to arrest without warrant for the violations of these laws, when necessary.
ROADS AND TRAILS.
How to reach Kaibab National Forest and the Grand Canyon of' the Colorado.
The Grand Cauyon of the Colorado is accessible from the north with automobiles over the Grand Canyon Highway. This road is a trunk line from the north boundary of the Forest to the rim of the Canyon. The total length of the road is 56 miles; it is an excellent auto road having only a few grades that exceed 10 per cent.
The town of Kanab is the gateway to the Grand Canyon country and is 82 miles from the Canyon’s rim.
Tourists who visit the Canyon by way of Kanab, whether by train or by auto, usually pass through Salt Lake City. This city, besides being the capital of the State of Utah, is one of the most interesting cities in the west and is the objective point for many tourists. There are several auto routes from Salt Lake City to Kanab. There are two railroads, the Denver & Eio Grande with its terminus at Marysvale, Utah, a distance of apqn-oximately 135 miles from Kanab; and the San Pedro, Los Angeles & Salt Lake, with a station at Lund, Utah, a distance of approximately 145 miles from Kanab. From either Marysvale or Lund there is regular auto stage service running to within 75 miles of Kanab. Automobiles and other special conveyances also can be hired at a reasonable rate.
The traveler who wishes to approach the Grand Canyon from the south should take the Atchison, Topeko, & Santa Fe Railroad to Grand Canyon Station. From this point there are trails down into the Canyon and a cable crossing over the Colorado Eiver. The trip
over the trails can be made afoot or horseback. By prearrangement ivith guides at Fredonia or Kanab, parties will be met either at the Grand Cauyon Station or at El Tavor Hotel on the south side of the Canyon, or, if preferred, at the river’s edge, from Avhicli points they will be conducted to the north side of the Canyon through the Kaibab Forest, the Game Preserve, into House Rock Valley, and other places of interest.
The boundary line betAveen the States of Utah and Arizona is crossed 3 miles south of Kanab. That part of Arizona lying north of the Grand Canyon and the Colorado Eiver is knoAvn as the “Arizona strip.” SeA'en and one-half miles south of Kanab is the little town of Fredonia, Ariz., the only toAvu or settlement Avith a post-office in Arizona north of the Grand Canyon; a toAvn made famous by its isolation with reference to other sections of its State, and also by the honor of having recently had one of its citizens elected as Governor of the State of Arizona. This little toAvu is also the home of James L. OAvens, a notable character and plainsman of the old school from the Panhandle of Texas. He is a famous hunter and has had charge of many notable hunting parties an the Kaibab Forest at different times, including ex-President Roose-A'elt; and son.
One and one-half miles southeast of Fredonia, the road forks! The road to the left and east should be folloAved, as it is the Grand Canyon Highway. The Avatering places along the route from Kanab are Fredonia, Jacobs Lake, East Lake, Crain Lake, Big Park Spring, and Bright Angel Eanger Station. From Kanab to Jacobs Lake Ranger Station, the first Avatering place enroute, the distance is 37.8 miles. Parties Avith automobiles should take on 10 gallons of extra water before leaving Kanab or Fredonia.

Plenty of gasoline should be taken on at Kanab, since there are at qn-esent no places on the Forest Avliere this commodity can be purchased. The smaller cars use from 12 to 15 gallons of gasoline in making the round trip from Kanab, a distance of 164 miles. Parties desiring to cross the Colorado Eiver to the railroad on the south side may secure guides at Kanab and Fredonia.
Bright Angel Trail leaves the rim of the Canyon 5 miles east of Bright Angel Point, the terminus of the Grand Canyon IlighAvay, and folloAvs the course of Bright Angel Creek, a distance of 15 miles to a suspension ferry crossing the Colorado Eiver. This ferry is for foot passengers only. Stock are made to SAvim the river. From the opposite side of the river the trail, after a short steeqa climb, follows the benches for about 5 miles and connects Avith the Cameron trail from El Tavor Hotel ou the south side of the Canyon. Bright Angel Trail is used extensively by tourists, and will continue to be used more each season as the roads of the country and tourist travel are developed.
