KAIBAB NATIONAL FOREST.
This folder describes briefly the Grand Canyon of the Colorado Eiver, the Kaibab National Forest, and contiguous country.
The Grand Canyon proper is within the boundaries of two of the National Forests, the Tusayan ou the south, and the Kaibab 011 the north. Also included within these Forests is the Grand Canyon National Game Preserve with an area of 1,492,928 acres, and the Grand Canyon National Monument with an area of 806,400 acres.
The Kaibab Forest has an approximate area of 1,072,900 acres. This area does not by any means include all of the interesting features of the Grand Canyon country. Immediately to the north, south, east, and west, and extending for hundreds of miles along the Colorado Eiver are mountains, plateaus, deep canyons, and wide valleys of surpassing interest, many of which have never been explored by white men. Little is known of the deep side gorges and canyons of the Grand Canyon proper, save that they afford safe retreat for mountain sheep (bighorn) and other wild game.
Visitors are always welcome in the Kaibab Forest and the Grand Canyon. The local Forest force is ready to furnish the traveler with information and to assist in making his trip a pleasant one. In return, visitors are earnestly requested to cooperate with the Forest officers in protecting the timber and other Forest resources from injury.
Carelessness with fire is an unforgivable sin. A forest fire once beyond control may not only destroy the traveler’s own opportunities for pleasure, but endanger his life as well, besides doing incalculable damage to timber and private property. A forest fire destroys in an hour that which has taken centuries to develop. To guard against this, visitors are requested to observe closely the regulations and laws regarding forest fires, as well as the Federal laws regarding the Game Presen e, the National Monument, and public health and camp sanitation.
SCENIC ATTRACTIONS.
The ‘ ‘ Grand Canyon ’ ’ of the Colorado lies entirely within the boundaries of Arizona. The Canyon, combined with the Kaibab National Forest and Game Preserve, presents recreational and sight-seeing features not found anywhere else in the West. Topograpically, the entire length of the Grand Canyon, beginning at Lee’s Ferry on the Colorado Eiver and extending westerly to the Grand Wash and nearly to the mouth of the Virgin Eiver, is 238 miles. That part of the Canyon forming the south boundary of the Kaibab Forest, about 150 miles along the river, presents scenic features of exceptional grandeur and is the Mecca of tourists from all all parts of the world.
The Grand Canyon was first explored in 1869-70, and the Colorado Eiver, which finds its way through the Canyon to the Gulf of Lower California, was navigated at the same time by Major Powell and party in the employ of the United States Government. A most interesting account of this trip through the Canyon in boats has been given by Fredrick S. Dcllenbaugh, who accompanied the party, in his book, u The Romance of the Colorado River.” Dellenbaugh’s description of their experiences while passing through Marble Canyon is well worth quoting:
“The 22d was a day particularly remembered, for the walls, though more broken at the water’s edge, were now some 3,500 feet high and seemed to be increasing by leaps and bounds, for at one place through the side gorge on the right, we could see cliffs so far above our heads that tall pine trees on them looked no larger than lead pencils. It was the end of the Kaibab Plateau whose summit was more than 5,000 feet higher than the river at that point. (This was the east rim of Greenland, the southern extremity of the Kaibab Plateau.) Cataract after cataract followed rapidly and rapids followed cataracts as we were hurled on down through the midst of the sublimity, which parting at our advance, closed again behind like some wonderful phantasmagoria.”
The following day Dellenbaugh describes their passage from Marble Canyon into the Grand Canyon proper:
£ 1 Late in the day there came a long straight stretch; at the bottom the river appeared to vanish. Had anyone now said that the course was underground from that point onward it would have seemed entirely appropriate. In the outer world the sun was low, though it had long gone to us, and the blue haze of approaching night was drawing a veil of strange uncertainty among the cliffs, while far above, the upper portions of the mighty eastern walls, at all times of gorgeous hue, were now beautifully enriched by the last hot radiance of the western sky. Such views as this were well worth the labor we had accomplished. When the end of the marvellous piece of canyon was reached, a small river was seen to enter on the left through a narrow gorge like the main canyon. This was the Little Colorado Eiver, and beside it on the sand bank we stopped for the night, having ended one of the finest runs of our experience. This day’s run was about 18 miles with but a single let-down, yet in this distance there were 18 rapids, one of which was about 2-1 miles long. It was a glorious record, and I do not recall another day which was so exhilarating. We arrived at the end of Marble Canyon and the beginning of the Grand Canyon, there being nothing to mark the division but the narrow gorge of the Little Colorado River. In Marble Canyon we had found 69 rapids in 65 miles with a total descent of 480 feet.”
The Buckskin Mountains and the Kaibab Plateau are practically one and the same, and like the Grand Canyon and the National Game Preserve, are within the boundaries of the Kaibab Forest. The word “plateau” aptly describes the physical features of the Forest. The word “Kaibab” is a Piute Indian name and means “mountain lying down,” a term thoroughly descriptive of the Buckskin Mountains. Save for the numerous small draws and ridges marking the surface, and a gradual variation of elevation between 8,000 and 9,000 feet,
the mountains form a plateau. The total length of this plateau north and south is more than 75 miles ; its width at the widest place on top is 25 miles. The area rises gradually from all sides to a point in the center. It is easily accessible from the east, west, and north sides, as well as from the northeast over the Grand Canyon Highway, which has been completed entirely across the plateau to Bright Angel Station on the rim of the Canyon. For about 30 miles out of Kauab the road passes over a desert country covered with sage brush, having an average elevation of perhaps 5,000 feet; then begins the climb up the side of the plateau 6 miles to the top. A rise of some 2,500 feet is made in this distance, which takes one into the edge of the pine timber for which the Forest has become famous, and which is perhaps the largest single body of such timber in the world. From this elevation the road continues almost due south across the plateau, via Jacobs Lake Eanger Station, through the timber, interspersed with beautiful parks where deer gather in large numbers, to the rim of the Grand Canyon. From Bright Angel Eanger Station it is only 2.2 miles to Bright Angel Point, where one comes suddenly to the rim of the Grand Canyon of the Colorado Eiver and the first splendid view.
The geological formation of this region, surface, transfiguration, location, climatical conditions, and variations, places the Grand Canyon entirely within a class by itself. The whole gamut of climatical variations are experienced in a trip from the rim of the Canyon at an elevation of over 8,000 feet, to the Colorado Eiver at the bottom of the Canyon some 5,000 feet below. The difference in elevation between the bottom of the Grand Canyon and Bright Angel Point is over 5,000 feet, or practically 1 mile.
The north rim of the Grand Canyon is fully 1,200 feet higher than the rim on the south side. At Bright Angel Point the benchmark
established by Major Powell in 1882 records an elevation of 8,153 feet. This monument is located on the furthermost extremity of a narrow tableland overlooking much of the deeper part of the Canyon. Splendid views from this point may be had of many of the side canyons, which are almost as deep as the Grand Canyon. From this point to El Tavor Hotel and the Santa Fe Eailway Station on the opposite rim of the Canyon, the distance is approximately 12 miles in a straight line. This is the average width of the Canyon from rim to rim for a distance of perhaps 75 miles. To the west of Bright Angel Point along the rim are Tiyo, Grama, Sublime, Lancelot, Emerald, and Yio-let Points. From Point Sublime a panoramic view can be had of at least 100 miles of the Grand Canyon and side canyons, with 2 or 3 miles of the Colorado Eiver deep down in the gorge.
West of Point Sublime lies Powell Plateau, a tableland set entirely off from the main land but accessible by trail. This plateau is completely surrounded by deep canyons and perpendicular limestone and marble cliffs, presenting a most stupendous assemblage of deep caverns, canyons and cliffs, temples and gorges. It is some 10 miles long and 2 miles wide, with an average elevation of 8,000 feet, and contains several thousand acres of splendid grazing land. Deer and other wild game abound. Splendid views are to be had from here of the Canyon, Eiver, Buckskin Mountains, the Forest, and desert to the west and south.
To the west of Powell Plateau are Kanab Creek and Kanab Canyon, marking the west boundary of the Kaibab Forest and Game Preserve. Kanab Canyon is in itself a Grand Canyon of no small porportions, and is so rugged and so infrequented by human beings that mountain sheep abound in great numbers. To the west of Kanab Creek outside the boundaries of the Forest, are Tucket Canyon, Toroweap Yalley. and Trumbull Mountain, also the home of mountain sheep and deer.
To the east of Bright Angel Point lies Greenland, which is, as may be seen from the accompanying map, a splendid timbered peninsula or tableland of some 20 miles in length, so named on account of its resemblance to the island of Greenland. Some of the finest views are to be had from Greenland, especially from Cape Eoyal at the extreme south end of the peninsula. The Colorado Eiver, deep down in the Canyon, is visible in several places from this point. Fully half of the Navajo Indian Eeser-vation, “The Painted Desert,” the Little Colorado Eiver and Canyon, which is nearly as deep as the Grand Canyon, the San Francisco Mountains, and the Tusayan National Forest, are plainly seen. At Cape Eoyal, Cape Final, Naji, Horan, Obi, and Komo Points, magnificent views are to be had of different sections of the Grand Canyon and Eiver. To the north of Greenland along the rim, and especially at a point locally known as “Skadoo Point,” other splendid views may be obtained. From this latter point Nancoweap, Kwagunt, House Bock Yalley, and the Pahreah Plateau are to be seen. House Bock Valley, with its 200,000 acres of fine grazing land, is in itself well worth the trip. It is a low, flat fan-shaped tract of land sloping toward the Colorado Eiver, ensconced between the high Buckskin Mountains to the north and west and the pink vermilion cliffs of Pahreah to the east. It is the winter range for a great number of cattle and horses. Some 40 buffalo and cattelo also range in this valley. The cattelo is a hybrid obtained by cross-breeding cattle with buffalo. The result is, however, to all appearances a buffalo, except that the characteristic hump is not as prominent.
From Skadoo Point the course of the Colorado Eiver is plainly visible for 50 miles to Lee’s Ferry by the snake-like course of the deep gorge across the floor of the valley. The course of the Colorado Eiver in this valley is through Marble Canyon, and is said to be the most beautiful and most dangerous to uavigate of any section of the Grand Canyon. Some 300
falls and cataracts were encountered by Major Powell in his memorable trip. Marble Canyon begins at Lee’s Ferry and is 50 miles in length. Lee’s Ferry is the only place iu a distance of 500 miles along the Colorado Eiver where one may cross to the south side of the Eiver with a team or other’conveyance on a ferry boat.
ANCIENT RUINS AND RELICS.
In the dark, inaccessible recesses of the Grand Canyon, thousands of feet below the rim, are numerous cliff dwellings, ruins of an ancient and vanished race. Many of these dwellings are high up under the overhanging cliffs and bluffs and cannot be reached. From evidences left by the cliff dwellers, the canyons, plateaus, and deserts of the surrounding country undoubtedly supported a large population. How they managed to exist in this deep canyon where there is so little soil suited to cultivation is a mystery. This one feature of the Grand Canyon is well worth the time and expense required to see it. Years could be spent in the depths of the canyons in the exploration of these hidden and long-abandoned homes of a race of people of whom we know so little. Within 10 miles of Kanab, in Cottonwood Canyon and other canyons nearby, are well preserved ancient dwellings. The timbers used in this construction are still preserved. In Kanak, Johnson, Shinumo, and other canyons and gulches are many Indian paintings and hieroglyphics on the surfaces of boulders and rock ledges. Trips from Kanab or Fredonia to all these interesting-ruins and paintings may be made with comparative ease, either with team or on horseback, at almost any time of the year.
WILD GAME.
It is estimated that the Grand Canyon National Game Preserve contains between 10,000 and 15,000 deer. A great many of them can be seen in a trip across the Forest, and sometimes they may be approached close enough to be photographed. In the Grand Canyon below the
rim, and in the breaks, are both deer and mountain sheep. The sheep are never seen on the plateau and very rarely in the Canyon. There are also numerous mountain lions in all parts of the Forest. They are frequently seen prowling around through the timber, and thousands of deer are destroyed each year by these predatory animals. The Government now employs hunters to destroy them. There are a few timber wolves, while coyotes and bobcats are numerous. To the east of the Game Preserve, and immediately off the Forest in House Rock Yalley, are some 45 head of buffalo. They were shipped into the country in 1907 from the Goodnight Ranch in the Panhandle of Texas. They are increasing and bid fair to develop into a large herd. The home of these animals is easy of access over trails from all parts of the Forest.
One other interesting feature of protected, wild life on this Preserve is the white-tailed squirrel. It is said that the Kaibab Forest is the only place in the world where this peculiar animal is found. In size and color it is similar to the common grey squirrel of the eastern and southern states, the only dissimilarity being that this animal has a white bushy tail. The animals are numerous, and are always seen during the course of a trip across the Preserve or Forest. Like the deer, mountain sheep, quail, and grouse, they are protected by Federal laws and there is no open season for hunting them.
The destruction of predatory animals, such as timber wolves, mountain lions, coyotes, and bobcats, however, is not prohibited but encouraged. No better mountain lion hunting can be found anywhere in the west than on this Forest, and more satisfactory results may be had than is ^usually the case elsewhere with this kind of sport. The timber in this section is open, making it possible to ride rapidly through it in following the chase.
FOREST RESOURCES.
Practically 40 per cent of the area of the Kaibab Forest is heavily timbered with a dense stand of western yellow pine (Rinus ponderosa.) This timber occupies the plateau section of the Buckskin Mountains above an elevation of 7,000 feet, and the extent of the belt is practically 50 miles north and south by 20 miles east and west. The main body of timber is frequently intercepted by long narrow areas of open grass parks. It is estimated there are over 2 billion feet of merchantable timber 011 the Forest, of which 80 per cent or more is yellow pine. Considerable Douglas fii' of large size and excellent (quality is scattered over the south half of the area. From a logging and lumbering standpoint, this timbered belt contains fewer engineering difficulties than any similar belt of timber west of the Eocky Mountains.
FOREST FIRES.
If we wish to preserve these National re-sou toes, extreme care must be exercised by campers and tourists with camp fires, matches, piqies, cigar and cigarette stubs from which fire may originate. More than three-fourths of all forest fires are due to carelessness on the part of campers and other travelers. Many disastrous fires have been caused by a non-extinguished match, a cigarette or cigar stub, carelessly flipped into inflammable material. Camp fires should not be built against trees or rotten logs, or near large accumulations of debris. Rotten logs often smoulder though apparently the fire has been extinguished, when after a few hours it will break out again in flames.
The six rules, given on page 14, if observed closely by campers, will keep down the number of fires to a minimum.
A close observation of these rules will not only add to the pleasure and security of the tourists and campers while on the Forest, but will be of inestimable assistance to the local Forest officers.
There are very stringent laws covering forest fires caused by carelessness. Forest officers are empowered to arrest without warrant for the violations of these laws, when necessary.
ROADS AND TRAILS.
How to reach Kaibab National Forest and the Grand Canyon of' the Colorado.
The Grand Cauyon of the Colorado is accessible from the north with automobiles over the Grand Canyon Highway. This road is a trunk line from the north boundary of the Forest to the rim of the Canyon. The total length of the road is 56 miles; it is an excellent auto road having only a few grades that exceed 10 per cent.
The town of Kanab is the gateway to the Grand Canyon country and is 82 miles from the Canyon’s rim.
Tourists who visit the Canyon by way of Kanab, whether by train or by auto, usually pass through Salt Lake City. This city, besides being the capital of the State of Utah, is one of the most interesting cities in the west and is the objective point for many tourists. There are several auto routes from Salt Lake City to Kanab. There are two railroads, the Denver & Eio Grande with its terminus at Marysvale, Utah, a distance of apqn-oximately 135 miles from Kanab; and the San Pedro, Los Angeles & Salt Lake, with a station at Lund, Utah, a distance of approximately 145 miles from Kanab. From either Marysvale or Lund there is regular auto stage service running to within 75 miles of Kanab. Automobiles and other special conveyances also can be hired at a reasonable rate.
The traveler who wishes to approach the Grand Canyon from the south should take the Atchison, Topeko, & Santa Fe Railroad to Grand Canyon Station. From this point there are trails down into the Canyon and a cable crossing over the Colorado Eiver. The trip
over the trails can be made afoot or horseback. By prearrangement ivith guides at Fredonia or Kanab, parties will be met either at the Grand Cauyon Station or at El Tavor Hotel on the south side of the Canyon, or, if preferred, at the river’s edge, from Avhicli points they will be conducted to the north side of the Canyon through the Kaibab Forest, the Game Preserve, into House Rock Valley, and other places of interest.
The boundary line betAveen the States of Utah and Arizona is crossed 3 miles south of Kanab. That part of Arizona lying north of the Grand Canyon and the Colorado Eiver is knoAvn as the “Arizona strip.” SeA'en and one-half miles south of Kanab is the little town of Fredonia, Ariz., the only toAvu or settlement Avith a post-office in Arizona north of the Grand Canyon; a toAvn made famous by its isolation with reference to other sections of its State, and also by the honor of having recently had one of its citizens elected as Governor of the State of Arizona. This little toAvu is also the home of James L. OAvens, a notable character and plainsman of the old school from the Panhandle of Texas. He is a famous hunter and has had charge of many notable hunting parties an the Kaibab Forest at different times, including ex-President Roose-A'elt; and son.
One and one-half miles southeast of Fredonia, the road forks! The road to the left and east should be folloAved, as it is the Grand Canyon Highway. The Avatering places along the route from Kanab are Fredonia, Jacobs Lake, East Lake, Crain Lake, Big Park Spring, and Bright Angel Eanger Station. From Kanab to Jacobs Lake Ranger Station, the first Avatering place enroute, the distance is 37.8 miles. Parties Avith automobiles should take on 10 gallons of extra water before leaving Kanab or Fredonia.
FolloAving is a distance table showing the number of miles between points of interest near and on the Kaibab Forest, as Avell as betAveen the National Forest and industrial toAvns and cities and railroads in various parts of the country :

Plenty of gasoline should be taken on at Kanab, since there are at qn-esent no places on the Forest Avliere this commodity can be purchased. The smaller cars use from 12 to 15 gallons of gasoline in making the round trip from Kanab, a distance of 164 miles. Parties desiring to cross the Colorado Eiver to the railroad on the south side may secure guides at Kanab and Fredonia.
Bright Angel Trail leaves the rim of the Canyon 5 miles east of Bright Angel Point, the terminus of the Grand Canyon IlighAvay, and folloAvs the course of Bright Angel Creek, a distance of 15 miles to a suspension ferry crossing the Colorado Eiver. This ferry is for foot passengers only. Stock are made to SAvim the river. From the opposite side of the river the trail, after a short steeqa climb, follows the benches for about 5 miles and connects Avith the Cameron trail from El Tavor Hotel ou the south side of the Canyon. Bright Angel Trail is used extensively by tourists, and will continue to be used more each season as the roads of the country and tourist travel are developed.
From Bright Angel Eanger Station there are trails to all parts of the Forest and a secondary Avagon road around the rim of the Canyon both

Washington, D.C. :U.S. Geological Survey, 1899.; Base map overprinted in red.; To accompany: "Report. Public resolution no. 25, 55th Congress, 3d session"--Upper right margin.; [Sheet 1] [Base map, 1:3,600,000] -- [Sheet 2] Explorations in Alaska, Sushitna River and adjacent territory [1:625,000] -- [Sheet 3] Headwaters of Skwentna and Kuskokwim Rivers and vicinity of Katmai [1:625,000] -- [Sheet 4] Middle Kuskokwim River, and part of Bristol Bay [1:625,000] -- [Sheet 5] Lower Kuskokwim River, Kanektok River, and Togiak Bay [1:625,000] -- [Sheet 6] Alaska, route of military expedition ... from Knik Arm to Tanana River [1:625,000] -- [Sheet 7] Alaska, military expedition. Copper River and adjacent territory [1:376,000] -- [Sheet 8] Prince William Sound and vicinity [1:376,000] -- [Sheet 9] Explorations in Alaska ..., portions of Tanana and White Rivers [1:625,000].

Distances from Juneau to the Mouth of Porcupine River (Ft. Yukon.)
via Chilkoot Pass

Population, 40,000.	An 577,390 Square Miles.
Climate. The climate o' Air.is much milder than that of countries of the -came latitu on the east coast of America. That of tne Aleutian %j« is similar to that of the west coast of Scotland. In the t,-on Valley there are large plains and extensive marshes u:.dftrlaid by ice which never melts even in the hottest summer .yeather, and are covered with vegetation. The mildness of tr- ^’imate along ■ the west coast is largely due to the influence of the prevalence of the Japanese current. At Fort Yukon, Circle City, and at Dawson City in the North-West Territory, the average winter temperature is about 60° below.
“ In the interior of Alaska the winter sets in as early as September, when snowstorms may be expected in the mountains and passes. Heading during one of these storms is impossible, and the traveler who is overtaken by one of them is indeed fortunate if he escapes with his life. Snowstorms of great severity may occur in any month from September to May, inclusive. The changes of temperature from winter to summer are rapid, owing to the great increase in < the length of the day. In May the sun rises at about 3 A.M. and sets about g P. M. In June it rises about 1.30 in the morning and sets at 10.30, giving about twenty hours of I daylight and diffuse twilight the remainder of the time. The 1 mean summer temperature of the interior ranges between 6o° and 70°, according to elevation, being highest in the middle and lower Yukon valleys.”
Up to the present time seal-fishing has been the principal industry of Alaska ; tnv-.v.js little doubt however that the recent gold discoveries will lead to the development of other rpineral industries, and there is in the southern portion of the mainland as well as in the islands a profusion of forests, sufficient for the perfect development of all the natural industries. Dawson and Circle City are prominent among the new cities that have sprung up in the newly discovered gold fields.
Physical Geography. The territory has an extensive length of over 2,000 miles, and a width of 1,400 miles, with a coast line of over 8,000 miles, being double the coast line of the United States on the Atlantic and Pacific, exclusive of Alaska. The interior of Alaska has been but slightly explored, and knowledge of the country has been confined mainly to a few of the larger rivers, to the islands and to the coasts.THE YUKON ROUTE

The frontage of this great Slate on the Pacific Ocean corresponds closely to that of the territory lying between Charleston and Boston on the Atlantic- Coast.
_ j,.	Its area in square miles is 158,360, in acres,
Its size. 101,350,400. By reference to the small tinted map in the corner of this folder it will be seen to equal nine States within its boundary lines. Its Central Valley alone is about 420 miles long by an average width of 45 miles, and the flat floor of this valley contains 17,200 square miles.
_ m	^ There are two gi cat mountain ranges,
1 OpOgrap,,y. running north and south, the Sierra Nevada and the Coast Range, and an arm thrust across from east to west called the Tehachapi. About one-third of the State lies below this barrier. At the north, Mt. Shasta unites the'two principal ranges. There are a few overlapping spurs, and the Coast] Range is somewhat broken, and in places doubled, with: small valleys between, and there is much agricultural land between the ocean and the Coast mountains, but for the most part the great Central Valley holds the bulk of the farming land. It is called by-two names, the Sacrament^ and the San Joaquin, after the two rivers winch drain -it tfrom opposite ends.
The Tehachapi mountains are the dividing line between Central and Southern California. Below Point Concepcion the coast swings sharply eastward; the Coast Range breaks down in places and disappears, leaving the whole interior more open to the sea. For 150 miles an extensive plain faces tlye.pacific. It runs back from 15 to 50 miles, and gradually merges in foothills or rolling country. This is Southern California, the Sierra Madre and the San Bernardino mountains taking the place of the Sierra Nevada.
.	California offers the most attractive
Agriculture. farming region in the world. This comes from its wonderful climate and the fertility of its soil. Few parts of the globe produce so great a variety of crops. ! The products of New England, of the Middle West, of Aiuch of the South, of Italy, Spain, Persia, Greece and Sicily are grown here, and he is a poor farmer who cannot, wnen the growing season almost corresponds with the months of the year, find a crop which he can produce successfully and make it pay.
o *i j	Much of the surface in California is sedi-
Jy 1	.	mentary. The great valley has been silted
Conditions. Up j,y wash from the mountains, and is rich-as'tne valley of the Nile. There is great variety of soils as a whole, including gravel and clays, but,, save in the mountains, no clearing is to be done.
1 A great delta region is formed where Delta DandS. tqe streams which drain the valleys come together at the head of the Bay of San Francisco. Here are perhaps a million acres that are among the richest in the world, with the advantage of a genial climate, rail and water transportation and proximity to cities.
A Farmer’s	Tim State is an empire of the farmer,
,	and whether he tills the soil, or raises
Land.	stock, or runs a dairy, or grows fruit,
he finds a bountiful soil and a healthful climate, with no actual winter or rough weather to compel snug houses or expensive shelter for stock.
We enumerate here some of the exceptional products of California farms:

TL p j#*" Wheat and barley are grown exten-1 tie Lerec -s.. sively, both for hay and grain. Corn is not largely grown, chiefly because other crops have been found more profitable. In some sections of the State it does not do well, owing to the cool nights, but generally it grows luxuriantly, and with the breaking up of the great wheat ranches and the coming in of irrigation corn will take its rightful place as a crop.
This is the great forage crop of the State, -H-Ilaila. deep soil and mild climate furnishing the best possible conditions. It is cut from four to six times, then pastured a part of the winter. It is grown and sold directly, and grown and fed to stock.
Hops and Several counties find hops a profitable cul-y, ”	ture, and the quality superior. The markets
Deans.	0f wor]ci seek for California hops. The
vine is generally free from blight or insect pest.
Beans are grown largely in several sections, and special localities find such profit in beans that they are grown to the exclusion of other crops.
p ,	'This is a special crop in Southern California,
‘Celery. 1-qg peat jan(js ;n Orange County being devoted to it. It is shipped from the field in midwinter, and goes in special trains to the cities of the East. Much land in Central California is also producing celery, and large areas are adapted to it.
,	Along the Sacramento River and on the
Asparagus. ;sian(js 0f the San Joaquin, the culture of asparagus is a great industry. It is largely canned, and finds a market even in foreign countries.
Seeds.
California is becoming the great seed-hed of Eastern dealers in flower and vegetable seeds. The long seasons are favorable for fully ripening the seeds, and those you buy from the well-known houses are probably chiefly grown in this State. The vigor and fertility of the seeds grown here open the doors of trade in all lands. It is a fascinating industry for women, as is also the growing of bulbs. These are also shipped in great quantities.
■p .	In certain localities the orange is produced in
I* ruits. great quantities, as is also the fig. In both Central and Northern California these semi-tropical fruits grow as successfully as in the South. Prunes are grown extensively, and raisins equal the best imported. Apples require certain conditions, but in several localities reach so fine a quality as to be shipped to Europe each year in increasing quantities. Peaches and pears, as well as all the small fruits, grow in all sections, and the State is famous for the abundance and size and the superior flavor of its fruits. It is indeed the greatest fruit-growing region on earth.
c„„ar ■Roots There are in California nine sugar ¥ _	.	factories, and this indicates the large
ana r actories. area Up0n which sugar beets can be grown. Any land that will produce about 12 tons per acre of 15 per cent, saccharine matter, 80 per cent, fine, can be profitably used for this crop, the only limitation being distance from the factory. The yield is often more than 15 tons and the sugar content higher than 15 per cent. Truck This is an ideal land for the market gardener. P	In a large part of the State planting and har-
r arms. vesting goes on all the year, and something is always ready to be turned off in the market. The growing of cabbages and tomatoes for winter shipment is increasing, and nearly all vegetables find either a good local market or can be shipped to mountain States or to ports around the Pacific.
LIVE STOCK
Agriculture in California has not been greatly diversified, and there have been but few herds fed upon the farm.
Cattle raising has been left to the range, or to the great cattle ranches, but with advantages of climate and green feed which are unequaled, California yet does not produce all the dairy and beef cattle used and consumed within its borders. There is here a wide field for men who know how to raise stock, and room, too, for thoroughbred stock. Some, indeed, of the best stock is here, the advantages and attractions of the business in this climate leading a few men of means to indulge their taste for finely-bred cattle, so that the choicest animals which money could buy have been brought here.
Dairying'	Dairying is an attractive	and profitable
, Z .	industry, and irrigation is	greatly stimu-
ana Lrrazmg.	lating it by providing an	abundance of
green feed, but dairy products are still shipped in from other States. Alfalfa economizes the business of the dairyman, and the “green winter” enables stock to hoard themselves in the open. Root crops can be grown all the year, and shelter is needed only at intervals.
The amount of free pasturage in California is growing less every year, but ranges can be bought, and on these cattle, horses and sheep are bred. As the season advances, herds are moved to higher lands, by midsummer finding the elevated tablelands and mountain meadows where the grass keeps green.
Sheen and '^'ie w0°l has declined from the days p *	of unlimited ranges, but is still consider-
Ltoats.	able. Not much attention is given to
other than wool-producing merinos, and the mutton breeds would be profitable in the hands of the small farmer in many sections.
There are large and generous places in the foothills for the Angora goat, and every part of the little animal—flesh, skin and fleece—is salable. For this hardy animal the brushy hills furnish good grazing ground. tt	The new-comer will find hogs profitable. Large
nogs. regions still furnish an “acorn harvest,” and “bands” of porkers are found among the oaks. Indian corn can he grown in most of the counties, and for the man who wants to raise corn and hogs there is a large field. Besides, the Jiog is a lover of alfalfa and a natural adjunct of the dairy.
Old-Stvle There is plenty of room for the man who ^	^ would be homesick without a farm of 160
* irms" acres or more and who wishes to farm in California as he did in the Middle West. These men are needed. The State wants men who will raise what is consumed—and the men who will produce broad fields of corn and pumpkins, keep sheep and hogs and fine cattle, will find success waiting upon their endeavor.
. IRRIGATION
California is not an arid State, but the rainfall is confined to the so-called winter months and the summers are absolutely dry. The precipitation over a large area is generally adequate for the production of crops, but there are other sections where it is too slight for successful general farming.
Southern California was the first section of the State to utilize irrigation, being devoted largely to orange growing. Expensive systems being provided for orange groves, other crops came naturally under the irrigating ditch. The rapid development of the Southern counties was due to irrigation more than to any other feature.
Fruit growing generally requires irrigation. Alfalfa, too, requires much moisture, and where this is systematically supplied the long, warm summers insure a growth so rapid that the harvest is almost continuous.

Advantages of Irrigation.
and beyond this
Government has authorized the expenditure of a large sum at Orland, in the upper Sacramento Valley, the initial step, it is believed, in a comprehensive system which shall include the whole Valley and serve to control the flood waters of the river.
The chief rivers of the State are the Sacramento, Feather, American, Mokelumne, Tuolumne, San Joaquin, Kings, Kern and Tule. On the coast, the Salinas, Santa Ana, Santa Clara, Pajaro and others are large streams for half the year. Water is ample from many such sources, while a considerable supply comes from artesian and other wells. Irrigation systems are an investment for the sake of revenue from the sale of water, or they are provided for by forming districts and issuing bonds. The charge per acre for the necessary water is but a slight tax.
Where water is available in streams or wells, but below the level of the land, pumps are used, being driven by gasoline engines, electricity or windmills. This method of irrigation is independent, not expensive, and is widely used.
The winter rainfall and mountain snowfall is still important. The hidden fountains are filled for summer needs, is felt no concern about the weather. Dependent on the clouds, the farmer elsewhere must take the rain when it comes, not when it is wanted always, or when it will be of most benefit to his crop. It may come at most inopportune times, and it may not come when drought means great loss. Probably more time is lost in a country having summer rains, in postponing necessary work because of rain and waiting for the ground to become tillable, than it takes in an irrigated country to apply water, and the injury to products by unseasonable rains will nearly, if not quite, equal the cost of purchased water.
HORTICULTURE
In its phenomenal production of fruit, California has attracted as wide attention as it did in the days of gold, even if the record has not been so dazzling. In its fresh or its cured state, California fruit is now known throughout the civilized world. It was not until the ’70’s that fruit-growing became a commercial factor, and the State rapidly broke out in orchards.
Scientific	-*-n *ate years care *ias ^een s>ven t0
a . .	selection of varieties, and better judgment
Agriculture. usecj ;n determining vital questions of soil, exposure and elevation necessary to develop the best of each variety. In the matter of handling and marketing fruit there is much yet to be learned, but, upon the whole, the skill of the growers is evident, and the quality of the fruit has made a world-wide market. Fruit-growing is to-day the distinctive industry of California, and is steadily growing and the market expanding.
Deciduous	1905 California shipped 8,071 carloads
t-,	.	of fresh fruit, ranging from Mexico to
rruits.	Canada, and reaching also England, Scot-
land and Germany. The shipment is a little less for 1906, but year by year ranges from 6,000 to 8,000 carloads.
Citrus These are produced in all parts of agricul-•p .	tural California, hut commercially the product
rruits. js much larger in the Southern counties. The planting of orange and lemon groves north of the Tehachapi Mountains is very recent, hut the area of good soil is very large, and along the foothills of the Sierras the climate is as well adapted as anywhere in the South. The orange district p. acr is more than 650 miles long. In the great Central Vatrey foothill^ ocean, the dry air, the large agg,;^

during the season, and the fine soil produces exceedingly fine fruit, of splendid color and flavor, and insures the very earliest ripening.
The total shipments for the State for 1906-7 are about 30,000 carloads.
Dried and California canned fruits are known . everywhere, and are in great demand. Canned Fruit. gjje pacjc for 1906 ;s reported at 2,700,-000 cases. The output of dried fruits exceeds 75,800,000 pounds, and this does not include prunes nor raisins. Prunes alone reach 180,000,000 pounds, and raisins 80,000,-000 more. Both the production of prunes and raisins are specialized, the Santa Clara-. Valley being the most important center of the prune; and Fresno County of the raisin grape, but both are grdwn quite extensively in other sections. Peaches, pears, cherries, figs, apricots, plums, olives and apples are grown in large quantities.
The direct commercial return is very great, and the intelligent fruit-grower in California finds it a profitable and attractive business, but the industrial side is It provides occupation for thousands of wage-earners, for it is an immense industry.
Many holdings are small, or a part of the. general plan of the farm and the work of preparing fruit is done by members of the family. The income is mostly net, and ten acres of fruit makes a comfortable living for many a family.
Room for There are yet thousands of acres of land _ ,	as well adapted to fruit culture as most, of
Utners.	now planted, and it awaits the coming
of industrious and thrifty settlers. Our fruit-growing districts have the busiest towns, the handsomest rural improvements, the largest assessment rolls and ard most attractive to home-seekers.	L—..
VITICULTURE
As a wine-producing State, California ranks first, producing more than 60 per cent, of all the wine made in this country.
The principal wine grapes are the Zinfandel, Mission, Reisling and Mataro; table and raisin grapes are also used for wine making.
The industry is a large one, and represents an immense capital. Besides direct investment in vineyards, winemakers buy grapes by the ton, and many make a business of producing grapes for the wineries, which command about $15 per ton.
Table	Pro<fuct:'on °f the table grape is a large
„	business in many localities. The Flame Tokay,
Crapes. ]j]ac]c Hamburg, Purple Damascus, and Emperor are favorites. The demand during the last few years has outrun production, and a few acres provide a good income.
Raisin	A large industry is the production of raisins.
„	Probably 70.000 acres are devoted to this
Crapes. business, and the acreage is expanding. The raisin grape is the Muscat of Alexandria, but the Malaga, a white grape, is also used. Two seedless varieties correspond with the so-called Zante “currants,” imported from Greece. Fresno, Kings, Madera and Tulare Counties, in the San Joaquin Valley are the chief centers of raisin production, but in many other localities these vines do equally well. So excellent is the cured product that it has fairly taken away the market from the Spanish or imported raisin.
In the San Joaquin Valley, vineyards range from five' to 1,000 acres, and are kept like a garden. The vines are pruned low., and cover most of the ground. The industry
is one which employs all members of the family down nearly to the baby.

MINING
It is carelessly thought that the gold mining days ov California are past, but the yield for 1905 is reported as; $19,197,043, an increase oi nearly $3,000,000 over ,1903.- This is due largely to gold dredging in the valleys, where gold-bearing rivers debouch. The golden sands and gravel are washed at a cost of a few cents per cubic yard and a good paying margin is left. There are vast reserves of this land, and millions in future years will he prdduced by dredging alone. The acreage is practically unlimited.
The Mother Lode will yield millions yet from! what are now mere prospect holes, and those best informed believe that mines will yet be discovered richer than any now being worked.

PP 17,000,000 pounds, but the discovery within Mines. tjje year J9Q5 0f jnimense deposits of the red metal is attracting great attention. Millions are being expended by the smelting combine in the construction of a great plant on the shores of the Bay of San Francisco, and it is expected that the northern countie? will yield large supplies of copper.

Borax, soda, glass sand, marble, clays for brick and pottery, platinum, lead, limestone, gypsum, asbestos, cement, coal, etc., are found in various parts of the State, California producing over seventy-five known minerals, of which forty-five have commercial value.
There is here a large field for the prospector, the natural wealth of the vast region being but imperfectly known.

The frontage of this great Slate on the Pacific Ocean corresponds closely to that of the territory lying between Charleston and Boston on the Atlantic- Coast.
_ j,.	Its area in square miles is 158,360, in acres,
Its size. 101,350,400. By reference to the small tinted map in the corner of this folder it will be seen to equal nine States within its boundary lines. Its Central Valley alone is about 420 miles long by an average width of 45 miles, and the flat floor of this valley contains 17,200 square miles.
_ m	^ There are two gi cat mountain ranges,
1 OpOgrap,,y. running north and south, the Sierra Nevada and the Coast Range, and an arm thrust across from east to west called the Tehachapi. About one-third of the State lies below this barrier. At the north, Mt. Shasta unites the'two principal ranges. There are a few overlapping spurs, and the Coast] Range is somewhat broken, and in places doubled, with: small valleys between, and there is much agricultural land between the ocean and the Coast mountains, but for the most part the great Central Valley holds the bulk of the farming land. It is called by-two names, the Sacrament^ and the San Joaquin, after the two rivers winch drain -it tfrom opposite ends.
The Tehachapi mountains are the dividing line between Central and Southern California. Below Point Concepcion the coast swings sharply eastward; the Coast Range breaks down in places and disappears, leaving the whole interior more open to the sea. For 150 miles an extensive plain faces tlye.pacific. It runs back from 15 to 50 miles, and gradually merges in foothills or rolling country. This is Southern California, the Sierra Madre and the San Bernardino mountains taking the place of the Sierra Nevada.
.	California offers the most attractive
Agriculture. farming region in the world. This comes from its wonderful climate and the fertility of its soil. Few parts of the globe produce so great a variety of crops. ! The products of New England, of the Middle West, of Aiuch of the South, of Italy, Spain, Persia, Greece and Sicily are grown here, and he is a poor farmer who cannot, wnen the growing season almost corresponds with the months of the year, find a crop which he can produce successfully and make it pay.

Jy 1	.	mentary. The great valley has been silted
Conditions. Up j,y wash from the mountains, and is rich-as'tne valley of the Nile. There is great variety of soils as a whole, including gravel and clays, but,, save in the mountains, no clearing is to be done.
1 A great delta region is formed where Delta DandS. tqe streams which drain the valleys come together at the head of the Bay of San Francisco. Here are perhaps a million acres that are among the richest in the world, with the advantage of a genial climate, rail and water transportation and proximity to cities.
A Farmer’s	Tim State is an empire of the farmer,
,	and whether he tills the soil, or raises
Land.	stock, or runs a dairy, or grows fruit,
he finds a bountiful soil and a healthful climate, with no actual winter or rough weather to compel snug houses or expensive shelter for stock.
We enumerate here some of the exceptional products of California farms:

TL p j#*" Wheat and barley are grown exten-1 tie Lerec -s.. sively, both for hay and grain. Corn is not largely grown, chiefly because other crops have been found more profitable. In some sections of the State it does not do well, owing to the cool nights, but generally it grows luxuriantly, and with the breaking up of the great wheat ranches and the coming in of irrigation corn will take its rightful place as a crop.
This is the great forage crop of the State, -H-Ilaila. deep soil and mild climate furnishing the best possible conditions. It is cut from four to six times, then pastured a part of the winter. It is grown and sold directly, and grown and fed to stock.
Hops and Several counties find hops a profitable cul-y, ”	ture, and the quality superior. The markets
Deans.	0f wor]ci seek for California hops. The
vine is generally free from blight or insect pest.
Beans are grown largely in several sections, and special localities find such profit in beans that they are grown to the exclusion of other crops.
p ,	'This is a special crop in Southern California,
‘Celery. 1-qg peat jan(js ;n Orange County being devoted to it. It is shipped from the field in midwinter, and goes in special trains to the cities of the East. Much land in Central California is also producing celery, and large areas are adapted to it.
,	Along the Sacramento River and on the
Asparagus. ;sian(js 0f the San Joaquin, the culture of asparagus is a great industry. It is largely canned, and finds a market even in foreign countries.
Seeds.
California is becoming the great seed-hed of Eastern dealers in flower and vegetable seeds. The long seasons are favorable for fully ripening the seeds, and those you buy from the well-known houses are probably chiefly grown in this State. The vigor and fertility of the seeds grown here open the doors of trade in all lands. It is a fascinating industry for women, as is also the growing of bulbs. These are also shipped in great quantities.
■p .	In certain localities the orange is produced in
I* ruits. great quantities, as is also the fig. In both Central and Northern California these semi-tropical fruits grow as successfully as in the South. Prunes are grown extensively, and raisins equal the best imported. Apples require certain conditions, but in several localities reach so fine a quality as to be shipped to Europe each year in increasing quantities. Peaches and pears, as well as all the small fruits, grow in all sections, and the State is famous for the abundance and size and the superior flavor of its fruits. It is indeed the greatest fruit-growing region on earth.
c„„ar ■Roots There are in California nine sugar ¥ _	.	factories, and this indicates the large
ana r actories. area Up0n which sugar beets can be grown. Any land that will produce about 12 tons per acre of 15 per cent, saccharine matter, 80 per cent, fine, can be profitably used for this crop, the only limitation being distance from the factory. The yield is often more than 15 tons and the sugar content higher than 15 per cent. Truck This is an ideal land for the market gardener. P	In a large part of the State planting and har-
r arms. vesting goes on all the year, and something is always ready to be turned off in the market. The growing of cabbages and tomatoes for winter shipment is increasing, and nearly all vegetables find either a good local market or can be shipped to mountain States or to ports around the Pacific.
LIVE STOCK
Agriculture in California has not been greatly diversified, and there have been but few herds fed upon the farm.
Cattle raising has been left to the range, or to the great cattle ranches, but with advantages of climate and green feed which are unequaled, California yet does not produce all the dairy and beef cattle used and consumed within its borders. There is here a wide field for men who know how to raise stock, and room, too, for thoroughbred stock. Some, indeed, of the best stock is here, the advantages and attractions of the business in this climate leading a few men of means to indulge their taste for finely-bred cattle, so that the choicest animals which money could buy have been brought here.
Dairying'	Dairying is an attractive	and profitable
, Z .	industry, and irrigation is	greatly stimu-
ana Lrrazmg.	lating it by providing an	abundance of
green feed, but dairy products are still shipped in from other States. Alfalfa economizes the business of the dairyman, and the “green winter” enables stock to hoard themselves in the open. Root crops can be grown all the year, and shelter is needed only at intervals.
The amount of free pasturage in California is growing less every year, but ranges can be bought, and on these cattle, horses and sheep are bred. As the season advances, herds are moved to higher lands, by midsummer finding the elevated tablelands and mountain meadows where the grass keeps green.
Sheen and '^'ie w0°l has declined from the days p *	of unlimited ranges, but is still consider-
Ltoats.	able. Not much attention is given to
other than wool-producing merinos, and the mutton breeds would be profitable in the hands of the small farmer in many sections.
There are large and generous places in the foothills for the Angora goat, and every part of the little animal—flesh, skin and fleece—is salable. For this hardy animal the brushy hills furnish good grazing ground. tt	The new-comer will find hogs profitable. Large
nogs. regions still furnish an “acorn harvest,” and “bands” of porkers are found among the oaks. Indian corn can he grown in most of the counties, and for the man who wants to raise corn and hogs there is a large field. Besides, the Jiog is a lover of alfalfa and a natural adjunct of the dairy.
Old-Stvle There is plenty of room for the man who ^	^ would be homesick without a farm of 160
* irms" acres or more and who wishes to farm in California as he did in the Middle West. These men are needed. The State wants men who will raise what is consumed—and the men who will produce broad fields of corn and pumpkins, keep sheep and hogs and fine cattle, will find success waiting upon their endeavor.
. IRRIGATION
California is not an arid State, but the rainfall is confined to the so-called winter months and the summers are absolutely dry. The precipitation over a large area is generally adequate for the production of crops, but there are other sections where it is too slight for successful general farming.
Southern California was the first section of the State to utilize irrigation, being devoted largely to orange growing. Expensive systems being provided for orange groves, other crops came naturally under the irrigating ditch. The rapid development of the Southern counties was due to irrigation more than to any other feature.
Fruit growing generally requires irrigation. Alfalfa, too, requires much moisture, and where this is systematically supplied the long, warm summers insure a growth so rapid that the harvest is almost continuous.

Advantages of Irrigation.
and beyond this
Government has authorized the expenditure of a large sum at Orland, in the upper Sacramento Valley, the initial step, it is believed, in a comprehensive system which shall include the whole Valley and serve to control the flood waters of the river.
The chief rivers of the State are the Sacramento, Feather, American, Mokelumne, Tuolumne, San Joaquin, Kings, Kern and Tule. On the coast, the Salinas, Santa Ana, Santa Clara, Pajaro and others are large streams for half the year. Water is ample from many such sources, while a considerable supply comes from artesian and other wells. Irrigation systems are an investment for the sake of revenue from the sale of water, or they are provided for by forming districts and issuing bonds. The charge per acre for the necessary water is but a slight tax.
Where water is available in streams or wells, but below the level of the land, pumps are used, being driven by gasoline engines, electricity or windmills. This method of irrigation is independent, not expensive, and is widely used.
The winter rainfall and mountain snowfall is still important. The hidden fountains are filled for summer needs, is felt no concern about the weather. Dependent on the clouds, the farmer elsewhere must take the rain when it comes, not when it is wanted always, or when it will be of most benefit to his crop. It may come at most inopportune times, and it may not come when drought means great loss. Probably more time is lost in a country having summer rains, in postponing necessary work because of rain and waiting for the ground to become tillable, than it takes in an irrigated country to apply water, and the injury to products by unseasonable rains will nearly, if not quite, equal the cost of purchased water.
HORTICULTURE
In its phenomenal production of fruit, California has attracted as wide attention as it did in the days of gold, even if the record has not been so dazzling. In its fresh or its cured state, California fruit is now known throughout the civilized world. It was not until the ’70’s that fruit-growing became a commercial factor, and the State rapidly broke out in orchards.

Agriculture. usecj ;n determining vital questions of soil, exposure and elevation necessary to develop the best of each variety. In the matter of handling and marketing fruit there is much yet to be learned, but, upon the whole, the skill of the growers is evident, and the quality of the fruit has made a world-wide market. Fruit-growing is to-day the distinctive industry of California, and is steadily growing and the market expanding.

The total shipments for the State for 1906-7 are about 30,000 carloads.
Dried and California canned fruits are known . everywhere, and are in great demand. Canned Fruit. gjje pacjc for 1906 ;s reported at 2,700,-000 cases. The output of dried fruits exceeds 75,800,000 pounds, and this does not include prunes nor raisins. Prunes alone reach 180,000,000 pounds, and raisins 80,000,-000 more. Both the production of prunes and raisins are specialized, the Santa Clara-. Valley being the most important center of the prune; and Fresno County of the raisin grape, but both are grdwn quite extensively in other sections. Peaches, pears, cherries, figs, apricots, plums, olives and apples are grown in large quantities.
The direct commercial return is very great, and the intelligent fruit-grower in California finds it a profitable and attractive business, but the industrial side is It provides occupation for thousands of wage-earners, for it is an immense industry.
Many holdings are small, or a part of the. general plan of the farm and the work of preparing fruit is done by members of the family. The income is mostly net, and ten acres of fruit makes a comfortable living for many a family.

of industrious and thrifty settlers. Our fruit-growing districts have the busiest towns, the handsomest rural improvements, the largest assessment rolls and ard most attractive to home-seekers.	L—..
VITICULTURE
As a wine-producing State, California ranks first, producing more than 60 per cent, of all the wine made in this country.
The principal wine grapes are the Zinfandel, Mission, Reisling and Mataro; table and raisin grapes are also used for wine making.
The industry is a large one, and represents an immense capital. Besides direct investment in vineyards, winemakers buy grapes by the ton, and many make a business of producing grapes for the wineries, which command about $15 per ton.
Table	Pro<fuct:'on °f the table grape is a large
„	business in many localities. The Flame Tokay,
Crapes. ]j]ac]c Hamburg, Purple Damascus, and Emperor are favorites. The demand during the last few years has outrun production, and a few acres provide a good income.
Raisin	A large industry is the production of raisins.
„	Probably 70.000 acres are devoted to this
Crapes. business, and the acreage is expanding. The raisin grape is the Muscat of Alexandria, but the Malaga, a white grape, is also used. Two seedless varieties correspond with the so-called Zante “currants,” imported from Greece. Fresno, Kings, Madera and Tulare Counties, in the San Joaquin Valley are the chief centers of raisin production, but in many other localities these vines do equally well. So excellent is the cured product that it has fairly taken away the market from the Spanish or imported raisin.
In the San Joaquin Valley, vineyards range from five' to 1,000 acres, and are kept like a garden. The vines are pruned low., and cover most of the ground. The industry
is one which employs all members of the family down nearly to the baby.

MINING
It is carelessly thought that the gold mining days ov California are past, but the yield for 1905 is reported as; $19,197,043, an increase oi nearly $3,000,000 over ,1903.- This is due largely to gold dredging in the valleys, where gold-bearing rivers debouch. The golden sands and gravel are washed at a cost of a few cents per cubic yard and a good paying margin is left. There are vast reserves of this land, and millions in future years will he prdduced by dredging alone. The acreage is practically unlimited.
The Mother Lode will yield millions yet from! what are now mere prospect holes, and those best informed believe that mines will yet be discovered richer than any now being worked.

Millions are being expended by the smelting combine in the construction of a great plant on the shores of the Bay of San Francisco, and it is expected that the northern countie? will yield large supplies of copper.

Other Minerals, about $1,500,000 annually. Borax, soda, glass sand, marble, clays for brick and pottery, platinum, lead, limestone, gypsum, asbestos, cement, coal, etc., are found in various parts of the State, California producing over seventy-five known minerals, of which forty-five have commercial value.
There is here a large field for the prospector, the natural wealth of the vast region being but imperfectly known.
PETROLEUM IN CALIFORNIA

transcription:
THE STORY OF THE YOSEMITE VALLEY
By F. E. Mattlies
A BIRD’S-EYE VIEW OF THE VALLEY
If you should start from San Francisco in an airplane and fly due east you would pass first over the wooded crests of the Coast Ranges; next over the broad, level expanse of the Great Valley of California, checkered with irrigated fields, vineyards, and orchards; and then, after a flight of about a hundred miles, you would come to a huge mountain barrier, stretching north and south at right angles to your course and rising in a long, gradual slope to a resplendent row of snow-flecked peaks. This is the Sierra Nevada, the longest, the highest, and the grandest single mountain range in the United States.
Deeply carved in its western flank, about midway between the torrid foothills and the wintry summits, in the genial middle zone of majestic forests, you would discover the Yosemite Valley, a chasm renowned the world over for its towering cliffs, its stately trees, and its delightful climate, but, above all, for its sublime waterfalls.

Figure 1.—Bird’s-e
R F Ribbon Fall.
EC El Capitan.
E P Eagle Peak.
Y F Yosemite Falls.
R Royal Arches.
W Washington Column. M L Mirror Lake.
T C Tenaya Canyon.
e view of Yosemite Sierra bkiond
N D North Dome.
B D Basket Dome.
M W Mount Watkins.
C Clouds Rest.
H D Half Dome.
L Mount Lyell.
L Y Little Yosemite.
L C Liberty Cap.
i’AILEY AND T.HE HIGH
B Mount Broderick. G Glacier Point.
S D Sentinel Dome.
S R Sentinel Rock.
C R Cathedral Rocks. B V Bridalveil Fall.
Y V Yosemite Village M R Merced River.
As you fly over the valley you may at first be surprised to find that it is no larger. It measures only 7 miles in length and 1 mile in width and is really but a widened part of a narrow canyon that furrows the range from crest to base, the canyon of Merced River. Indeed, the valley is only one of a great many features—though by far the most wonderful—of the Yosemite National Park, which embraces a part of the western flank of the Sierra Nevada, almost as large as the State of Rhode Island, that is studded with peaks, domes, and spires and sculptured by valleys, gorges, and canyons. Among the canyons is the Grand Canyon of Tuolumne River, which lies 12 miles north of the Merced Canyon and parallel to it and which also has a Yosemite like widened part—the beautiful Hetch Hetchy Valley.
A SCENE OP WORLD-WIDE FAME
But when finally you descend into the Yosemite you at once perceive the reason for its world wide fame. No other valley is so remarkably fashioned; no other valley holds within so small a compass so astounding a wealth of striking and distinctive scenic features. As a whole, it is a broad rock-hewn trough with parallel sides, boldly sculptured and ornamented with silvery cataracts. The level floor, whose groves and meadows afford ideal places for camping and other forms of recreation, lies 4,000 leet above the sea, and the forested uplands on either side rise 3,000 to 4,000 feet higher.
As you look eastward up the valley from its lower end your eye is at once attracted by the sheer profile of El Capitan (fig. 7), the most majestic cliff in the Yosemite and perhaps in the world. It projects from the north wall, arid its top rises 3,000 feet above the valley floor. Directly opposite stand the three Cathedral Rocks, of nearly equal height, which form the only promontory that juts far out into the valley. From the west end of this promontory leaps Bridalveil Fall, 620 feet high, its spray suffused with the glory of the rainbow.
Eastward beyond El Capitan the valley abruptly regains its full width, and you see in an embayment on the right the two Cathedral Spires, the frailest rock shafts in the valley. On the left are the Three Brothers, whose gabled summits rise one above another, all built on the same angle, as if designed by an architect. The highest, known as Eagle Peak, rises 3,800 feet above the valley. Opposite them stands Sentinel Rock, a finely modeled obelisk with a pointed top.
A mile farther up the valley, on the north side, just below Yosemite Village, the main tourist center of the park, are the Yosemite Falls (fig. 2), booming amid clouds of pearly mist, most glorious of all the cataracts in the valley. The upper fall, 1,430 feet high, would alone make any valley famous; it is the highest unbroken
leap of water on the continent, perhaps the highest in the world. The lower fall, which descends 320 feet, seems insignificant in comparison, yet it is twice as high as Niagara. The entire chain of falls and cascades has a height of 2,565 feet.
Farther up, on the north side, are the Royal Arches, sculptured one within another in an inclined rock wall that rises to a height of 1,500 feet. An enormous natural pillar, the Washington Column, flanks them on the right, and above them rises a smoothly curving, helmet-shaped boss of granite called North Dome. Facing the Royal Arches stands Glacier Point, a high promontory that has become a veritable Mecca for tourists by reason of its matchless view and its unique overhanging rock, below which the cliffs fall off sheer 3,200 feet.
The head of the valley is squared off by another rock wall, above which, planted as on a pedestal, stands Half Dome, the most colossal and most strangely modeled rock monument in the Sierra Nevada, smoothly rounded on three sides and cut down sheer on the fourth. Though formerly inaccessible, it may now be easily scaled with the aid of steel cables so hung as to serve as handrails.
From the summit of Half Dome, 4,850 feet above the valley, you look down, on the south side, into the Little Yosemite, a broad-floored, cliff-girt valley shaped like the Yosemite, though much smaller. It stands 2,000 feet above the main valley, and from its portal, guarded by Liberty Cap, the Merced descends by a cyclopean stairway, making two magnificent cataracts, Nevada Fall, 594 feet high, and Vernal Fall, 317 feet high. On the north side of Half Dome you look down into Tenaya Canyon, a chasm as profound as the Yosemite itself, yet the pathway of only a small brook. Almost directly under Half Dome, at the mouth of the canyon, lies romantic Mirror Lake. To the northeast Clouds Rest, the loftiest summit in the vicinity of the valley, rises 9,929 feet above the sea, and beyond spreads the vast panorama of the High Sierra, its jagged peaks culminating in ice-covered Mount Lyell at a height of 13,090 feet.
And now, filled with wonder at the marvels of this stupendous scene, you may ask: How was all this created f By what strange forces has the Yosemite been fashioned, and through what happy circumstances has it become endowed with so much charm and grandeur?
A STORY THAT BEGAN MILLIONS OP YEARS AGO
This, then, is the story of the Yosemite: Millions of years ago, about the middle of what geologists call the Tertiary period, all the country between the Pacific coast and the Rocky Mountains began to bulge up as a result of disturbances in the interior of the earth. The movement was slow and intermittent, yet it caused the crust of the earth locally to warp and bend, so as to form low mountain ranges and intermediate plains. In some places long fractures, or “faults,” were produced, and on these faults the adjoining blocks of the crust slipped past each other, the mountain blocks rising, the valley blocks
Figure 2.—Yosemite Falls, from the banks of Merced River
The upper fall, 1.480 feet in height, is probably the highest fall of its kind in the world. The lower fall is 820 feet high, and the total descent of the water from the brink of the upland to the floor of the valley is 2,565 feet. The lower fall as seen above is three-fourths of a mile from the camera; the upper fall is nearly 1J miles distant. Photograph by Pillsbury Picture Co.
sinking or remaining low. Such movements took place notably along the line of faults delimiting the east side of that huge crustal block, 400 miles long and 80 miles broad, which was destined to become the Sierra Nevada.
At first the Sierra block had only moderate height and a gentle westward slant, but in the later half of the Tertiary period it was raised, together with the country to the east, several thousand feet
higher, and its slant was correspondingly steepened. Finally, about the dawn of the Quaternary period—the last great division of geologic time, which has embraced the Ice Age and witnessed the rise of man—the Sierra block was still more strongly tilted, and its eastern edge was lifted to its present great height. Owens Valley and the other basins to the east sank down, and thus the range came to stand out as it does to-day, with an abrupt eastern front and a long western slope.
One effect of the tilting was, naturally, to rearrange the waters on the Sierra block. The main streams originally drained in diverse directions, but when the slant became sufficiently steep, a new system of rivers was formed that flowed westward, roughly parallel to one another, down the slope. The Merced was one of these new rivers. (See fig. 3.)
ORIGIN OP HANGING VALLEYS AND CASCADES The side streams were at first unable to trench as rapidly as the Merced. They had smaller volume and therefore less cutting power, and a number of them were handicapped by following courses that lay at right angles to the general course of the river and therefore at right angles to the slope of the Sierra block. These streams were not steepened by the tilting and continued to flow as leisurely as before. As the river cut its gorge deeper and deeper, therefore, the side valleys remained “hanging” at greater and greater heights. But later, as the master stream’s gradient became flatter and its cutting power waned, most of the side streams by degrees “caught up” with its trenching and the hanging valleys were cut down—all but a few in the Yosemite region that were underlain by very resistant massive granite. These few remained almost untouched, and so, at the end of
now produces the great Yosemite Falls, then made a broken cascade 600 feet high; Bridalveil Creek and Sentinel Creek each plunged down 900 feet; Meadow Brook 1,200 feet; Ribbon Creek 1,400 feet.
The last and greatest uplift of the Sierra Nevada, which occurred about the beginning of the Quaternary period, again accelerated the Merced to the swiftness of a mountain torrent—indeed, it gave that stream greater velocity and cutting power than it had ever possessed. What is more, the greatly increased height of the range brought with it a marked change in climate. Deep snows fell on the crest in winter, and the rapid melting of these snows in spring produced freshets of tremendous volume and correspondingly great destructive power. Thus the river again intrenched itself and with greater rapidity than before carved a new inner gorge, producing a “three-story canyon” such as is outlined in Figure 5. In this new inner
VIEW EASTWARD UP THE VALLEY FROM THE FOOT OF THE THREE BROTHERS
In the center are the Royal Arches and the Washington Column; on the left is North Dome; on the right are the cliffs under Glacier Point. In the background are Clouds Rest and Half Dome, overlooking
the abyss of Tenaya Canyon. Photograph by J. K. Hillers
In the long period of quiet that followed the earlier tiltings the Merced fashioned for itself a broad, level valley, through which it wound sluggishly in serpentine meanders. The valley was flanked as far up as the site of the present Yosemite chasm by rolling hills and occasional ridges a few hundred to a thousand feet in height, all covered with luxuriant semitropical vegetation. The rounded summit of El Capitan was one of the rolling hills ; it rose about 900 feet above the Merced. Toward the headwaters of the river the land was more mountainous, but the region as a whole still lay near sea level.
The great uplift of late Tertiary time, which raised the Sierra block to a height of several thousand feet, affected the behavior of the Merced profoundly. The course of the stream now being much steeper than before, its flow became swift and powerful, and, with the sand, gravel, and boulders that it swept along, it began vigorously to scour and deepen its bed. As time went on it cut in the broad floor of its old valley a narrow, steep-walled gorge—a “gorge within a valley.” Although the river cut ever more slowly as its gradient became flatter, near the end of the Tertiary period it had intrenched itself almost a thousand feet. By that time, however, the gorge, through the crumbling of its walls, had been transformed into a valley with sloping sides, and so the river lay at the bottom of a “valley within a valley ”—or “two-story valley.” (See fig. 4.)
Tertiary time, the Yosemite was left with several hanging side valleys from whose lips poured foaming cascades. Yosemite Creek, which
Figure 3.—Generalized diagram of part of tilted Sierra block
The break, or “fault,” that separates it from the next block to the east is shown by a heavy line, and the directions in which the blocks have slipped past each other are shown by arrows. The height and slant of the Sierra block are much exaggerated. In front of the range is a strip of the Great Valley of California, which is underlain by many layers of sand and silt washed down by streams. At the back of the range is a strip of Owens Valley, likewise covered with sediment. The main rivers on the Sierra block have arranged themselves roughly parallel to one another, in the direction of the western slope, but their lesser tributaries continue to be guided by the irregularities on the surface and flow in diverse directions. The main rivers, having been accelerated by the tilting, have carved deep canyons, but many of their tributaries, and especially those that flow at right angles to the direction of the tilting, have not yet intrenched themselves and still drop into the canyons from “hanging valleys.” The conditions shown are those that prevailed for some time after the first great uplift mentioned in the text
gorge the river still flows from the lower end of the Yosemite Valley to the foothills. At El Portal, the main gate to Yosemite National Park, the gorge attains its greatest depth—about 2,000 feet—and the three-story canyon as a whole has a depth of about 3,500 feet.
As happened after the preceding uplift, so after the last, the side streams, and especially those running at right angles to the direction of the tilting, were unable to trench as rapidly as the master stream. And so the Yosemite, which already possessed one set of hanging valleys, acquired a second, lower set. To this lower set belong the valleys of Indian Creek and Illilouette Creek. Both of them, as well as some of the hanging side valleys of the lower Merced Canyon, are still well preserved, although they are underlain by less resistant rocks than the older and higher hanging valleys of the region. Indeed, so short a time, in a geologic sense, has elapsed since the last uplift that only a few of the more favorably situated side streams have succeeded in “catching up ” with the trenching of the master stream.
Among these successful streams are two that enter the Merced in Yosemite Valley — Tenaya Creek and Bridalveil Creek. Tenaya Creek had the double advantage of a southwesterly course, following the direction of the tilting, and of being underlain by closely fractured rock, and it was thus able to trench deeply. Bridalveil Creek, less advantageously situated, carved only a short, steeply descending
gulch—the gulch that now ends abruptly at the precipice of Bridalveil Fall. That cataract, however, was not yet in existence, for the gulch led directly to the bottom of the main chasm. The present lip of the gulch at the top of the waterfall still indicates roughly the level at which the Merced lay in early Quaternary time—that is, just prior to the first great extension of the glaciers of the Ice Age. Evidently the Yosemite then already had a depth of 2,400 feet, measured from the brow of El Capitan. It was, however, a much narrower and less impressive chasm than the Yosemite of to-day; it was a “ three-story canyon ” no wider at the bottom than the channel of the river itself and winding sharply among craggy spurs that projected alternately from either side. But it was adorned by cascades of remarkable height: Illilouette Creek cascaded down 600 feet; Indian Creek 1,500 feet; Yosemite Creek 1,900 feet; Meadow Brook 2,300 feet; Sentinel Creek and Ribbon Creek each 2,400 feet.
TRANSFORMATION WROUGHT BY THE ICE
And now came that epoch of wintry climate known as the great Ice Age. In the upper valleys of the Sierra Nevada snow gathered to depths of thousands of feet and, becoming compacted to granular

Figure 4.—Section of the “two-story valley” which the Merced
HAD CUT BY THE END OF THE TERTIARY PERIOD
A-A is the profile of a side stream which was unable to trench as rapidly as the Merced and whose valley has therefore remained “ hanging.” B-B is the profile of aside stream that succeeded in “catching up” with the trenching. Two such glaciers, each more than 2,000 feet thick, converged upon the Yfesemite Valley, one through Tenaya Canyon, the other through the Little Yosemite. The Ice Age, however, in the Sierra Nevada as in those parts of the continent which were covered by the great ice sheet, consisted not of one uninterrupted reign of glacial conditions, but of several glacial stages, each of which was hundreds of centuries long and was separated from the others by equally long or even longer intervals of warm climate during which the glaciers melted back part way or all the way to their sources. The Yosemite Valley, so far as is now known, was invaded by the ice three separate times. The two earlier invasions were the most extensive and the most destructive. They wiped

The transformation from the original “three-story canyon ” was accomplished mainly by the quarrying action of the glaciers of the Ice Age. The floor of the glacial trough is at D. The present valley floor is at E, and D E is the depth of the basin of ancient Lake Yosemite, which is now filled with river-borne sediment. As a result of further deepening of the chasm and of its widening by the ice the valley of the stream C-C now also “hangs,” so that there are three sets of “hanging valleys,” one above another, all having waterfalls pouring from their mouths

During the last ice invasion the Yosemite Glacier reached only to the Bridalveil Meadow. It filled the valley to moderate depth and accomplished relatively little excavating, but it accentuated the
