THE TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS OF THE UNITED STATES

0 *2r
The United States Geological Survey is making a series of standard topographic maps to cover the United States. This work has been in progress since 3882, and the published maps cover more than 47 percent of the country, exclusive of outlying possessions.
The maps are published on sheets that measure about 16| by 20 inches. Under the general plan adopted the country is divided into quadrangles bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude. These quadrangles are mapped on different scales, the scale selected for each map being that which is best adapted to general use in the development of the country, and consequently, though the standard maps are of nearly uniform size, the areas that they represent are of different sizes. On the lower margin of each map are printed graphic scales showing distances in feet, meters, miles, and kilometers. In addition, the scale of the map is shown by a fraction expressing a fixed ratio between linear measurements on the map and corresponding distances on the ground. For example, the scale means that 1 unit on the map (such as 1 inch, 1 foot, or 1 meter) represents 62,500 of the same units on the earth’s surface.
Although some areas are surveyed and some maps are compiled and published on special scales for special purposes, the standard topographic surveys and the resulting maps have for many years been of three types, differentiated as follows:
1.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of great public importance—relating, for example, to mineral development, irrigation, or reclamation of swamp areas—are made with sufficient detail to be used In the publication of maps on a scale of —5^ (1 inch = one-half mile) or (1 inch = 2,000 feet), with a contour interval of 1 to 100 feet, according to the relief of the particular area mapped.
2.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of average public importance, such as most of the basin of the Mississippi and its tributaries, are made with sufficient detail to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of ^ (1 inch = nearly 1 mile), with a contour interval of 10 to 100 feet.
3.	Surveys of areas in which the problems are of minor public importance, such as much of the mountain or desert region of Arizona or New Mexico, and the high mountain area of the northwest, are made with sufficient detail to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of (1 inch = nearly 2 miles) or (1 inch = nearly 4 miles), with a contour interval of 20 to 250 feet.
The aerial camera is now being used in mapping. From the information recorded on the photographs, planimetric maps, which show only drainage and culture, have been made for some areas in the United States. By the use of stereoscopic plotting apparatus, aerial photographs are utilized also in the making of the regular topographic maps, which show relief as well as drainage and culture.
A topographic survey of Alaska has been in progress since 1898, and nearly 44 percent of its area has now been mapped. About 15 percent of the Territory has been covered by maps On a scale of (1 inch = nearly 8 miles). For most of the remainder of the area surveyed the maps published are on a scale of ioo^joo (3 inch = nearly 4 miles). For some areas of particular economic importance, covering about 4,300 square miles, the maps published are on a scale of 0-,-^ (1 inch —nearly 1 mile) or larger. In addition to the area covered by topographic maps, about 11,300 square miles of southeastern Alaska has been covered by planimetric maps on scales of and .
The Hawaiian Islands have been surveyed, and the resulting maps are published on a scale of
A survey of Puerto Rico is now in progress. The scale of the published maps is
The features shown on topographic maps may be arranged in three groups—(1) water, including seas, lakes, rivers, canals, swamps, and other bodies of water; (2) relief, including mountains, hills, valleys, and other features of the land surface; (3) culture (works of man), such as towns, cities, roads, railroads, and boundaries. The symbols used to represent these features are shown and explained below. Variations appear on some earlier maps, and additional features are represented on some special maps.
All the water features are represented in blue, the smaller streams and canals by single blue lines and the larger streams by double lines. The larger streams, lakes, and the sea are accentuated by blue water lining or blue tint. Intermittent streams—those whose beds are dry for a large part of the year— are shown by lines of blue dote and dashes.
Relief is shown by contour lines in brown, which on a few maps are supplemented by shading showing the effect of light thrown from the northwest across the area represented, for the purpose of giving the appearance of relief and thus aiding in the interpretation of the contour lines. A contour line represents an imaginary line on the ground (a contour) every part of which is at the same altitude above sea level. Such a line could be drawn at any altitude, but in practice only the con-tom’s at certain regular intervals of altitude are shown. The datum or zero of altitude of the Geological Survey maps is mean sea level. The. 20-foot contour would be the shore line if the sea should rise 20 feet above mean sea level. Contour lines show the shape of the hills, mountains, and valleys, as well as their altitude. Successive contour lines that are far apart on the map indicate a gentle slope, lines. that are close together indicate a steep slope, and lines that run together indicate a cliff.
The manner in which contour lines express altitude, form, and grade is shown in the figure below.

The sketch represents a river valley that lies between two hills. In the foreground is the sea, with a bay that is partly enclosed by a hooked sand bar. On each side of the valley is a terrace into which small streams have cut narrow gullies. The hill on the right has a rounded summit and gently slop-
ing spurs separated by ravines. The spurs are truncated at their lower ends by a sea cliff. The hill at the left terminates abruptly at the valley in a steep scarp, from which it slopes gradually away and forms an inclined tableland that is traversed by a few shallow gullies. On the map each of these features is represented, directly beneath its position in the sketch, by contour lines.
The contour interval, or the vertical distance in feet between one contour and the next, is stated at the bottom of each map. This interval differs according to the topography of the area mapped: in a flat country it may be as small as 3 foot; in a mountainous region it may be as great as 250 feet. In order that the contours may be read more easily certain contour lines, ' every fourth or fifth, are made heavier than the others and are accompanied by figures showing altitude. The heights of many points—such as road intersections, summits, surfaces of lakes, and benchmarks—are also given on the map in figures, which show altitudes to the nearest foot only. More precise figures for the altitudes of benchmarks are given in the Geological Survey’s bulletins on spirit leveling. The geodetic coordinates of triangulation and transit-traverse stations are also published in bulletins.
Lettering and the works of man are shown in black. Boundaries, such as those of a State, county, city, land grant, township, or reservation, are shown by continuous or broken lines of different kinds and weights. Public roads suitable for motor travel the greater part of the year are shown by solid double lines; poor public roads and private roads by dashed double lines; trails by dashed single lines. Additional public road classification if available is shown by red overprint.
Each quadrangle is designated by the name of a city, town, or prominent natural feature within it, and on the margins of the map are printed the names of adjoining quadrangles of which maps have been published. More than 4,100 quadrangles in the United States have been surveyed, and maps of them similar to the one on the other side of this sheet have been published.
Geologic maps of some of the areas shown on the topographic maps have been published in the form of folios. Each folio includes maps showing the topography, geology, underground structure, and mineral deposits of the area mapped, and several pages of descriptive text. The text explains the maps and describes the topographic and geologic features of the country and its mineral products. Two hundred twenty-five folios have been published.
Index maps of each State and of Alaska and Hawaii showing the areas covered by topographic maps and geologic folios published by the United States Geological Survey may be obtained free. Copies of the standard topographic maps may be obtained for 10 cents each; some special maps are sold at different prices. A discount of 40 percent is allowed on an order amounting to $5 or more at the retail price. The discount is allowed on an order for maps alone, either of one kind or in any assortment, or for maps together with geologic folios. The geologic folios are sold for 25 cents or more each, the price depending on the size of the folio. A circular describing the folios will be sent on request.
Applications for maps or folios should be accompanied by cash, draft, or money order (not postage stamps) and should be addressed to
THE DIRECTOR,
United States Geological Survey,
November 1937.	Washington, l). C.

THE TOPOGRAPHIC MAPS OF THE UNITED STATES

0 *2r
The United States Geological Survey is making a series of standard topographic maps to cover the United States. This work has been in progress since 3882, and the published maps cover more than 47 percent of the country, exclusive of outlying possessions.
The maps are published on sheets that measure about 16| by 20 inches. Under the general plan adopted the country is divided into quadrangles bounded by parallels of latitude and meridians of longitude. These quadrangles are mapped on different scales, the scale selected for each map being that which is best adapted to general use in the development of the country, and consequently, though the standard maps are of nearly uniform size, the areas that they represent are of different sizes. On the lower margin of each map are printed graphic scales showing distances in feet, meters, miles, and kilometers. In addition, the scale of the map is shown by a fraction expressing a fixed ratio between linear measurements on the map and corresponding distances on the ground. For example, the scale means that 1 unit on the map (such as 1 inch, 1 foot, or 1 meter) represents 62,500 of the same units on the earth’s surface.
Although some areas are surveyed and some maps are compiled and published on special scales for special purposes, the standard topographic surveys and the resulting maps have for many years been of three types, differentiated as follows:
1.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of great public importance—relating, for example, to mineral development, irrigation, or reclamation of swamp areas—are made with sufficient detail to be used In the publication of maps on a scale of —5^ (1 inch = one-half mile) or (1 inch = 2,000 feet), with a contour interval of 1 to 100 feet, according to the relief of the particular area mapped.
2.	Surveys of areas in which there are problems of average public importance, such as most of the basin of the Mississippi and its tributaries, are made with sufficient detail to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of ^ (1 inch = nearly 1 mile), with a contour interval of 10 to 100 feet.
3.	Surveys of areas in which the problems are of minor public importance, such as much of the mountain or desert region of Arizona or New Mexico, and the high mountain area of the northwest, are made with sufficient detail to be used in the publication of maps on a scale of (1 inch = nearly 2 miles) or (1 inch = nearly 4 miles), with a contour interval of 20 to 250 feet.
The aerial camera is now being used in mapping. From the information recorded on the photographs, planimetric maps, which show only drainage and culture, have been made for some areas in the United States. By the use of stereoscopic plotting apparatus, aerial photographs are utilized also in the making of the regular topographic maps, which show relief as well as drainage and culture.
A topographic survey of Alaska has been in progress since 1898, and nearly 44 percent of its area has now been mapped. About 15 percent of the Territory has been covered by maps On a scale of (1 inch = nearly 8 miles). For most of the remainder of the area surveyed the maps published are on a scale of ioo^joo (3 inch = nearly 4 miles). For some areas of particular economic importance, covering about 4,300 square miles, the maps published are on a scale of 0-,-^ (1 inch —nearly 1 mile) or larger. In addition to the area covered by topographic maps, about 11,300 square miles of southeastern Alaska has been covered by planimetric maps on scales of and .
The Hawaiian Islands have been surveyed, and the resulting maps are published on a scale of
A survey of Puerto Rico is now in progress. The scale of the published maps is
The features shown on topographic maps may be arranged in three groups—(1) water, including seas, lakes, rivers, canals, swamps, and other bodies of water; (2) relief, including mountains, hills, valleys, and other features of the land surface; (3) culture (works of man), such as towns, cities, roads, railroads, and boundaries. The symbols used to represent these features are shown and explained below. Variations appear on some earlier maps, and additional features are represented on some special maps.
All the water features are represented in blue, the smaller streams and canals by single blue lines and the larger streams by double lines. The larger streams, lakes, and the sea are accentuated by blue water lining or blue tint. Intermittent streams—those whose beds are dry for a large part of the year— are shown by lines of blue dote and dashes.
Relief is shown by contour lines in brown, which on a few maps are supplemented by shading showing the effect of light thrown from the northwest across the area represented, for the purpose of giving the appearance of relief and thus aiding in the interpretation of the contour lines. A contour line represents an imaginary line on the ground (a contour) every part of which is at the same altitude above sea level. Such a line could be drawn at any altitude, but in practice only the con-tom’s at certain regular intervals of altitude are shown. The datum or zero of altitude of the Geological Survey maps is mean sea level. The. 20-foot contour would be the shore line if the sea should rise 20 feet above mean sea level. Contour lines show the shape of the hills, mountains, and valleys, as well as their altitude. Successive contour lines that are far apart on the map indicate a gentle slope, lines. that are close together indicate a steep slope, and lines that run together indicate a cliff.
The manner in which contour lines express altitude, form, and grade is shown in the figure below.

The sketch represents a river valley that lies between two hills. In the foreground is the sea, with a bay that is partly enclosed by a hooked sand bar. On each side of the valley is a terrace into which small streams have cut narrow gullies. The hill on the right has a rounded summit and gently slop-
ing spurs separated by ravines. The spurs are truncated at their lower ends by a sea cliff. The hill at the left terminates abruptly at the valley in a steep scarp, from which it slopes gradually away and forms an inclined tableland that is traversed by a few shallow gullies. On the map each of these features is represented, directly beneath its position in the sketch, by contour lines.
The contour interval, or the vertical distance in feet between one contour and the next, is stated at the bottom of each map. This interval differs according to the topography of the area mapped: in a flat country it may be as small as 3 foot; in a mountainous region it may be as great as 250 feet. In order that the contours may be read more easily certain contour lines, ' every fourth or fifth, are made heavier than the others and are accompanied by figures showing altitude. The heights of many points—such as road intersections, summits, surfaces of lakes, and benchmarks—are also given on the map in figures, which show altitudes to the nearest foot only. More precise figures for the altitudes of benchmarks are given in the Geological Survey’s bulletins on spirit leveling. The geodetic coordinates of triangulation and transit-traverse stations are also published in bulletins.
Lettering and the works of man are shown in black. Boundaries, such as those of a State, county, city, land grant, township, or reservation, are shown by continuous or broken lines of different kinds and weights. Public roads suitable for motor travel the greater part of the year are shown by solid double lines; poor public roads and private roads by dashed double lines; trails by dashed single lines. Additional public road classification if available is shown by red overprint.
Each quadrangle is designated by the name of a city, town, or prominent natural feature within it, and on the margins of the map are printed the names of adjoining quadrangles of which maps have been published. More than 4,100 quadrangles in the United States have been surveyed, and maps of them similar to the one on the other side of this sheet have been published.
Geologic maps of some of the areas shown on the topographic maps have been published in the form of folios. Each folio includes maps showing the topography, geology, underground structure, and mineral deposits of the area mapped, and several pages of descriptive text. The text explains the maps and describes the topographic and geologic features of the country and its mineral products. Two hundred twenty-five folios have been published.
Index maps of each State and of Alaska and Hawaii showing the areas covered by topographic maps and geologic folios published by the United States Geological Survey may be obtained free. Copies of the standard topographic maps may be obtained for 10 cents each; some special maps are sold at different prices. A discount of 40 percent is allowed on an order amounting to $5 or more at the retail price. The discount is allowed on an order for maps alone, either of one kind or in any assortment, or for maps together with geologic folios. The geologic folios are sold for 25 cents or more each, the price depending on the size of the folio. A circular describing the folios will be sent on request.
Applications for maps or folios should be accompanied by cash, draft, or money order (not postage stamps) and should be addressed to

United States Geological Survey,
November 1937.	Washington, l). C.

DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE BUREAU OF PUBLIC ROADS
THE
FEDERAL AID HIGHWAY SYSTEM
PROGRESS MAP
SOUTHEASTERN CALIFORNIA
Scale 1:760,320, or 1 inch=12 miles.
Projection—Modified Polyconic.
Base Map from U. S. Geological Survey State map.
Base revised as to cities and towns on F. A. H. S. and county lines by Bureau of Public Roads, Feb. 1,1929 Data for pavement types on those portions of F. A. H. S. heretofore.
improved without F. A., compiled from latest State records. Sections of pavement less than half a mile in length merged with adjacent section of nearest similar type.
Published in accordance with Act of Congress approved Nov. 9, 1921, creating the Federal Aid Highway System Data corrected to July 1, 1929

PAVEMENT TYPES SHOWN BY LETTERS
PRINTED BY THE U S GEOLOGICAL SURVEY
A.	For roads having surfaces of bituminous materials irrespective of base :
such as Sheet Asphalt, Bituminous Concrete, Bituminous Macadam, and all types included in Bureau’s Code Numbers 47-69.
B.	For Block, Brick, and all types included in Bureaus Code Numbers 80-99.
C.	For Portland Cement Concrete and all types included in Bureau’s Code
Numbers 70 79.
E. For Earth Graded and Drained and all types included in Bureau’s Code Numbers 10-19.
G. For Gravel and all types included in Bureau’s Code Numbers 30-39.
M. For Surface Treated Macadam, Water-bound Macadam, and all included in Bureau’s Code Numbers 40-46.

transcription:
DESCRIPTION OF THE TOPOGRAPHIC MAP OF THE UNITED STATES.
The United States Geological Survey is making a topographic map of the United States. This Avork has been in progress since 1882, and about one-fifth of the area of the country, including Alaska, has been mapped. The mapped areas are widely scattered, neai’ly every State being represented, as shown on the progress map accompanying each annual report of the Director.
This great map is being published in atlas sheets of convenient size, which are bounded by parallels and meridians. The four-cornered division of land corresponding to an atlas sheet is called a quadrangle (a word used as specifically as section is in the surveys of the public lands). The sheets are of approximately the same size: the paper dimensions are 21| by 184 inches; the map occupies about 17^ inches of height and 111 to 16 inches of width, the latter varying with latitude. Three scales, however, are employed. The largest scale is 1:62,500, or very nearly one mile to one inch; i. e., one linear mile on the ground is represented by one linear inch on the map. This scale is used for the thickly settled or industrially important parts of the country. For the greater part of the country an intermediate scale of 1:125,000, or about two miles to one inch, is employed. A third and still smaller scale of 1:250,000, or about four miles to one inch, has been used in the desert regions of the far West. A few special maps on larger scales are made of limited areas in mining districts. The sheets on the largest scale cover 15' of latitude by 15' of longitude; those on the intermediate scale, 30' of latitude by 30' of longitude; and those on the smallest scale, 1° of latitude by 1° of longitude.
The features shown on this map may, for convenience, be classed in three groups: (1) water, including seas, lakes, ponds, rivers and other streams, canals, swamps, etc.; (2) relief, including mountains, hills, valleys, cliffs, etc.; (3) culture, i. e., the works of man, such as towns, cities, roads, railroads, boundaries, etc. The conventional signs used for most of these features are shown and explained in the marginal columns herewith.
All water features are shown in blue, the smaller streams and canals in full blue lines, and the larger streams, lakes, and the sea by blue water-lining. Certain streams, however, which flow during only a part of the year, their beds being dry at other times, are shown, not by full lines, biit by lines of dots. Ponds which are dry during a part of the year are shown by oblique parallel lines. Salt-water marshes are shown by horizontal ruling interspersed with tufts of blue, and fresh-water marshes and swamps by blue tufts with broken horizontal lines.
The land features of the relief, usually represented on maps by shading of some sort, with pen or brush, are here shown by contour lines in brown. Each contour passes through those points which have the same altitude. If one follows a contour on the ground one will go neither uphill nor dowmhill, but on a level.
By the use of contours not only are the shapes
of the plains, hills, and mountains showm, but also the elevations. The line of the sea-coast itself is a contour line, the datum or zero of elevation being mean sea-level. The contour line at, say, 20 feet above sea-level is the line that would be the sea-coast if the sea were to rise or the land to sink 20 feet. Such a line runs back up the valleys and forwnrd around the points of hills and spurs. On a gentle slope this contour line is far from the present coast line, wdiile on a steep slope it is near it. Thus a succession of these contour lines far apart on the map indicates a gentle slope; if close together, a steep slope; and if they run together in one line, as if each contour were vertically under the one above it, they indicate a cliff. In many parts of the country are depressions or hollows with no outlets. The contours of course surround these, just as they surround hills. Those small hollows known as sinks are usually indicated by hachures, or short dashes, on the inside of the curve. Certain contours, usually every fifth one, are accompanied by numbers stating elevation above sea-level. Many other heights, instrumentally determined, are also given, the number in each case being placed in close proximity to the point to which it applies.
The works of man are shown in black, in Avhich color all lettering also is printed. Boundaries, such as State, county, city, land-grant, reservation,, etc., are shoAvn by broken lines of different kinds and weights. Cities are indicated by black blocks, representing the built-up portions, and country houses by small black squares. Roads are shown by fine double lines (full for the better roads, dotted for the inferior ones), trails by single dotted lines, and railroads by full black lines with cross lines. Other cultural features are represented by conventions easily understood.
The sheets composing the topographic atlas are designated by the name of a principal town-or of some prominent natural feature within the district, and the names of adjoining published sheets are printed on the margins. The sheets are sold at five cents each w’hen fevver than 100 copies are purchased, but when they are ordered in lots of 100 or more copies, w'hether of the same sheet or of different sheets, the price is tAvo cents each.
The topographic map is the base on which the facts of geology and the mineral resources of a quadrangle are represented. The topographic and geologic maps of any quadrangle are finally bound together, accompanied by a description of the district, to form a folio of the Geologic Atlas of the United States. The folios are sold at twenty-five cents each, except such as are unusually comprehensive, which are priced accordingly.
Applications for the separate topographic maps or for folios of the Geologic Atlas, accompanied by the cash or by post-office money order (not postage stamps), should be addressed to-—
THE DIRECTOR,
United States Geological /Survey, Washington, D. C.

transcription:
John R. Borchert Map Library University of Minnesota S 76 O.M. Wilson Library
ZI
WASATCH NATIONAL FOREST.
The National Forests constitute the chief recreation grounds of the nation. They are visited annually by a great number of tourists and campers, and the Forest Service is expending large sums of money to make them accessible and to protect them from fire.
Visitors are always welcome. Pleasure seekers who use the Forests, however, are urged to always bear in mind that carelessness with fire may result in immense damage to the public property which the Forests contain, destroy the beauty of the region, and endanger human life. Green trees are a promise of future prosperity, health, and happiness.
In assisting you, by this folder, in making use of the Wasatch National Forest, it is believed that you will do your share in protecting the public resources by a careful observance of the rules and suggestions given.
The Wasatch National Forest has an area of approximately 612,000 acres. It embraces the Wasatch Eange, which gives it its name, from Provo Canyon on the south to City Creek Canyon on the north, Stansbury Range south of Great Salt Lake, which is not shown on the map, and the region on the north and west side of the Uinta Range, thus including part of the headwaters of the Green River and the headwaters of the Bear, Provo, and Weber
2
SCENIC ATTRACTIONS.
Mount Timpanogos and its glacier present one of the greatest scenic attractions of the West. Professor Buss of the Brigham Young University of Provo has furnished the following interesting description of Mount Timpanogos:
“Mount Timpanogos, the highest and most prominent peak of the Wasatch Range, lies just within the southern limit of the Wasatch National Forest. It is a somewhat isolated mountain mass rising abruptly 7,500 feet above Utah Valley and separated from other parts of the range by the deeply cut canyons of Provo and American Fork Rivers.
“The western face is a great fault scarp, bold and rocky, but barren because of the intense heat generated under the perpendicular rays of the summer’s afternoon sun. The eastern slope is somewhat more gentle although deeply trenched by great canyons excavated by the combined work of running water and glacial ice. On this side are found magnificent groves of quaking aspen, fir, and spruce and it is abundantly supplied with clear mountain streams which cascade down the ledges from the perennial snow banks which lie protected in the shadow of the great cliffs.
“Because of the beauty and scientific interest of this eastern side, the U. S. Forest Service, upon the solicitation of the Timpanogos Nature Club of Provo and other interested persons and
7
Big Cottonwood Canyon is the most beautiful canyon of the Wasatch Range, and special camp grounds near the head of the canyon are maintained by the Forest Service for the benefit of the camper.
Brighton, in Big Cottonwood Canyon, is one of the choice summer colonies of Utah. About 500 people spend their summers here amid the lofty peaks and the glacial lakes of the Wasatch Range.
Travel through the Uinta Mountains is entirely by saddle and pack horse, and supplies for the entire trip must be carried, since they can not be replenished after depletion by a mountain appetite. * Clothing should be warm, as the nights will be below freezing even in summer, and heavy coats are comfortable as soon as the sun is down.
There is much small game in the Uinta Mountains, and deer, elk, mountain sheep, and bear summer at the high altitudes. Holiday Park, on the headwaters of the Weber River, is one of the choice summer home locations of the Wasatch Forest. About 75 people spend their summers here at the foot of the Uinta Mountains, and are able to enjoy wonderful fishing throughout the year. Holiday Park may be reached by automobile from Salt Lake City.
For a trip through the Uinta Mountains you leave the wagon and automobile road at Holiday Park and travel up the Weber River to the

Rivers together with the small streams draining into Salt Lake Valley. The maintenance of favorable streamflow conditions on these watersheds is essential to the prosperity and health of the most populous section of Utah.
GENERAL FEATURES OF THE WASATCH NATIONAL FOREST.
At one time the Wasatch Mountains were occupied by glaciers as far north as Mill Creek. One of these, the glacier on the eastern face of Mount Timpanogos, remains and is the only one in Utah. To the deposits resulting from this early glaciation we owe the numerous small lakes in the heads of the canyons. During, or immediately following the glacial period, a great lake, historically known as Lake Bonneville, formed in the regions west of the Wasatch Mountains, thereby occupying a large part of western Utah and eastern Nevada.
This ancient fresh water lake was a thousand feet higher than its present remnant, Great Salt Lake, which now contains in solution upwards of 22 per cent solid mineral matter. The principal outlet was through Port Neuf Canyon to the Snake River. Sudden geological changes made correspondingly quick alterations in the relative elevation of the surface of the lake. The evidence of this is the numerous shore lines along the mountains which show that the waters washed back and forth at these levels for varying periods during its recession.
3
institutions, has seen fit to withdraw from grazing and other forest operations about 800 acres of land. Within this area lies the miniature glacier and lake for which the mountain is noted, as well as scores of magnificent waterfalls and a most wonderful flora and fauna comprising species native to all latitudes north of 40°. Here the geologist, the physiographer, the botanist, the zoologist, and the entomologist as well as the mere lover of the beatiful in nature may find a veritable paradise.
“The main aspects of this portion of the mountain were determined by the work of a glacier, which, during what is known geologically as the “Ice Age” had its birth near the mountain crest and advanced down the canyon of the North Fork of Provo River to a point only about three miles above the junction of North Fork with the main stream. This ice mass formed three great cirques or amphitheatres near the mountain top, swept the debris from the sides and bottom of the main canyon, planed away the projecting spurs and then melting under the head of the lower altitude deposited its earthy load to form the fine system of terminal and lateral moraines which remain to tell the story of that age.
“The present tiny glacier which is probably the only remaining remnant, in Utah, of the great alpine glaciers of the Ice Age lies in the embrace of one of the great cirques near the
8
divide at the head of the Duchesne, thence eastward through the Granddaddy Lake country. Or you can go north of the main divide of the Uinta Mountains and through the heads of Bear River and Blacks Fork. Either route will give good fishing, hunting, and beautiful camp grounds. You may also go up Moffit Creek and over the divide into the head of Bear River and and then eastward along the north side of the Uinta. This route is not as rough as up the Weber River. On either route the Forest Ranger and his telephone line will be there to render assistance and information if desired.

Located along the courses of the streams are power plants having a total water-wheel installation of 111,900 horsepower. Practically the entire amount of electrical energy transmitted from these plants is consumed as power or light in Salt Lake City, Ogden, Provo, and the intervening small towns.
In addition to the power developed by the numerous mountain streams the waters are used for irrigation and all domestic purposes. The immediate watersheds of the streams which furnish Salt Lake City with water are closed to grazing, while camping and mining are permitted under sanitary regulations which will guard the health of the city’s population.
The amount of timber in the Forest is estimated at 500,000,000 feet, consisting principally of lodgepole pine, Engelmann spruce, and alpine fir.
The Forest provides summer range for about 14,000 cattle and horses and 61,000 sheep, the property of approximately a thousand local residents.
Mining is now and has been ever since the pioneer days one of the principal industries of this section. The camps of Alta, American Fork Canyon, and Park City are located on or draw electrical energy, wood, and water from the Forest.
Two nurseries are maintained for the raising of young trees to be planted in the various
National Forests of the intermountain region. One is located near Kamas on Beaver Creek, the other near Brighton on Big Cottonwood Creek.
FOREST IMPROVEMENTS.
Each of the various ranger stations within the Forest is connected by phone with the nearest exchange of the Mountain States Telphone and Telegraph Co. These telephone lines are constructed principally for the protection and administration of the Forest, but campers and tourists are welcome to use them.
One long ring on any telephone at a lookout or ranger station will give you the nearest central of the Bell system. Calls for the different ranger stations inside the Forest may be made through central or direct by making the ring given on the instruction sheet hung above the telephone.
The great amount of prospecting, mining, and travel throughout the mountains of the Wasatch division has resulted in a fine system of roads and trails, giving easy access to every creek and canyon. Existing roads and trails have been blazed and new ones built by the Forest Service.
When you are traveling in the Uinta Mountain division of the Forest you should look for the tree blaze with a notch above, which marks the Forest Service trails. If you are being guided by the Forest Service signs and notices and desire to follow a Service trail to your des-
4
5
mountain top. Around its edge runs the true “bergsehrund” of glaciers and at its foot lies a diminutive glacial lake. This glacier is perhaps one mile long, one-quarter mile wide, and has an estimated thickness of 150 or 200 feet. Its movement is very slight though real, as is indicated by the recent bunching up of a moraine across the lake, and the undulatory surface of the central portion of the glacier itself.
“Here it lies to-day, crossed annually by hundreds of “hikers” telling, to one who has eyes to see, the story of the ages gone. To the ordinary individual, climbing the mountain, its chief interest lies in the splendid opportunity its steep upper portion presents for a midsummer toboggan.
“There is little doubt that to everyone a climb to the narrow crest of this monarch of mountains is an inspiration, revealing as it does through the clear air of this western land a veritable sea of mountain and valley rolling off below in every direction, billow upon billow, until finally lost in the blue haze of the far distance.”
In making your trip to Mount Timpanogos, you should endeavor to take in American Fork Canyon as well as the Provo Canyon. A trip through these canyons will add greatly to the enjoyment of your vacation.
American Fork River for the last 4 miles of its journey, has cut its channel through the
Wasatch fault, and this channel has not been smoothed by glaciation. The contrast of this rugged gorge with the smooth rolling hills of the higher valley is one of the most striking features of the Wasatch Range.
The Uinta Mountains are the highest in the State; the peaks range from 12,000 to 13,498 feet. Kings Peaks with an elevation of 13,496 and 13,498 are the highest in Utah. These mountains offer scenery of wonderful beauty to those able to stand the hardships and who have the time for a trip. From any of the high peaks glacial lakes and rugged mountain crags can be seen as far as the eye will reach. From the backbone of the range streams flow north and south through high mountain meadows and from lake to lake until lost in the heavy timber of the lower slopes.
Fishing is to be had in all the streams and lakes, and beautiful camping grounds are to be found wherever night overtakes you. In traveling you are lost from all world’s connection, and the Forest officer and the lonesome sheep herder will likely be the only outposts of civilization encountered.
A report by the Geological Survey thus describes the region:

For your convenience a large number of signs have been placed at the intersection of the principal roads and trails, indicating the direction and distance to the nearest settlement or ranger station. The signs are put up for your benefit and their mutilation is a wanton act punishable by law.
Cami) grounds soon Become unsightly and insanitary unless each camper hums and huries all refuse as it accummulates from day to day.

It is especially important that care be taken not to contaminate the water in springs and creeks. Remember that these mountain streams furnish the domestic water supply for campers and settlers below you.

effect is that of desolate grandeur; but in the lower basin-like valleys, which support a heavy growth of coniferous trees, the view of one of these mountain lakes, with its deep-gi-een water and fringe of meadow land, set in the somber frame of pine forests, the whole inclosed by high walls of reddish purple rock whose bedding gives almost the appearance of Cyclopean masonry, forms a picture of rare beauty.”
FOREST TRIPS.
In planning yonr vacation, a trip through the Wasatch Forest should be given first place. A trip to one of the many resorts within the Forest or a camping trip in the Wasatch or through the rugged wilderness of the Uinta Range will drive away the dull cares and return you to the business world fit for any duty.
The electric line of the Emigration Canyon Railroad makes Pinecrest the most accessible point from Salt Lake. This line follows the route of the pioneers from Salt Lake to Pine-crest, a distance of 13 miles, and carries-passengers to the head of the canyon aud to the numerous summer homes throughout the canyon.
To the camper with but a week to spare, Big Cottonwood Canyon offers the best in the Wasatcli Range. The trip is through a rugged cauyon which opens to a beautiful mountain valley at the head, surrounded on all sides with mountains extending above timber line.
11
The weight of a ration will avei'age from 5 to 6 pounds. The ordinary pack horse will carry about 150 pounds, and keep in good condition in traveling from 15 to 20 miles per day.
The nights are always cool in the mountains so plenty of warm clothing and bedding should be taken. Waders are desirable if one is to do much fishing in the streams.
FOREST FIRES.
Every forest fire means direct damage to one or sevei’al of the foi'est resources. At least two-thirds of the fires that start are due to human agencies. Camp fires left burning, unextinguished matches, and burning tobacco are responsible for a large part of the fires—causes that are entirely preventable. Large fires are certain to cause great damage to timber aud forage, and perhaps to homes and livestock as wel I.
Campers and travelei’S do not always realize that every large fire starts from a small one. By observing the following simple rules, the danger of fires can be greatly reduced.
Before building your camp fire clean the ground for a considerable distance around of all debris and inflammable material ; or dig a pit and wall it with rock.
Build your fire in the open and not against a tree or rotten and water-soaked logs. Be careful that it is not in a windy or exposed place where sparks are liable to be blown for considerable distances.
Before leaving camp, even for a few hours, always extinguish your fire by pouring water upon it, or, if water is not availble, cover thorouglily with dirt.
Be sure that your match is out before throwing it away. Extinguish your cigar and cigarette stubs and be careful that they, as well as. ashes from a pipe, are dropped where there is no inflammable material.

WASATCH NATIONAL FOREST.
The National Forests constitute the chief recreation grounds of the nation. They are visited annually by a great number of tourists and campers, and the Forest Service is expending large sums of money to make them accessible and to protect them from fire.
Visitors are always welcome. Pleasure seekers who use the Forests, however, are urged to always bear in mind that carelessness with fire may result in immense damage to the public property which the Forests contain, destroy the beauty of the region, and endanger human life. Green trees are a promise of future prosperity, health, and happiness.
In assisting you, by this folder, in making use of the Wasatch National Forest, it is believed that you will do your share in protecting the public resources by a careful observance of the rules and suggestions given.
The Wasatch National Forest has an area of approximately 612,000 acres. It embraces the Wasatch Eange, which gives it its name, from Provo Canyon on the south to City Creek Canyon on the north, Stansbury Range south of Great Salt Lake, which is not shown on the map, and the region on the north and west side of the Uinta Range, thus including part of the headwaters of the Green River and the headwaters of the Bear, Provo, and Weber
2
SCENIC ATTRACTIONS.
Mount Timpanogos and its glacier present one of the greatest scenic attractions of the West. Professor Buss of the Brigham Young University of Provo has furnished the following interesting description of Mount Timpanogos:
“Mount Timpanogos, the highest and most prominent peak of the Wasatch Range, lies just within the southern limit of the Wasatch National Forest. It is a somewhat isolated mountain mass rising abruptly 7,500 feet above Utah Valley and separated from other parts of the range by the deeply cut canyons of Provo and American Fork Rivers.
“The western face is a great fault scarp, bold and rocky, but barren because of the intense heat generated under the perpendicular rays of the summer’s afternoon sun. The eastern slope is somewhat more gentle although deeply trenched by great canyons excavated by the combined work of running water and glacial ice. On this side are found magnificent groves of quaking aspen, fir, and spruce and it is abundantly supplied with clear mountain streams which cascade down the ledges from the perennial snow banks which lie protected in the shadow of the great cliffs.
“Because of the beauty and scientific interest of this eastern side, the U. S. Forest Service, upon the solicitation of the Timpanogos Nature Club of Provo and other interested persons and
7
Big Cottonwood Canyon is the most beautiful canyon of the Wasatch Range, and special camp grounds near the head of the canyon are maintained by the Forest Service for the benefit of the camper.
Brighton, in Big Cottonwood Canyon, is one of the choice summer colonies of Utah. About 500 people spend their summers here amid the lofty peaks and the glacial lakes of the Wasatch Range.
Travel through the Uinta Mountains is entirely by saddle and pack horse, and supplies for the entire trip must be carried, since they can not be replenished after depletion by a mountain appetite. * Clothing should be warm, as the nights will be below freezing even in summer, and heavy coats are comfortable as soon as the sun is down.
There is much small game in the Uinta Mountains, and deer, elk, mountain sheep, and bear summer at the high altitudes. Holiday Park, on the headwaters of the Weber River, is one of the choice summer home locations of the Wasatch Forest. About 75 people spend their summers here at the foot of the Uinta Mountains, and are able to enjoy wonderful fishing throughout the year. Holiday Park may be reached by automobile from Salt Lake City.

GENERAL FEATURES OF THE WASATCH NATIONAL FOREST.
At one time the Wasatch Mountains were occupied by glaciers as far north as Mill Creek. One of these, the glacier on the eastern face of Mount Timpanogos, remains and is the only one in Utah. To the deposits resulting from this early glaciation we owe the numerous small lakes in the heads of the canyons. During, or immediately following the glacial period, a great lake, historically known as Lake Bonneville, formed in the regions west of the Wasatch Mountains, thereby occupying a large part of western Utah and eastern Nevada.
This ancient fresh water lake was a thousand feet higher than its present remnant, Great Salt Lake, which now contains in solution upwards of 22 per cent solid mineral matter. The principal outlet was through Port Neuf Canyon to the Snake River. Sudden geological changes made correspondingly quick alterations in the relative elevation of the surface of the lake. The evidence of this is the numerous shore lines along the mountains which show that the waters washed back and forth at these levels for varying periods during its recession.
3
institutions, has seen fit to withdraw from grazing and other forest operations about 800 acres of land. Within this area lies the miniature glacier and lake for which the mountain is noted, as well as scores of magnificent waterfalls and a most wonderful flora and fauna comprising species native to all latitudes north of 40°. Here the geologist, the physiographer, the botanist, the zoologist, and the entomologist as well as the mere lover of the beatiful in nature may find a veritable paradise.
“The main aspects of this portion of the mountain were determined by the work of a glacier, which, during what is known geologically as the “Ice Age” had its birth near the mountain crest and advanced down the canyon of the North Fork of Provo River to a point only about three miles above the junction of North Fork with the main stream. This ice mass formed three great cirques or amphitheatres near the mountain top, swept the debris from the sides and bottom of the main canyon, planed away the projecting spurs and then melting under the head of the lower altitude deposited its earthy load to form the fine system of terminal and lateral moraines which remain to tell the story of that age.
“The present tiny glacier which is probably the only remaining remnant, in Utah, of the great alpine glaciers of the Ice Age lies in the embrace of one of the great cirques near the

divide at the head of the Duchesne, thence eastward through the Granddaddy Lake country. Or you can go north of the main divide of the Uinta Mountains and through the heads of Bear River and Blacks Fork. Either route will give good fishing, hunting, and beautiful camp grounds. You may also go up Moffit Creek and over the divide into the head of Bear River and and then eastward along the north side of the Uinta. This route is not as rough as up the Weber River. On either route the Forest Ranger and his telephone line will be there to render assistance and information if desired.

Located along the courses of the streams are power plants having a total water-wheel installation of 111,900 horsepower. Practically the entire amount of electrical energy transmitted from these plants is consumed as power or light in Salt Lake City, Ogden, Provo, and the intervening small towns.
In addition to the power developed by the numerous mountain streams the waters are used for irrigation and all domestic purposes. The immediate watersheds of the streams which furnish Salt Lake City with water are closed to grazing, while camping and mining are permitted under sanitary regulations which will guard the health of the city’s population.
The amount of timber in the Forest is estimated at 500,000,000 feet, consisting principally of lodgepole pine, Engelmann spruce, and alpine fir.
The Forest provides summer range for about 14,000 cattle and horses and 61,000 sheep, the property of approximately a thousand local residents.
Mining is now and has been ever since the pioneer days one of the principal industries of this section. The camps of Alta, American Fork Canyon, and Park City are located on or draw electrical energy, wood, and water from the Forest.
Two nurseries are maintained for the raising of young trees to be planted in the various
National Forests of the intermountain region. One is located near Kamas on Beaver Creek, the other near Brighton on Big Cottonwood Creek.
FOREST IMPROVEMENTS.
Each of the various ranger stations within the Forest is connected by phone with the nearest exchange of the Mountain States Telphone and Telegraph Co. These telephone lines are constructed principally for the protection and administration of the Forest, but campers and tourists are welcome to use them.
One long ring on any telephone at a lookout or ranger station will give you the nearest central of the Bell system. Calls for the different ranger stations inside the Forest may be made through central or direct by making the ring given on the instruction sheet hung above the telephone.
The great amount of prospecting, mining, and travel throughout the mountains of the Wasatch division has resulted in a fine system of roads and trails, giving easy access to every creek and canyon. Existing roads and trails have been blazed and new ones built by the Forest Service.
When you are traveling in the Uinta Mountain division of the Forest you should look for the tree blaze with a notch above, which marks the Forest Service trails. If you are being guided by the Forest Service signs and notices and desire to follow a Service trail to your des-
4
5
mountain top. Around its edge runs the true “bergsehrund” of glaciers and at its foot lies a diminutive glacial lake. This glacier is perhaps one mile long, one-quarter mile wide, and has an estimated thickness of 150 or 200 feet. Its movement is very slight though real, as is indicated by the recent bunching up of a moraine across the lake, and the undulatory surface of the central portion of the glacier itself.
“Here it lies to-day, crossed annually by hundreds of “hikers” telling, to one who has eyes to see, the story of the ages gone. To the ordinary individual, climbing the mountain, its chief interest lies in the splendid opportunity its steep upper portion presents for a midsummer toboggan.
“There is little doubt that to everyone a climb to the narrow crest of this monarch of mountains is an inspiration, revealing as it does through the clear air of this western land a veritable sea of mountain and valley rolling off below in every direction, billow upon billow, until finally lost in the blue haze of the far distance.”
In making your trip to Mount Timpanogos, you should endeavor to take in American Fork Canyon as well as the Provo Canyon. A trip through these canyons will add greatly to the enjoyment of your vacation.
American Fork River for the last 4 miles of its journey, has cut its channel through the
Wasatch fault, and this channel has not been smoothed by glaciation. The contrast of this rugged gorge with the smooth rolling hills of the higher valley is one of the most striking features of the Wasatch Range.
The Uinta Mountains are the highest in the State; the peaks range from 12,000 to 13,498 feet. Kings Peaks with an elevation of 13,496 and 13,498 are the highest in Utah. These mountains offer scenery of wonderful beauty to those able to stand the hardships and who have the time for a trip. From any of the high peaks glacial lakes and rugged mountain crags can be seen as far as the eye will reach. From the backbone of the range streams flow north and south through high mountain meadows and from lake to lake until lost in the heavy timber of the lower slopes.
Fishing is to be had in all the streams and lakes, and beautiful camping grounds are to be found wherever night overtakes you. In traveling you are lost from all world’s connection, and the Forest officer and the lonesome sheep herder will likely be the only outposts of civilization encountered.
A report by the Geological Survey thus describes the region:
“The scenery of this elevated region is singularly wild and picturesque, both in form and coloring. In the higher portions of the range where the forest growth is extremely scanty the

tination, remember that a trail marked with a blaze without a notch above can not be safely followed unless you are familiar with the country through which you are traveling.
This map will show the routes of all Service trails.
For your convenience a large number of signs have been placed at the intersection of the principal roads and trails, indicating the direction and distance to the nearest settlement or ranger station. The signs are put up for your benefit and their mutilation is a wanton act punishable by law.
Cami) grounds soon Become unsightly and insanitary unless each camper hums and huries all refuse as it accummulates from day to day.
When you establish a camp, dig a hole at a safe distance from the water and throxv into it all camp refuse, tin cans, etc. When camp is moved it will take but a minute to cover it with dirt, leaving it in a satisfactory condition for the next visitor.
It is especially important that care be taken not to contaminate the water in springs and creeks. Remember that these mountain streams furnish the domestic water supply for campers and settlers below you.

effect is that of desolate grandeur; but in the lower basin-like valleys, which support a heavy growth of coniferous trees, the view of one of these mountain lakes, with its deep-gi-een water and fringe of meadow land, set in the somber frame of pine forests, the whole inclosed by high walls of reddish purple rock whose bedding gives almost the appearance of Cyclopean masonry, forms a picture of rare beauty.”
FOREST TRIPS.
In planning yonr vacation, a trip through the Wasatch Forest should be given first place. A trip to one of the many resorts within the Forest or a camping trip in the Wasatch or through the rugged wilderness of the Uinta Range will drive away the dull cares and return you to the business world fit for any duty.
The electric line of the Emigration Canyon Railroad makes Pinecrest the most accessible point from Salt Lake. This line follows the route of the pioneers from Salt Lake to Pine-crest, a distance of 13 miles, and carries-passengers to the head of the canyon aud to the numerous summer homes throughout the canyon.
To the camper with but a week to spare, Big Cottonwood Canyon offers the best in the Wasatcli Range. The trip is through a rugged cauyon which opens to a beautiful mountain valley at the head, surrounded on all sides with mountains extending above timber line.
11
The weight of a ration will avei'age from 5 to 6 pounds. The ordinary pack horse will carry about 150 pounds, and keep in good condition in traveling from 15 to 20 miles per day.
The nights are always cool in the mountains so plenty of warm clothing and bedding should be taken. Waders are desirable if one is to do much fishing in the streams.
FOREST FIRES.
Every forest fire means direct damage to one or sevei’al of the foi'est resources. At least two-thirds of the fires that start are due to human agencies. Camp fires left burning, unextinguished matches, and burning tobacco are responsible for a large part of the fires—causes that are entirely preventable. Large fires are certain to cause great damage to timber aud forage, and perhaps to homes and livestock as wel I.
Campers and travelei’S do not always realize that every large fire starts from a small one. By observing the following simple rules, the danger of fires can be greatly reduced.
Before building your camp fire clean the ground for a considerable distance around of all debris and inflammable material ; or dig a pit and wall it with rock.
Build your fire in the open and not against a tree or rotten and water-soaked logs. Be careful that it is not in a windy or exposed place where sparks are liable to be blown for considerable distances.
Before leaving camp, even for a few hours, always extinguish your fire by pouring water upon it, or, if water is not availble, cover thorouglily with dirt.
Be sure that your match is out before throwing it away. Extinguish your cigar and cigarette stubs and be careful that they, as well as. ashes from a pipe, are dropped where there is no inflammable material.
